description:
Still one of my favorite coffee spots. Blue bottle has been one of my favorites for the longest time and this location is a nice one! There's no seating or outlets/wifi for you to make yourself cozy, but it's in the ferry building! Such a beautiful location and the view of the bay bridge from the back is always nice. This is where I love taking visitors to. You get a beautiful view and you get to sip on some great coffee at the same time. 

I always go for the ice coffee here. Always high quality and it never disappoints. But really, try everything on their menu, it's all good. The only thing is that I tend to stay away from their cookies and things. It's alright, but not nearly as great as their coffees and it's pretty pricey too.
author: Julie L.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee used to be da Bomb!  However, through the years, with its expansion to other cities and with many other coffee roasters opening, I don't find them that great anymore.  My palate for my espresso may have change but I now realize I don't like sour espresso which is what I get from Blue Bottle Coffee!

I prefer my espresso to be bold and smooth so we asked the cashier's recommendation and she said get the Hayes Valley Espresso.  Just for kicks, I also ordered the Single Origin Espresso to compare.  The Single Origin was too sour and the Hayes Valley Espresso was only just a bit better and less sour.

It seems like I only make it a habit of going to Blue Bottle Coffee when I am In San Francisco, not because it is good, but because of the nostalgia of what it used to mean to me and what I thought was good before.

The staff at this location also wasn't too nice when I asked all my questions.  They were short with me and expressionless.  I didn't appreciate it, especially when they are located in an area where there are tons of tourists!
author: Johnny N.

description:
Last time I was here in SF, my friend had to go to a BB shop. I was forced to buy a cup of coffee and half a pound of beans. No, I'm just kidding. I wanted to make the purchase. The first time I went to a BB I believe I got a cold brew, and I recall it being really good. Today, I went with a regular drip coffee. I went with the cheaper option, and that was a very full bodies coffee! I had to add a good amount of creamer and simple syrup to help tame it down. That's usually a morning type brew, not a middle of the day! Lol. 

What I liked about this location is that it had 2 ordering locations. One in the main walkway and one off to the side, which basically no one was ordering from. So of course I went to that ordering location. I even had a chance to talk to the cashier for a bit to figure out what beverage I wanted before the next guest even walked up. 

I'll be back for more! I gotta work my way up to the $10 cup of drip coffee. Supposedly a rare bean!
author: Antonio L.

description:
Solid as Superwoman's chest.
Smooth as Lex Luthor's head.
Pricey as an overpriced organic Supermarket.

Location: The Ferry Building, San Francisco, CA. 

The above description is my view on Blue Bottle Coffee. It's hella good, but you pay for what you get: A quality coffee shop in the Ferry Building. Hey, I don't mind paying up for quality, but no chairs or tables or even an inside, instead an order counter and counter you may enjoy your drink. Of course, at the Ferry Building many spots to sit and enjoy. 

I'm cruising the waterfront and in the area so decide to drop by. It's my first time at Blue Bottle Coffee, I've had it before, but it was at a restaurant. I just recall it was happiness to my taste buds. I locate this location at the furthest left side of the building (if looking at the bay). I am enthusiastically greeted... I order a Latté and good vibes with that, please. The two barista's working were professional and cheery which is always a good thing to encounter. And before you know it.. "Latté for Eric!" 

My Latté was a work of art and filled to the lip. First sip was all I needed to remind me how good Blue Bottle Coffee is. I walkout and find a bench facing the Bay Bridge - I sip and savor every sip and savor. Ahh a reminder how good coffee is when made perfect. I question myself is this the best Latté ever? That's hard to answer since I've had the best coffees worldwide, but just entertaining the question should indicate that it's pretty darn good! 

In the end, I recommend Blue Bottle Coffee. You should try it at least twice and see if you consider it one of the best ever. It's up there. Just pay up. In fairness to Blue Bottle Coffee they do have actual coffee shops with cafe chairs throughout the city, but my experience was with this little one with pleasant baristas and zero chairs. Hey, grab a bench outside and share it with the city pigeons... hope it gives you super powers 'til the next time!
author: Eric R.

description:
One of my favorite third wave coffee shops! Love their branding and quality of the coffee they put out.

Though this location is notoriously busy, being located inside of the Ferry Building (which is usually jam-packed with tourists), I usually grab a cup of their Iced New Orleans when roaming around the Farmer's Market on Saturday mornings on the waterfront. 

Drinks come out in a timely manner, which is understandable considering the large masses of people who have ordered before you. Clean appearance. Well stocked napkins, signature blue straws and simple sugar syrup or sugar in the raw to sweeten things up- if you would like. Never had a badly made cup of coffee here. 

Also a tip, if the line gets too long here there is a side window just around the corner as well. You're welcome.
author: Janet N.

description:
This location takes FOREVER. For a latte, it took about 20 minutes. All the tourists are here and it's a small place. Just skip this location if you want coffee. Nonetheless, the coffee is good here. There really isn't any seating here either. 
Pros: coffee, friendly staff
Cons: lots of people, slow, no seating 
Stars :2.75
author: Sunny L.

description: I've been wanting to try this Bay Area staple for the longest time. Everything about this brand is so cool. I only have tried it through just their products sold in stores but never at a location when made fresh. I enjoyed the coffee here and will definitely be back. This location in particular is pretty packed so be aware!
author: Alex L.

description: Okay look, I'm a barista and I gotta hand it to these folks. They made the best cappuccino I've ever had. Perfect amount of foam, great artwork, amazing taste. My drink was made quickly, and the dude that took my order was nice. Will definitely stop by when I visit SF again.
author: Young J.

description:
Coveniently located outside of the ferry building!

Menu includes all the basic drinks you would get at a coffee shop. My go-to drink is an iced mocha and they make it perfectly here! Not super sweet and really good milk.

Lines can get pretty long during the week due to the farmers market. Limited seating next to the place.

Prices are ok for a coffee shop. However if you pay with Apple Pay you get 30% off your order which is very nice!! 

Customer service is ok and fast.

Overall nice coffee shop outside the ferry building with a good selection of coffee.
author: Michele G.

description:
I had heard about Blue Bottle Coffee but never tried it.  I'm a fan of third wave coffee and marked it on my list as a place I should try, chain or not.  I actually used to hate coffee only a few years ago.  Places like this have gotten me into it, much as craft breweries have gotten me into beer.

This location wasn't busy when I came by on a Tuesday morning.  Understand that there are 2 at the Ferry Building so you can go to either.  

I liked the service.  It was quick and one of the baristas was super knowledgeable.  Sometimes you can tell when someone is reading off a script and when they are truly passionate about something.  His suggestions to the guy in front of me had me wanting a drip but I decided to go ahead and have the NOLA iced coffee.  I ordered it without the knowledge that people go ga-ga over it.  I can see why they do.  It's excellent.  

Hopefully they open one in Vegas so I can enjoy one every day.
author: Christina R.

description:
I had the New Orleans coffee here and for being a chain (albeit one more local to SF) the quality of the coffee here was quite good. It was well chilled, the coffee had an excellent taste and the milk went along with it perfect.

They give you a choice of whether to sweeten it or not and even sweetened it was just the right amount, not an overbearing amount.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Blue Bottle is just dang good coffee. Actually, I dare say it's my FAVORITE coffee. It's super high quality, and I really think it's one of the best out there. I'm also a fan of Philz and Stumptown if that gives you a clue of what kind of coffee I like and helps you decide if you want to read the rest :)
Blue bottle stands out because they still do it by hand- dripping, filtering, steaming - none of those pots of coffee that sits for hours. 
Blue bottle has awesome drip coffee- rich, smooth, and not bitter. It's seriously so delicious that I drink it black. The cold brews are also one of the best. 
As far as location, this is a super popular location (read long lines). However, they know how to move quickly and the wait ends up being pretty quick. People are friendly even amidst the long line.
Definitely go here for amazing coffee- a special treat!!
author: Jen K.

description:
The line to order at this Blue Bottle Coffee location (in Ferry Building) is ALWAYS so quick!

If you don't know what you want, you might want to stand in front of the menu BEFORE you join the line, else you'll be going "ummmm..." in front of the cashier while the long line of caffeine addicts behind you start planning an attack.

Love taking these cups outside and sitting at one of the benches while fighting off some of the seagulls. :) It's a great spot: You could watch the ferries arriving and departing and on a clear day, Alcatraz is so visible.
author: Kislev A.

description:
Visiting from Elk Grove and staying in Oakland, I took the ferry to SF to imbibe some culture. There was no coffee in the house, so I decided to get my drink when I arrived. I strolled the 1 Ferry building and found Blue Bottle. They have enough of a reputation so that I knew I'd get a good cup of coffee.

It was almost frantically busy, but the order taker was someone at the top of his game. Two macchiatos in "to-stay" cups. My wife waited in the tiny seating area on the side, while I waited for my drinks.

...And waited. Finally, the barista's assistant asked me if I was waiting for something, and, when I told her, she said they were already delivered to my wife out of sight through the side window. I fumed a bit at my wife, but realized I'd been the victim of very sloppy service. The cups were paper, not the china I asked for, and the barista had somehow assumed that the drinks were for the woman by the window. Fine coffee, but lukewarm in a soggy cup.

If all you serve is coffee, a few at a time, and make two mistakes in an order, I'd say there was a staffing problem. In any case, I doubt I'll choose Blue Bottle again.
author: John M.

description:
Frequented the Ferry Building location. 
Two words: Simple and SMOOTH. 
That's all I really want from my coffee, I don't need crazy flavors or any crazy concoctions. Blue Bottle serves coffee as it should be served and offers simple syrup/sugar on the side to add to your liking. This shows me they focus on the coffee itself. I was most impressed with how smooth the coffee was, no heartburn or acidic taste afterwards I could probably knock back two or three with ease. One of the best lattes I've ever had. Glad I went. Easy to order and staff is friendly but gets the job done.
author: Raquel G.

description: The Ferry Building is always fun to visit- but Blue Bottle Coffee is the real reason I go into the Ferry Building. The coffee is so good that people who add cream don't even feel the need to add any. And don't forget the views ;)
author: Sydney G.

description: There is nothing wrong in getting a second cup while passing a different location of your favorite coffee place. My goal is to hit 3 by days end.
author: Basil M.

description:
I stopped by this location today after my long run.  Normally the line is very long but today there were 4 people inline to order but many were waiting for their drinks.  It took no more than 5 mins wait for me to place my order and get my coffee - super happy!

I always get the New Orleans iced coffee. It's rich, tasty and just the right amount of sweetness.  I wish they have different size option for this drink.  It only comes in one size which is not enough for me :( (this is the only reason I took one star) 

Staffs here are very friendly!

They have a "secret" coffee bar tucked around the corner from their main cafe - a lot of people don't know about, so when the line is very long just go around the corner and you'll see the other window!! 

I took my coffee outside by the waterfront and enjoyed it while sitting on the bench!
author: Junaline G.

description:
I thrive on the feeling of walking down the street with a dang good iced coffee -- especially if it has a blue straw.

Blue Bottle nails both espresso & coffee drinks. Their flavor profile is not too acidic or overly toasty. It's juuuust right. 

My first drink from Blue Bottle was the New Orleans on a sunny day in Palo Alto. It remains my favorite even on a ridiculously chilly day in San Francisco!  

It's sweetened and creamed with chicory syrup + whole milk. Keep it exactly as is - no non-dairy subs, less sugar, whatever you do to your Starbucks order - Blue Bottle has nailed this one. Trust. 

If you're not in the mood for iced, try their pour overs. They usually have 2 roasts to choose from, so ask the barista what their favorite is.  

Blue Bottle is a total classic! A must if you're in the Bay Area.
author: Monica H.

description:
Craving some artisan coffee while walking around the Ferry Building and we came across this little shop. Tried the Samovar (herbal tea) sage mint 
and a Cappuccino. The shop gets busy as there are many patrons who visit this tourist attraction, so understandably, there is a wait to get your coffee. The tea was quite delicious and I was told the cappuccino was also quite good! I'd recommend coming here for a different coffee experience. I would've love to have tried the single drip coffee but I don't like caffeine at night so I stuck with the tea. Come here to grab something hot as you explore and sightsee around the ferry bldg! We came at night and enjoyed the bay bridge lights while sipping on our warm liquids.
author: Heidi A.

description: One of my favorite coffee shops ever. There isn't a blue bottle anywhere near where I live so I always make sure to grab a cup anytime I'm in the city. The coffee is on the pricier side, but it's definitely worth it. It doesn't taste watered down like typical Starbucks or Peet's coffee.
author: Kelly C.

description:
The coffee here is good. I drink my coffee black so I get all the flavour or I'm just crazy. But black coffee I find taste the best.

I stumbled upon this place completely by accident, I was walking downtown and saw it and walked in. 

I'll have to check out the other locations also. I had no idea it was a chain till I looked it up.
author: Jae L.

description:
I know Blue Bottle is awesome enough to be super popular in LA, too, but for some reason I never pass by when I'm in a coffee mood.. That is until Christmas weekend! 

I passed by and wanted affogato. So for Christmas, I bought myself affogato. 

Oh my. My taste buds died and went to heaven. The espresso was delectfully bitter and not too acidic - I like my coffee strong so I loved this! The two scoops of (vanilla bean?) ice cream topped with that caramel nutty thing - so delicious.
author: Verena K.

description:
I am normally just a regular coffee drinker, so I was not expecting much when I stopped here for coffee. I just really needed a pick me up that day and I am glad I choose Blue Bottle instead of Philz.

At first I was a little turned off seeing how at first glance it seems like a hipster coffee place where they charge you an arm and a leg for mediocre coffee. Boy was I wrong.

The line gets pretty long here since it is in the busy Ferry Building. I lined up around 5 o clock and the line was still pretty long. It went by pretty quickly with no hassle. I opted for the cafe latte, and it was pretty much the best latte I have ever had. The coffee had just enough bitterness and sweetness making it the perfect cup of joe. The staff was very friendly and made my experience much more exciting. It was so good that we got it two days in a row! I enjoyed every sip of this drink and it was the perfect size for a midday pickmeup. I will be back next time I am in the bay for their amazing drinks!
author: Michelle T.

description:
Went here on recommendation, our order was taken quickly and payment was vastly processed. My wife and I received our drinks quickly after paying. 
Everyone behind the counter was very nice and greeted you with a smile. The area was clean and well organized. 
The drinks tasted great! Leaving me disappointed with the portion size as they seemed a bit small for the price. 
Overall I recommend everyone to give them a try!
author: Christopher S.

description: My fiancé finally took me out on his day off so we just went roaming around the area and he noticed Blue Bottle Coffee from afar. He was so excited that he started running towards it and took his phone out to take snaps to send to his friends. I never even heard of this place so I'm just standing wondering what's so special about their coffee. So we both ordered the New Orleans Iced Coffee and it was delicious. It had the perfect amount of sugar, cream, and the coffee itself was amazing. I'm not a crazy coffee drinker but I'd have this again if I come across it.
author: Neloffer E.

description: I had a mocha that had a rich chocolate flavor, it was delicious. My fiance had the cold brew which was standard. His coffee came out right away, mine only took 3 minutes. We were here on a Wednesday around 11am. Not much else to say!
author: Christina M.

description: Longest line for coffee that I have ever waited in! I mistakenly came here during the farmer's market time and talked up Blue Bottle to the out of towners who love coffee and did not want to leave till we got it.
author: Sunil R.

description:
How to drink coffee like a boss - in 5 steps. 
(1) Stroll over to the Ferry Building. Head to Blue Bottle Coffee. 
(2) Avoid the long lines out front and go to the side window. 
(3) Order a single espresso - in a Demitasse cup. They serve it with a small glass of sparkling water (so you can cleanse your mouth and enjoy every sip to the max). 
(4) Take your Cup and Glass to the walkway outside and find a bench overlooking the water. 
(5) Enjoy your coffee - like a boss!
author: Navin K.

description: Great coffee, good quality milk, and excellent aroma. We went to the one in the ferry building. It's very crowded morning and afternoon, but worth the wait. They are fast with their service.
author: Nikki J.

description: The coffee here is one of the best coffees' I've ever tried as it is strong, tasty, and smooth. I ordered a latte and it was delicious. Other than the coffee, the service is SUPER slow! I waited about 15-20 minutes for my drink when i was second in line.
author: Mimi V.

description:
Went here today and got an iced caffe mocha. I was going to substitute with almond milk until the barista suggested I go with the "oat milk" option that was popular among the baristas. I decided to go for it, and it definitely gave the mocha a very unique flavor. The oat milk also made my drink a bit creamier than one typically finds in a mocha, but in a good way. I'll definitely go with this combination again.

Also, the male barista with the nose ring is super cute #sorrynotsorry
author: Filip H.

description: Great customer service, loved the latte art. Coffee wasn't the best I've ever had, but it was still good. I'd go back if it was in the area. I wouldn't go searching for it again though.
author: Justine E.

description:
I've never tried blue bottle coffee and have heard about all the raves. When we arrived in San Francisco and saw a blue bottle coffee shop inside Ferris Building, there is no reason not to try!

We ordered the caffee latte and drip coffees (both grande and Kenya)

The barista was super nice and friendly and gave us her personal favorite (two shots of espresso with equal amount of milk) in a glass for free. We could not be more grateful
author: Sunny X.

description: Line is very long, especially on weekends but don't let that scare you away. The employees are quick here! Hot chocolate, coffee, cappuccino are delicious. Great location, too.
author: Juan M.

description:
If you want cheap coffee that taste like garbage, pass this place up.  

Blue bottle has to be my absolute favorite treat, which I only get one in a blue moon.  They know their coffee.

There is usually a line, so waiting is a given.  But what do you expect?  It's a small shop in the ferry building.

Customer service is great.  Everyone feels genuinely nice.  I give Phil's coffee the best customer service in the coffee business, but blue bottle a close second.
author: Nathan S.

description:
Well i'll be darned. This was actually some of the best coffee i've ever had. There's not many things I find more obnoxious than some of the newer wave of coffees that tend to be just a huge flavorless cup of acid designed to wake the dead.

Blue Bottle Coffee really proved that your coffee can be strong while maintaining that lovely quintessential roasted coffee flavor. The entire time I was sipping it I was so confused because it was honestly just such a nicely balanced flavor but with the obvious kick of caffeine you need for the day.

This had to be one of my favorites while visiting SF. Will definitely be back here first on my next visit! Absolutely amazing!
author: Michael C.

description:
After a tiresome Saturday, we decided to go to the ferry building to have some coffee. I think we were lucky that we stopped at this shop. My wife is not a huge fan of coffee but she loved this one.

Definitely a nice way to close a Saturday.
author: Qasim Z.

description:
TL;DR smoooth smoooth (expensive) coffee

PLUSES:
+ best lattes ever
+ long lines, but they go by pretty fast
+ in the ferry building, can grab a bite anywhere to go w/ your coffee
author: Sophia L.

description:
I get Blue Bottle Coffee very occasionally because I typically make my own coffee at home, and when I don't, I sometimes get coffee from other closer coffee shops to work. My favorite menu item is probably the New Orleans Iced Coffee.

I think my biggest complaint would be the fact that you get a pretty small amount of coffee for the price that you pay (usually around 4 - 5 dollars), and as a fast drinker, I tend to finish the darn thing before I even get back to the office!

I've been meaning to try their cold Brew, but haven't gotten a chance yet. It's interesting to note that you can get Blue Bottle ice cream at Humphry Slocombe across the hallway, though I have yet to try that either.

Tldr, if you want to try some nice coffee, the NOLA iced coffee is the way to go!
author: Ed W.

description:
This place is worth the hype.  As a graduate student I live off of Starbucks coffee on campus. I can definitely taste the difference in richness and flavor. Nothing unnecessary is added.  It's all I wanted in coffee. 

The line is long but moves quickly so make sure you decide your order before you get to the register.
author: Vanessa N.

description:
Love Blue Bottle Coffee! There was no line at mid-morning on a Wednesday. The New Orleans Ice coffee was amazing, as always. It was a smooth and flavorful drink. I wish the cups were larger! This is the same drink they sell in the small "milk cartons" at the grocery stores or at Costco.

Located in the beautiful the Ferry Building toward Gotts.
author: Tim Y.

description: There are certain tourist activities that are needed in every city. In SF, I would argue that the Ferry Building Market is a must visit if you have never been. This coffee shop is located inside and will treat visitors to some great coffee but it comes at a premium. Lines can be very long later in the day and the prices are high for coffee. They do offer non-dairy milk alternatives but you have to ask for them. They aren't on the menu. Visitors will not be upset with the coffee here and it goes really well with the chocolate sold right across the hall. I would recommend.
author: Patrick G.

description: There was a survey on line the other day asking my taste preferences and was directed to Blue  Bottle Bella Donovan.  So while in Ferry Building I picked up the beans.  My guests and I really enjoyed the smooth blend for our Sunday cuppa.  New fav!!!
author: Jodi M.

description:
Gotta try Blue Bottle Coffee while in San Francisco. This coffee shop is located inside the Ferry Building and there's always a line for it. 

I savor that caffe latte!! I love how strong it is, it was a little bit bitter for my taste and I had to add 2 packets of brown sugar. But BOY does it wake you up!!!! I bought a couple of sample coffee grounds as well, I have not yet tried it. 

Good luck trying to look for parking. 

Can't wait to come back to San Francisco to get some more coffee.
author: Hazel Chastine R.

description: Blue Bottle is the most amazing coffee. I'm not sure if it's due to their fresh roasted beans or if it's the pour over method they use. I'm sure it's a combination of those things and more.  Plus I'd like to mention that their customer service is excellent! Anytime I'm in San Francisco I try to get a cup of Blue Bottle, and usually I try for a cup a day while I'm there because there is not a better coffee that I have found.  It's flavorful and rich and so smooth. I'm wishing for a cup while I'm sitting here writing this, but I'm 2,000 miles away.  I'll always hope Blue Bottle is still around when I make it back to San Francisco. If you haven't yet tried their coffee you are missing out. Definitely give them a try and you will be so happy you did.
author: Kate D.

description: We go here to grab a bag of beans to take back home and grab a cup of refreshing cold brew. Lines aren't so bad here. And then go to Humphry Slocombe for a scoop (or two) of Secret Breakfast.
author: Lynto L.

description: There was a giant line for this coffee spot and I didn't understand why! I remember seeing this place in NY before, but I never got the chance to try it. All drinks will cost you almost $5, and they're pretty no frills and stick with the basics. I just got an iced coffee cold brew for about $4.75, and I will say that it was nice and smooth with very little acidity. It didn't even need creamer or milk! I see why this place has such a following, though I'm not sure I could wait in line like this all the time for $5 for a small cup. On the bright side, they are very quick with their orders and the employees are all very friendly.
author: Monica L.

description:
--LOCATION-- Ferry Building Market place, across from Miette Patisserie

--MENU-- they have coffees, lattes, macchiato, iced coffees, mochas, etc. Typical coffee selection.

LATTE ($5): it's very comparable to other lattes I've had. You can choose which type of dairy/non-dairy you'd like too (but some options cost extra). Comes piping hot.

--OVERALL-- I find it a solid place to get coffee. The hype may have effected my expectations because I didn't find it absolutely amazing. 

They really need coffee cup sleeves!! Ask for a second cup to act as a sleeve.

It's too pricey.
author: Telena V.

description: I visited on a Friday. It was busy, but the line moved quickly and the service was great- the place was clean and had a nice vibe. I had trouble deciding when I got to the front and I was surprised at how nice the server was! Even though there was probably a steady stream of people all day (such a busy area) Terry was friendly and smiling and so helpful! I went back and forth between something hot or cold and he didn't make me feel stupid for not knowing the menu. I ended up getting the New Orleans iced coffee with oat milk. I HATE almond milk and he assured me that oat milk tasted different- he was right! Its hard to find a place with good service in this city, I'll be back for sure :)
author: Andreya W.

description: Came for farmer market so we stopped by for a cup of morning coffees.  Ordered Caffè latte which was nice.  Service is nice and friendly.  There is a long wait line for order and another long line for pick up.  It's nice to pick up a cup of hot coffee and walk around this building.  Price is around $4.50 per cup of latte.  We used public transportation to avoid the parking chaos down in this area.
author: Sydney T.

description: We came here for a quick coffee & wAffle (delicious). It was so good it didn't need any syrup or toppings. The price was great and they were very fast in making our coffees. We'll be back
author: Harry H.

description: I had a great time talking to this guy working at Blue Bottle Coffee named Ryan. He was very accommodating while I was asking him about their coffees . He even offered me a free pour over of their "Three Africas" which is really good. While I was about to purchase a coffee bean bag from them, I mentioned that I also work at a coffee shop and I want to share it with my co workers. He said that he's happy to talk and see other baristas coming to their store so he ended up giving me the coffee bean bag of Three Africas for free! I'm so glad I visited their store at Ferry Building. I had an awesome experience with them! Thanks again, BLUE BOTTLE COFFEE! (via IG: notgretelle)
author: Gretelle D.

description:
In a town where there is the smell of coffee (along with bakeries and ice cream) on every block, blue bottle was definitely one that stood out! 

We were drawn in by the simplicity, yet sleek, design of their space in the ferry building.  Hubby got a cappuccino and I just got an iced coffee.  The espresso of his cappuccino was definitely strong...how A espresso drink should be!   And when a coffee joint delivers your ice coffee straight up, black, you know it's not messing around with foo foo coffee drinks!

Good coffee and cute blue straws! =
author: Alice L.

description:
If you're in San Francisco, you definitely need to grab a cup of Blue Bottle Coffee, especially if you're walking around the Marketplace. While they have been expanding to SoCal, Blue Bottle Coffee is still incredibly well-known in SF. Their coffee is really good that it justifies the wait in line. 

Their menu is pretty simple - I've only tried three things from Blue Bottle, and both I really enjoyed. Prices are also pretty decent considering the fact that you are paying for high quality coffee. I'm not a big coffee person, but I've been learning to enjoy it more as I become older. 

Out of all the drinks that I've tried, I definitely recommend the New Orleans cold brew if you are into smooth and not too sweet coffee. This drink was incredibly smooth and not too bitter yet not too sweet. I could really taste the quality of the ingredients that were used to make it. I've also tried both the cappuccino and the macchiato. I love how they always top off the drink with coffee art - definitely makes for a pretty Instagram picture. The macchiato is always a bit too bitter for my liking (but still - flavor is top quality), but the cappuccino is a favorite - subtle, not too overwhelming, and definitely hits the spot on a cold SF day. You can pretty much walk outside and enjoy the view with a cup of Blue Bottle Coffee in your hand. It's amazing! 

The workers are super friendly and eager to help you out if you need a minute or two to decide. Drinks don't take too long to make, so hopefully you'll be in and out of line within ten minutes. 

tl;dr - A must try if you love coffee and decide to walk around the Marketplace. Always hits the spot whether it is a cold or hot day.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Yes I waited in a huge line, yes it was delicious. I asked the guy taking my order if I should get a latte or a mocha - Meaning which was their specialty, but he just explained the difference in the drinks to me, and I felt silly. I wanted to tell him I knew the difference, but feared that would even make me look more foolish. I got the mocha. 

Once i was waiting for my order I saw lots of tips about a sidewalk kiosk that was never busy, but I never found it. Perfect sheen on my mocha and it was a nice deep cocoa flavor without tasting like pure sugar...delicious! 

As Blue Bottle continues to expand, I hope they make their way into the Las Vegas market, I really want to try their affogato, and the New Orleans cold brew.
author: Ranae W.

description:
It's completely exorbitant. I can't believe think that a latte is CHEAPER than a pour over coffee. But that's their shtick. It's quite a production to watch them using their cute metal pitchers to do the pour over, which I like to do while munching on a blondies or a pretzel roll. 

I go here regularly on Wednesday's for a coffee splurge. I could not afford to go here as a daily habit. But the coffee really is exceptional so I enjoy my weekly treat. 

I like to challenge the barrista a But and ask for a coffee consult. I tell them what mood aim in and can they suggest what i should drink. It's a joke on my part but they take it in stride. 

I really like that they flavors they promise you to show up in the pour overs actually do show up. Toffee and leather are pretty neat to taste. You don't get that at a Starbucks or a Peet's much as I enjoy those places for what they are.
author: Tim P.

description: My second time here and every bot as good as the first . Delightful staff and a great product. The Ferry building is a food lovers paradise with so many options. It's good to see Blue bottle really busy! Looking forward to next time in town
author: Laurence K.

description:
Located inside the Marketplace on the far west end. There's no name or witty signage to grab your attention, just a blue bottle and lots of people in line. The coffee is good, hence the long line. They also have coffee beans, coffee makers, books, chocolate and small grab & go food items.

Service was fast, friendly & efficient. It's small so, sort of like a walk-up coffee shop with a couple (as in 2) seats located on side of the cafe. 

I was pleased with the taste of my well crafted Cappuccino but the $1 up-charge for Almond Milk was a bit extravagant. 

I'll round my 3.5 down to a solid 3 for the lack of space and astronomical cost for healthy choices (milk alternative).

~Christy
author: Christy A.

description:
This place definitely lives up to the hype. I stopped by on a cold, rainy day. Before I start, I want to point out that I am actually not a huge coffee person. I survived college without coffee, but I recently got into it for the taste. 

I ordered a cafe mocha, and oh my gosh it was rich. Even as an amateur coffee drinker, I can taste the difference in quality. The pretty foam art was a plus. I'm also a sucker for packaging, and the simple blue logo is everything. 

As expected, the drinks are a bit expensive. However, you're in San Francisco and in the touristy Marketplace area -- treat yo'self.
author: Karen C.

description: Boutique coffee at its best! And this place opens early so avoid the sheeple at Starbucks and Philz and make your way to the Ferry Building for great coffee.
author: Gerald H.

description: They always have a huge queue in front of their store but it goes pretty fast as the service is efficient.  I really liked that they use organic milk. They have lots of options to choose from.  I had cappuccino which was great.
author: Ruchi S.

description: So good! Stopped for their New Orleans iced coffee this morning and it was perfect. Just what I needed to wake up. Also, their waffle was so flavorful! It was a great breakfast for me!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Maybe I'm not a coffee connoisseur but I really don't think it tastes much different from Starbucks.  The staff was friendly and received the coffe fast but it was just OK. I had the iced coffee which was good but had to add some simple syrup for it to taste better.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
Before I headed out to San Francisco to visit my sister a got countless recommendations to visit Blue Bottle Coffee. Then my own sister picked up the call as well, touting their praises. I rolled my eyes because coffee to me is something I drink to get through a long work day on limited sleep thanks to the toddler in my house and one coffee is just like another to me. But since I had a day to kill by myself in San Francisco and was already at the ferry building I figured I'd give it a try. And with that everything I knew about coffee was blown out of the water. This place was amazing!!! The lines were long and I'm sure the high prices were inflated thanks to the touristy location of being inside the ferry building, but it was all worth it. I took my coffee outside and just marveled at the sights of the bay while drinking the most delicious latte I had ever had.

It was so delicious that on my last day in San Francisco I made a special trip to the ferry building just to have another latte before making my way to the airport.
author: Sonja H.

description:
Defiantly one of my top coffee houses. Had a dark roast blend. 

The line was a little long but the wait was pretty short. The baristas were all really kind and made sure I liked the taste before I left.
author: Louis T.

description: There's no doubt Guy Fieri would offer the barista a knuckle busting fist bump and an enthusiastic "Flavortown!" after sipping this bean water. It's a damn good cup-o-joe. In a perfect world, every first sip of coffee in the morning would taste fist bump worthy as Blue Bottle. But at what price? At what price do you make a pact with the devil for a mouthgasmic trip to Flavortown? I paid $10.00. My first thought was the cashier botched my order and charged me for 1/2 pound of beans. No such luck. I paid $10.00 for a cup of coffee! I've heard of expensive coffee where the bean is harvested after it passes through the digestive track of a goat or something. These weren't those beans. Now, there's a chance I ordered the most expensive roast on the menu -and- there's a chance I was being charged tourist prices at the Ferry Bldg. But I paid $10.00 for a tiny cup of coffee and I'd prob do it again. Tell me again why millennials can't afford homes...
author: Nick O.

description: Yes I am a fan of all of the blue bottle locations, At times I wonder why do I wait in such a long line at the Ferry Building and then once I take the first sip I remember. Yes it is that good. Today I ordered a Ginger cookie for my wife and they forgot to give it to us. No problem, I went back and they gave us two for the mistake. That is what customer service should be. and that is why I will always choose Blue bottle first. Quality, Consistency and Great people that care about making great coffee.
author: Manny G.

description:
I'd heard of Blue Bottle Coffee and though there are several locations in my own town I ended up trying it for the first time in SF because damn Philz was closed. I had the cappuccino which I never get because I hate foam but this was actually REALLY good. It's just GOOD coffee, deep, flavorful, not sweet but not overtly bitter.

The line was super long and I waited about half an hour for one cup of coffee (ugh) but what can you say when they are hand pouring each one, and it's a work of art. My one gripe about this place is PEOPLE NEED TO READ THE MENU AND MAKE UP THEIR MINDS WHILE WAITING, not start to look at the menu once you get to the barista and they ask you what you want. I was SOOOOOOOOOOOO frustrated when people in front of me were just staring in to space while waiting for over half an hour then began to contemplate the menu extremely seriously and wasted even more time. 

Unsure of what parking is like, but this place is reasonably easily accessible by public transport and ride share services.
author: Amy K.

description: First time at this blue bottle location and it was ok. Busy location with tourists (I visited on a Sunday) but the service was quick and the coffee good. I ended up getting their affogato (my first!) and loved it. I'd get it again but at a different location. Get the affogato if you're craving ice cream and coffee. :)
author: Mira B.

description: As a new Bay area resident, I swore I would never fall for fancy, expensive coffee. I definitely hadn't  heard of a  pour over before. But I think Blue Bottle has converted me. I love the smooth taste. It's liquid gold! The New Orleans Iced Coffee is a must try-not overly sweet and definitely satisfies the sweet tooth!
author: Sharmila C.

description:
Really really good cafe latte and mocha. Friendly staff. Got my day off to a great start!

Order from the side if/when there's a line up front.
author: David D.

description:
I love blue bottle. I also love coffee. Add in my deep, passionate love for the Embarcadero and you get the blue bottle location in the ferry building ( they even have a stall outside the ferry building!)

There are a couple of drinks Iv tried here and some are good and some are different:

Cold brew[New Orleans]: ICE COFFEE LOVERS THIS IS YOUR DRINK!!!! It's a perfect balance of strong coffee but it's also not too bitter or earthy. Perfect with a bit of simply syrup and milk.

Cold brew[single origin]: Very strong and bitter, I added a lot of simple syrup and milk but it still tasted very bitter. If you like an iced coffee that's bitter and has an earthy taste this is your drink.

Cafe Mocha: When chocolate and coffee have a child this is their baby. Simple perfection. The chocolate doesn't overpower the coffee and they compliment each other perfectly. Even if you are not a hot drink person you have to try this!!!!!!!!!!
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Sunday morning at the ferry building I wanted some ice cream. I needed some coffee. Believe it or not, as I was waiting on line at HS, I received a text from N-- get an Affogato at Blue Bottle. So I did a 180 and ordered an Affogato at Blue Bottle. OMG. Best thing ever!  

I am thinking about it now, as I sit here with my drip coffee...:(
author: Kris M.

description:
Always hit this spot when we are in SF.  Well worth the long line, trust me!  Just be sure to know what you want before you jump in line (hate when people hold up the line geeze).
Hard if not impossible to find seating on weekend.
author: Jill S.

description:
I'm so glad I finally got the chance to try blue bottle coffee. I've had opportunities to try it but it was from cafes "proudly brewing" their coffee. I wanted to actually go to one of their places with their baristas so I could get the full effect. 
I got my usually order of a shot of espresso and a pour over. I just loved the richness of the different notes that each sip exemplified. The espresso was pulled perfectly and the pour had just the perfect ratio of coffee to water. And big kudos for having the pour over done as soon as I was done paying. It was almost like getting a drip coffee at other spots but as a pour over. 
The hype is definitely real and definitely worth it. Blue bottle. Bam!
author: Jonas S.

description: Delicious caffe mocha.  In the Ferry Building right across the street from our hotel.
author: K P.

description: I had Blue Bottle coffee before and was not a fan, but on this occasion, it changed my mind.  The coffee was much better, I actually can taste the hardy favor of the bean when it is served on ice.  I love strong, bold coffee, and at this particular Blue Bottle, they made just that and even better, because when coffee is served cold, the boldness and richness of coffee may dissipated and melted with the ice. It is much better than I ever had before.  Yes, the line is long and wished they had mentioned there is also another smaller section on the other side of their store to release the overcrowding waits.
author: Frances C.

description:
3.5 Stars

I've always been puzzled by the Blue Bottle fever; the location I walk past twice a day almost always has a queue stretching out the door and down the block. (Huh? Isn't this the land of startups with free coffee and snacks? This place must be good...)

Even with that thought - daily - I never went in. (And your girl loves coffee.)

I finally got to try Blue Bottle down by the Embarcadero. I got an iced latte and even took a cool pic of it with the Bay Bridge in the background, only to lose the picture (I snapped it and forgot to save -- woops!).

My coffee was good, not great; I don't think it was worth $4. That said, it wasn't bad. I don't know what it is about iced coffee in the Bay, but I've had some iced lattes that were down-right nauseating. This one wasn't.

Blue Bottle's coffee is very mild. It's pleasant, but there's nothing remarkable about it. I'm not sure why I'm going on and on rewording the same sentiment 10x. Perhaps I'm a bit let down. With all the hype, I expected more.
author: Nic Z.

description: Was out and about on a Sunday afternoon, and after searching through tons of closed coffee shops, saw this place was open. Showed the bf and we decided why not. The line wasn't too long, and thankfully everyone knew what they wanted which made it go by pretty fast too. The bf tried the New Orleans Coffee, and let me have a sip. Absolutely delicious. He finished it probably five minutes after getting it lol. I tried their affogato, interesting but wasn't for me, and I ended up pawning it off to the bf who loved it as well. Would be five stars, but the wait for the drinks took what felt like forever. Other than that, worth another visit!
author: Marcos A.

description: What an amazing cup of coffee. Don't come expecting the fast food mentality of fast brewed coffee or espresso, this coffee takes time to brew individual cups of pour over coffee and it's worth every single minute. Lines can be long to even get to the order counter, but truly this coffee is worth the wait... Wish we had one of these in Portland Oregon!
author: J M.

description:
I don't drink coffee often (I'm more of a tea drinker) so when I want some good roasted caffeinated beans, I treat myself to Blue Bottle.  To me, I find that their lattes are almost buttery, their coffee has great acidity, and I even love the New Orleans Iced Coffee in a box.  

There's often a line at this location but the wait is worth it. Also, if you haven't tried it yet, get the Liege Waffle!
author: Maya S.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is one of my favorite coffee shops in SF. Located in the touristy and upscale Ferry Buildling, their iced mochas are very smooth and not too sweet, just a perfect all-around beverage! 

Service is very friendly and they take credit cards via Square. 

They use TCHO chocolate to make their Mochas! :)

There's a second counter in the alley, if the main counter at the front is too congested! ;)
author: Derek S.

description:
Try to ignore the long lines, the high prices, and the overall snobbery of the place and focus on what's truly important: the coffee! This is some quality brew. If the coffee wasn't so good I'd never put up with all of this crap. 

The baristas craft your coffee with the utmost care and it shows (pretty designs on top if you order a cappuccino). Great flavor, high quality milk and a cup of joe that really delivers a gourmet experience. I had a cappuccino and it was delicious, very strong and obviously made with high quality beans. 

There are some small outdoor tables where you can sit and watch the bustle of San Francisco pass you by, but this is not your traditional coffee house (i.e., no comfy couches to lounge around on and no tables for working on your laptop). A great stop for a tasty coffee break.
author: Louisa M.

description:
While in line, I over heard this between two guys.
"Man, the line is long."
"Why is it so long?"
"There's a Starbucks over there.  Is this really that much better that Starbucks?"
"Nah.  Let's go."

Woman behind me could barely contain herself.  

Oh yeah.  The coffee is worth the wait.
author: S F.

description:
Caffeine done right + fresh waffles = perfect start to the morning! 

Despite the Sunday craze, service was super fast. We got the Cold Brew (Three Africans) with Almond Milk ($1 extra) plus some fresh, piping hot waffles. 

Coffee = on point. There's a reason why this place is so popular; they know exactly what they're doing. If you love your coffee, you gotta give Blue Bottle a try!

Waffles = wonderfully fluffy and piping hot. Not too sweet and the perfect complement to the ice cold coffee. They totally nailed the texture: fluffy on the outside, and slight crisp around the edges. If eaten by itself, the waffle is a little bit on the blander side, just because the waffle doesn't come with any syrup/sugar/whipped cream - so definitely best paired with coffee! Or perhaps some ice cream from Humphry Slocombe nearby! ;)
author: Joyce W.

description:
I love this place! 

I've found my favorite here, which is the Mocha, omg delicious drank. I've been really into mochas lately and I've been trying it all over the city. The mocha here is delicious and they use Tcho chocolate! They use really high quality ingredients and you can taste the difference.

My boyfriend loves the New Orleans iced coffee here, which I think is good too. But I have a sweet tooth so I usually go for the syrup on the side table :)

I've also tried their affogato before, which is a delicious ice cream treat with a shot of espresso poured all over. They made sure I was there before pouring the espresso which was really satisfying to watch, lol.

They usually have a long line, but it's really quick. Plus, if you order the iced coffee, they make it on the spot real quick & dirty.
author: Melanie T.

description:
So about this blue bottle--this imagery for coffee left me wondering, as I took another sip from the man's cup... which was pleasantly robust (for him), though a bit much for my weaker palate... I didn't bother brewing small talk because, you know, being a tourist for only a few days while wanting to see and do everything, inc. climb the Golden Gate (as Kong did, or didn't?) demanded more of my precious little time and further divided half-attention...

I also haven't much to say about this particular stand located inside the Ferry Building (which is kinda cool, itself, for its variety of eateries and gift shops--I'm talking CHOCOs and 'shrooms, among others) and where you can kill quite a few birds at one trip... I mean, I don't eat meat, but I at least manage to knock down three huge vegan spring rolls from Imperial Tea Court, which is obviously another story--so. Just picture a modern coffee lab, a la the Park Slope branch (where we tried the salted CHOCO cookie I didn't care for, but that the guys liked), except without the seating... Other than that, I haven't really had a chance to even try the drinks here, except a sip of the man's coffee, as I had already mentioned. Nor do I feel inclined to--I don't know, we'll see--maybe in New York... It's cloudy right now, and there are tons of cafes and coffee shops to overwhelm even your twins ADD and OCD (you wrote this at Brewshot, which you have yet to yelp about--but you digress again, jaded one).

The logo intrigues though... Intriguingly evocative of clean water... And I've always liked most shades of blue and any allusion to water... So maybe it's the idea behind it..? (Though I didn't read up on it. Perhaps someone else has the time to visit the website and let us all know??)

But here's for blue bottle--yet don't take my word for it, okay? Just try to have fun with it, and don't lose your interest and meaning in the crashing tides of modernity... Cheers~
author: Mikaya S.

description: Their fresh waffle is the best. I always order one for my afternoon snack. Good size and tasty.
author: Ihsuan Y.

description:
Cute little coffee stand serving awesome coffee. You see those pictures with all those cool designs in their lattes, well this is it.

They use iPads for their transactions and it was down at the moment so the owner (or what I presumed to be the owner, asian lady) gave us our orders for free. I guess I have Apple to thank for that.

The worker also dropped the case of pastries and so I felt bad so I gave them a generous tip.
author: John C.

description:
I think I've fallen in love!

One thing around me: I don't drink coffee. Never have, never will. But that's okay. Because did you know, Blue Bottle Coffee actually does great TEA?

I've become addicted to their black tea. Yep, I have. $3 a pop for a fairly small cup, but it's delightful.

I think it's how it's brewed (they don't use your bog-standard tea bag).

You can also free-pour their natural (I think) sugar and cream, allowing you to customize your perfect cup.

Can't wait to try the southern California locations. 

TIP: with this location, there are TWO areas to be served from: the line at the front of the shop, and also a little window to the left. The smaller window is considerably less crowded.
author: Kristin Leigh M.

description: Delicious latte! Same price as anywhere else in SF. This location is outside and has a few tables and chairs to sit. No outlets for chargers.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Incredible customer service- they gave us two samples of cold brew without us asking and we walked away super happy. Nicest people ever. Will come again. We are from Seattle where we know good coffee and it was refreshing to have good quality.
author: Kate R.

description:
Amazing overnight oats!! Made with almond milk for the lactards. We also had the waffles which did live up the hype. Lightly sweetened, warm, soft, dense. Mmmm. 

The "drip" coffee is actually V60 pourover (we had some terminology confusion) but it was really good. 

It's rather expensive but that's par for the SF snobby coffee scene. Downside is, there aren't many places to sit but we found a bench out back of the ferry building overlooking the bay and bay bridge so that was solid.
author: Jessie B.

description: The tall barista with the Buddha tattoo was extremely friendly !! I was a bad a morning but he turned it around with his small talk!
author: Kevin T.

description: Great coffee. I was, however, put off when the payment tablet asked me to choose a tip of $1, 2, or 3 for a $5 takeaway coffee. That's 20-40-60%. I noticed that larger orders were offered 15-20-25%. That still seems like a lot for takeaway even in SF, but they shouldn't try to get more just because I was a single customer ordering one item.
author: Linda M.

description:
The only Blue Bottle that will do affogato with "brown butter sugar" ice cream instead of vanilla (and doesn't tell you ahead of time or have vanilla ice cream as an option). 

I wouldn't recommend the affogato here but I'm sure the coffee it's still good.
author: Ming Y.

description:
Cute hipster place with friendly service. 
We had a New Orleans Ice coffee and a cappuccino. 
New Orleans: amazing cold brew ice coffee!!! Perfectly sweetened and creamed. Wow - you can still taste the depth of rich and smokey flavor. Get this!!!
The cappuccino was full bodied, smooth, rich and flavorful. No bitterness here. One of my favorites ever!
author: Anne O.

description:
I'm hesitant to say... but I think this is the best latte I've ever had. Picture a chilly, windy afternoon, the Embarcadero beckoning you to walk down it. Enter Blue Bottle - a stop for a quick, warm pick me up. 

Their almond milk latte fit the bill.. but would have been exceptional even on an average day. The espresso was actually flavorful unlike most coffee, and the perfectly foamed almond milk added a velvet creaminess. 

Well done, Blue Bottle. You raised the bar.
author: Samantha K.

description: Great service with pour over option! Yes it's open with view of barista at work! Nicely located to the ferry terminal
author: Tiffany H.

description: Great latte - seems like there are lines whenever they're open and now I know why.  Wonderful aromas, great service, superb coffee.
author: Ali C.

description:
The kindest staff, the best coffee. I can only dream of having blue bottle in Austin.

The smoothest iced coffee I've ever had. I dream of this stuff. Literally liquid gold hahah

Also, beautiful and simple marketing with the blue bottle logo and blue straw. Love it so much

Plus, the ferry building is just super cool to check out
author: Sarah S.

description: Excellent coffee and different from the dark roast coffee that I'm use it. We bought a bag to bring home to Chicago we still enjoying this coffee at home. I can't say a whole lot about the place since it was my husband who stood in a long line to order some Blue bottle coffee that is not actually in any type of blue bottle but it's cool still great cup of joe.
author: Jaci Y.

description: Awesome coffe! The best around in my opinion. That it's organic just adds to the greatness of this place. It is nicely done and staff is quick. The setting in the ferry building is great.
author: Jonas R.

description:
I saw someone with a Philz Coffee cup and asked where it was and someone told me to just go HERE!! Since it's in the Ferry building already. This place also gives validation if you need it. There are also 2 registers, one in the front where everyone goes and one on the side (less crowded imo). 

The worker that helped me was super nice and explained to me some little things, not rushing me even though the line was piling up. The menu is pretty self explanatory, so I ended up just getting an iced soy latte ($4.75) while my mom got hot coffee. Their coffee is pretty good, esp since I'm not TOO much of a coffee drinker but I thoroughly enjoyed my drink. The lines go by quickly from what I see, and it is a little pricer than I'm used to for the smaller portion but that's alright, the coffee was super good!
author: Jenny H.

description: Wow. Delicious mocha cappuccino. Was really hot chocolate mmmmmmmmm and everyone was so helpful. They helped me choose beans for my daughter. Just a wonderful stop. No seating. But there are benches outside.
author: Alex M.

description: Best coffee ever, and this place is a must when I come to the ferry building. This place always has a line, so I will go to their side window which always has a very short or no line and order their New Orleans coffee. It has the right amount of sweetness to it.
author: Monica K.

description:
Good helpful staff.  The lines are a little longer, but its worth the wait.  The business recognizes the wait times and created a second window to help shorten wait times.  

Coffee is amazing.  Love the single drip.
author: Prean P.

description:
I am a fan of Blue Bottle Coffee. I take a lot of people here when they visit San Francisco. There are a couple around the area but THIS place is the place to go to. It is located in to the middle of the Ferry Building. 

It is a place to meet up, walk around, and chill on a cup of coffee. They have special types of coffee that are pretty tasty. Try the New Orleans Iced Coffee. p good. 

Overall: Recommend to people visiting SF or if you are in the area.
author: Stephen C.

description: Two words: New Orleans. Best iced coffee in California! This place is worth the wait and the money. The coffee is never bitter and their menu, while simple, is all delicious. The New Orleans cold brew has a natural sweetness so that as someone who always needs some sort of sweetener in her coffee, I can attest that you don't need it! The decaf latte was also delicious and not bitter at all; nice and buttery! Probably one of the best lattes I've ever had and no sugar was needed!
author: Sarina J.

description:
I like coffee....this is excellent coffee! Not pungent-but strong...I had the cappuccino. It was such a perfect combination. I would have it again and again!  

I recommend going during the weekday to enjoy a short line!
author: Rula S.

description: Any time we're in SF, we always have to stop at Blue Bottle. This particular location is a favorite of ours because it's located right next to our favorite ice cream shop - Humphry Slocombe. The coffee here is incredible- so smooth, rich, and flavorful. My boyfriend ordered the affogato because it's the ultimate combination of his two favorite things: coffee and ice cream. What makes this even more special is the fact that they use Humphry Slocombe ice cream. The world has never seen a more delicious love child. The contrasting flavors, textures, and temperatures provided a much needed wake up call to our tastebuds. The sharp bitterness of the freshly pulled espresso shot was instantly tempered by the sweet floral vanilla ice cream. When fresh, the liquid espresso is best scooped up with a spoonful of solid ice cream, but after everything melts a bit, the slurry becomes the yummiest espresso drink ever. I'd get that stuff pumped into me via IV any day. It's definitely an indulgent treat, but totally worth it.
author: Angela L.

description:
Great coffee and also aesthetically bee-eautiful and this one is in the Ferry Building, so it's even nicer. Great for tourists, coffee snobs, and non coffee snobs alike. 

Grab a cup and walk around the little corners of this pretty building. It's the equivalent of Chelsea Market in New York.
author: Priti K.

description: So there's no sign at the storefront, but a drawing of a blue bottle and a lot of people in line will clue you in to this place. I tried their New Orleans ice coffee, which was AMAZING. Not too sweet, smooth and rich, it's an interesting blend of flavors. +$1 for almond milk substitute seems a little much, but if you go for regular milk, I think $4 for this drink is a good deal. Makes a great companion for ferry/people watching at the ferry terminal. One con is there is not too much seating at the store itself, but there is plenty of benches and places to sit elsewhere to enjoy your drink.
author: Momona Y.

description:
OMG - we were in the Ferry Building at the start of our morning, just spending a day in San Fran with our pup. I've always wanted to get coffee here but the line is just absolutely enormous! We were there early so only about 3-4 people ahead of me in line so it was perfect. I asked the cashier what he recommended from a drink perspective since it was my first time there and he didn't steer me wrong. I can't completely remember what I ordered but it was amazing - and they do the coffee "art work" on the top of your drink too. The barista that made my drink was super nice and friendly and I can't wait to go back!

As you would expect - SF and Ferry Building, coffee is expensive - we got 2 drinks and it was like $12, but for a treat - it's worth it :) We will be back!
author: Vivian P.

description: I love Blue Bottle coffee. This is a good location but they do not offer a full menu. They didn't have Siphon coffee or any food. If you are looking for coffee, this is a great place. If you're looking for food to go with your coffee, there are many places to go in the ferry building.
author: Dave G.

description:
All the rumors are true. The geniuses at Blue Bottle really have designed a superior coffee experience. I tried an Ethiopian as well as a New Orleans, and on both counts was fully impressed.

I love Ethiopian coffee, and the variety served here, Yirgacheffe, is one I have had on numerous other occasions, a favorite. However Blue Bottle made the wonderful beans sing like never before - clear, true taste, very smooth. 

The New Orleans was as advertised and reminded me of my days living on the Gulf Coast and savoring Chicory coffees in Biloxi and New Orleans. A nice balanced iced coffee.

Bottom line - these cats have the reputation and hype, but in this case I would say it is all on the mark.
author: Robert H.

description: I don't review places but as my first review, this place needs to be called out on. Blue bottle does NOT list the prices on any of their items and that's just wrong because you don't know what your getting yourself into until you meet the cashier. And I went DEEP. They charged me $10.40 for a cup of coffee.  If I paid $5 or $6 I would've been ok with it since it's a tourist trap area. But $10 for a f***ken cup of coffee is just down right pretentious and snobby. And I don't know how they are getting away with this.  They gave me a card saying this is extremely rare coffee, but it just taste like a watered down version of Starbucks regular coffee right across the street. I would Avoid this place unless you want to pay double or even triple.
author: Joey T.

description: The atmosphere of this location is lovely! I think I have to review the taste of their famous coffee. It taste good! That's that!
author: Ploi S.

description: Very bad coffee, was adulterated. The kid could not even take a proper order from me. Terrible.
author: Peace P.

description: Great for a latte and a waffle! Try their waffle while you buy one of the best lattes around! I loved my San Francisco breakfast treat!
author: A T.

description: Such a high quality coffee spot! Everything tastes so good! The staff is always friendly and nice. I strongly recommend affogato, brown butter ice cream with a shot of nice fresh hot espresso poured over. It's $5.75 it's a bit pricey but definitely worth it!
author: Selen A.

description:
Yes, this was probably the one of the most delicious tiny cups of coffee I've had in my lifetime. I didn't really think I was a coffee snob, but I'm finding that the iced coffee I've been drinking faithfully from Starbucks doesn't even come close to places like this. I was a little upset that I couldn't get more because the cups are so small. Should I have ordered two? For myself?? Haha

While the ferry building is always busy throughout the day, there is no way to anticipate when the lines will be short. While I was standing in line for ice cream across the walkway, I saw the line go from about 10 people deep to 2. Good luck :)

Blue bottle, like many of the other establishments along the inside of the ferry building, don't have seating, but there are several options outside, complete with great views of the bay! 

I saw several people talking selfies with their coffee and the very cute and iconic sign. DO IT! No shame!!
author: Krysten I.

description: I ordered the New Orleans cold brew. It was pricy but had a nice flavor. The cups and straws were cute and added a nice touch.
author: Courtney L.

description:
Coffee is my jam, so I was eager to try the famed Blue Bottle Coffee and grabbed three bags of Ethiopian roast to-go. My tl:dr verdict: Delicious.

These craft roasted bags are as flavorful and delicate as you could hope for. It's not always the case that taking a bag to go will taste as good as when you order in the shop, but it definitely was. 

I don't know what more to say other than it's an enjoyable roast of coffee, albeit a tad on the pricier side. Will definitely come back next time I'm in San Fran!
author: Adam S.

description: Price is cheap for the coffee quality. I requested an americano which is off the menu. Turnaround is quick and it seems like people prefer this over other coffee places here.
author: Marco S.

description: Got the New Orleans Ice coffee. It was good but nothing special. Not worth $5-$6 for a small coffee.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Love Blue Bottle...servers are nice, place is always clean, inviting and modern atmosphere. The iced coffees are great but the Affogato...YUM! Ice-cream PLUS espresso! Can't ask for anything more...except...open a shop in Orange County!
author: Miss D.

description:
Gee, now that I've been to the new, classically stylish Blue Bottle at 115 Sansome (review: http://bit.ly/1dw7iGi), it's a bit difficult to appreciate the smaller outposts like this one at the Ferry Building. This location is also burdened by the overbearing foot traffic of both tourists and commuters, which of course is compounded by the long queues that form for family-friendly Humphry Slocombe Ice Cream right across the hallway. If you get past the churning crowds generated by these two complementary businesses on a Saturday afternoon, then you are a more dexterous man than I am. Probably skinnier, too.

And yet for all these barriers, it's still worthwhile to get a $4.25 Caffe Latte here (photo: http://bit.ly/1GLILVd).It's the smoothest brew you can get on this side of the Embarcadero (sorry Peet's), and they gratefully renovated and expanded the space to accommodate the burgeoning caffeine addicts. No longer are you relegated to the side order window, and the line feels like it goes marginally faster as a result. Listen, Blue Bottle is worthwhile in almost any setting, and that includes the stand on Linden Alley in Hayes Valley where I had my very first one. So if you're hankering for a fix at the Ferry Building, just make you don't order it five minutes before your ferry departure.

COFFEE - 4.5 stars...still a smooth latte that is not easily duplicated elsewhere
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...more spacious now but still crazed at the Ferry Building
SERVICE - 4 stars...nicer baristas than you would expect
TOTAL - 4 stars...when Blue Bottle calls, you must answer
author: Ed U.

description:
I know so many people that rave about Blue Bottle Coffee, but I just don't understand the hype for this place. I've tried this place twice, the first time ordering a hot mocha, which I didn't quite like and the second time, ordering what I heard some people rave about...the New Orleans Iced Coffee. The New Orleans Iced Coffee includes milk, cane sugar, and roasted chicory. It's was not bad, but I didn't think it was amazing or anything. I'll admit, it wasn't too sweet or too bitter and had just enough milk, which I did like. I guess the best part is that it's all organic. 

This place always has a line and the prices are not cheap (for coffee). The hot mocha is now $5, the New Orleans Iced Coffee is $4.00, and the Cafe Latte is $4.25. There is only one size, which is not medium or large. Everything is to-go as there is no seating for the store. For me, the customer service was average as the worker that took my order and made my drink was not friendly or rude. Would I come back here? I probably would if I'm in the area just because I like coffee, but I definitely wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
author: Jean S.

description: I did not like the guy who took my order as he got my order wrong first of all and did not put that I wanted a milk substitute, so the baristas remade my drink. If he wasn't talking so to a coworker I would have been able to catch the mistake on time, however on that note, his recommendation on the drink i ordered was hands down a great drink. Work on the service a little more taking orders, and I'd give 5 stars
author: Mandy S.

description:
Terrible. Waited 30 mins while the cashier taking orders from the single person in front of me chatted away. The guy ordered 8 lattes, which is fine, but the artisan coffee maker seemed overwhelmed by the order and actually went on a break before "tackling the order". When he came back he seemed to have to psyche himself up to the mammoth task ahead of him muttering "I guess we're doing this. All eight". After the entire order was done and the conversation wrapped up, the cashier turned attention to me and asked for my order. When I received a small brown smudge in a cup I mentioned I had asked for a double espresso and was told "that is exactly 20mls of ristretto, which is a double espresso". I can't eyeball 20 mls, but it was hardly enough to make the cup moist...  over hyped, overrated, rude. 

Don't know why I keep going back... it never changes.
author: Justin T.

description:
Excellent fresh coffee in the heart of san fran.

The latte presentation was in standard coffee house excellence and while it was busy, I was surprised at how quickly we went through.

The waffle is fresh baked and possibly the best thing in the building. So good, the right balance of sweet and delicious!
author: Peter H.

description: I'm not a big coffee drinker but  when I do drink it, it's usually  recommended by a friend. I'm glad I listened and checked out this place! I ordered the caffe mocha and it was so good! It was made just right. Not too sweet and not too bitter. Definitely one of my favorite coffee places coming from a person who rarely drinks coffee!  I also tried their Leige waffle and it was so delicious! After trying so many kinds and types of waffles from all over the places, this one is definitely one of the best!
author: Ingrid H.

description:
The service here is pretty good. There is a really long line, so be prepared to wait. I tried the drip and the caffè mocha. I don't consider myself a coffee person, but the coffee was smooth and cool as a cucumber. Another plus was the way they put the cream on. They put a cool flower design on my caffè mocha.
As someone who does not drink coffee very much, while this coffee was very smooth, I did not like it.
Overall, I would highly recommend this place for coffee lovers, but be prepared to wait 10-15 minutes.
author: Derek N.

description:
The blue bottle coffee here is the same amazing blue bottle coffee you get everywhere else in this city. However, every time I have gone it has an extremely long slightly disorganized line. 

The coffee is good as always but I do find blue bottle to be a bit expensive. I would usually rate it a 4-5 star place but this particular location is very busy and its worth walking to another one.
author: Neil P.

description:
Blue Bottle inside of the ferry terminal? Count me in.

I am a BIG fan of Blue Bottle. I would do anything for their New Orleans ICE Coffee. Came here by while I was waiting to eat at Hogs and it totally made my day. Staff is quick and efficient.
author: Danny L.

description: Expect long lines, but it's totally worth it! They make waffles in-house, and they have perfected the art of making the most exquisite macchiato known to man. Even the coffee is super premium. They don't budge on the quality of the bean. Once you give this place a try, you'll despise Starbucks. I'm ruined for life! :)
author: Sara M.

description:
When I come to visit SF, as a coffee lover, Blue bottle and Philz coffee springs to mind.

This place has a great tourist allure and rightly so. Lines are always there when we visit during the afternoons but come before 9:30am and you might get in right away.

Love the *New Orleans* iced coffee, it's much more than just any iced coffee, strong and creamy, no additions needed for this lone survivor.

As a hot alternative, the cafe latte is surprisingly similar to New Orleans drink. I must say drinking these does make things move in my tummy, if ya get my meaning! Definitely a strong-ass coffee 

They put their hearts in those coffees and if I lived in San Fran, I would come here all the time!!
author: Mallika G.

description:
This is considered by many to be the best coffee available anywhere,especially in San Francisco.

The founder of the company has a strong focus on quality coffee and it really shows in the product. There's a couple of dedicated blue bottle locations and some other retail places/cafes that'll serve it but this review is for the main location inside the ferry building(not the walk up outside facing Embarcadero.

Parking is typical for SF which means that you'll be coming here by some way which does not involve driving. The good news here is that the ferry building is kind of a hub for non car transportation options. There's literally a dozen ways to get here that do not involve driving. 

The coffee products here are splendid perfection. The drip coffee is magnificent, and the espresso is the best I've had in America. Ditto for the latte's. The pastries are also extraordinarily tasty. To summarize pretty much anything you order here will be awesome.

Now for the slightly negative news. There is always a line here. It's not always very organized. Upon occasion people who really should know better will just run up and grab whatever coffee is yelled out regardless of what they ordered. That's happened twice to me, and I regret to say I was less then gracious when it occurred the second time. the staff are really awesome, and another coffee was made w/o issue from the staff both for me, and the other guy who came back to complain that he didn't order a latte. Typically the line in front is for people who are not in a hurry, want a pastry/food option, or don't really know what they want.

There is another way to get coffee in a flash and bypass that line however. Around the corner-the one on the way to the ocean facing exit and bathrooms-there is a little walk up window for basic orders.This is not to be confused with the walk up in another part of the building, this one is attached to the main cafe. Perfect for an espresso to go, or a coffee and a danish. This window has much much less of a line, and serves the same coffee. There is no menu board so you need to know what you want. Serving time tends to be quicker as well, but if you need to take the selfie to prove you were here do it with the main front in the background as the walk up counter is not as an attractive setting.

Not the most cost effective option as just coffee and a sweet can run close to ten bucks, depending on what you order, but the quality is much better then average.
author: Steven W.

description:
I've heard so many great things about Blue Bottle Coffee Co. I feel like when I'm in SF, there's always this debate over which is better, Philz coffee or Blue Bottle. Well, since I finally tried both places, I can give you an honest answer. I LIKE BOTH! The thing is that both places are so different. From Philz, I always enjoyed an iced drink and at Blue Bottle I tried out the latte. 

The latte here was pretty damn good. I've worked as a barista before elsewhere and I was never the biggest fan of a normal latte, but they sure know how to make a delicious one here. The foam was perfect and you can still taste all of the espresso even with the steamed milk taking over the cup. 

Overall, I really enjoyed the latte at Blue Bottle Coffee Co. A definite must if you want a hot cup of coffee in the chilly SF weather.
author: Ryan W.

description:
I finally got my hands on a cup of New Orleans and oh man, oh man, it was pretty good. I added extra sugar at the bar and had a cool texture voyage as I would get a hit of the coffee from the straw followed by some cane sugar granules that I was happily chewing on. 

I really liked tasting all the richness in the cold brew, chicory and milk and the weird gentle chewing party after. I dont know! I am a weirdo! You should try it! But, you probably did already!
author: Niana D.

description:
I have always seen the lines in the Ferry Building but it took me almost a year to try out Blue Bottle Coffee today. Well, now I see what the craze is all about. Their coffees are indeed a piece of art, every cup! 

I ordered a latte and was really impressed the way the Barista took time to create the masterpiece. I really liked the flavor. And also, not to forget about the latte art.
