author: Carlo D.

description: Exceptional coffee. And they know how to make Flat Whites. Yay. Staff are very knowledgeable, effortlessly polite, and hip. But not annoyingly so.
author: Noelle M.

description: They're using what is supposedly a higher quality almond milk -- without all the stabilizers and additives found in most commercial almond milks -- but it should NOT be used for espresso drinks. Although it had a lovely almond taste, the almond milk was entirely too watery and completely destroyed the cappuccino it was used in. It is also unfortunate that Blue Bottle charges $1 extra for non-dairy substitutions.
author: Patricia D.

description:
Oh my goodness, this place.  
Their service is always friendly and fast and the coffee is to die for.  I would recommend it to anyone and always make a point to bring people that are visiting the city here.  

The New Orleans iced coffee is my favorite and I would drink it forever if I could.
author: Laura D.

description:
I never tried this place before but read reviews that the New Orleans and drip coffee were both number one choices for other customers.  Both were delicious and very affordable.

The wait wasn't too bad as I went on a Friday around 10am. There weren't any long lines and only took about 5 minutes max for the drip coffee to be ready. I will definitely come here again.
author: Cassandra S.

description:
Best Iced Coffee in the city, hands down.

Was that statement offensive?  I don't care because it is the truth.

The sweet cane, chicory, maddening kick of overpriced caffeine is my favorite thing to order.  The drip is great as well.

Staff is always quick and friendly so they make the line not much of an issue.  

The wait that people mention must be on the weekend.  During the week its never more than 10-15 people in cue and it moves.
author: Andrew T.

description:
We all know the coffee is amazing. However, here's my little secret.

Get the affrogato. They occasionally change the type of ice cream they carry from Humphry Slocombe. This past weekend it was brown butter.

It always pairs amazingly with the espresso.

Now to step it up, get the waffle (which they finally have again). 

Waffle + affrogato = amazingness. 

Try it, you'll LOVE it.
author: Mendel L.

description: This update is purely for their food, as I'm still leery of their service.  I get that the coffee is amazing (I've come to find that I enjoy their lattes more than anything else) but has anyone had the WAFFLE they serve??  I mean this, the waffle they serve here is hands down INCREDIBLE.  Dipped in maple syrup with some sugar crystals dotted around the waffle, this is hands down one of the best finds.  I can't believe it! It goes magically with the coffee, and on a cold day, having a waffle with your coffee kinda brings some great comfort and happiness to the morning.  Please do yourself a favor and get the waffle here, you won't be disappointed!
author: Lisa I.

description: Had to come try the famous blue bottle coffee... Be prepared to wait in a long line unless you go really early. I ordered a latte w/ almond milk and a waffle. The latte was good and the waffle was AMAZING! Came out super hot and was so tasty! All the pastries looked so good I was tempted to order one of everything!
author: Lauren M.

description:
Love that this Blue Bottle Coffee is near my work so whenever I do want something more than just a Starbucks, it's an easy walk away. (Located within the ferry building across from Humphreys).

I usually order the New Orleans because honestly, you can't go wrong with this iced coffee! Also, the workers there are pretty friendly. I loved my server the last time I was there because he was super nice and even gave us recommendations with what sort of milk tastes better, etc. 

With about a little over a handful of people in line ahead of us I would say.. We waited about 20 ish mins? Which is usually longer than what you would be waiting at Starbucks or Peets but LBR, the coffee is much better here.
author: Krystal O.

description:
When I first moved to SF, I thought Blue Bottle was fantastic. But then I discovered Ritual and Philz and quickly realized that there are better options. However, Blue Bottle is still very good and their New Orleans Iced Coffee remains one of my favorite beverages.

The biggest problem with this location is the wait. The Ferry Building is always a mess, but the line at Blue Bottle is especially long. If you don't mind waiting, stick it out. If you do, try Peet's or Frog Hollow instead. They're both nearby and serve decent cups.
author: Nick K.

description: From Washington and I totally make blue bottle a stop!  The iced New Orleans coffee is to die for!! Line was long but totally worth the wait!
author: Ashlee F.

description: Come on a rainy day and you won't have to worry about those insane lines! I finally got to try blue bottle after the third try. I ordered the New Orleans iced with soy. I loved it and didn't even need to put sugar in it. The baristas are super friendly and I definitely could compare this with Monmouth in the UK. (Monmouth has more options though ;))
author: Hannah C.

description: This is my new favorite coffee joint in SF.  I wish they had these everywhere!  They have a few items on the menu and I got the cafe latte, which was delciious.  The best part about this coffee shop is that they make awesome designs in the foam, which puts a smile on my face everytime.  This place is crowded, but well worth it for an extremely smooth cup of coffee!
author: Jenn T.

description: Long line but one of the best lattes or iced coffee you can get. Drip is good as well. Obviously I'll brave the line. There's too spaces one inside the ferry building and one of stands in front. Just treat yourself and wait in line its worth it if you have time to spare.
author: Eleanor B.

description:
Blue bottle gets an extra star for offering almond milk, but really this is a 3 star review. I really enjoyed my iced coffee, but I would not make this a daily stop. $5 for 16oz, including ice is not in the budget. I might try some of their concentrate, though. 
I love coffee and I went to say I'd been, but I can't say I understand the hype.
author: Shakila M.

description: Delicious coffee - especially the cold brewed New Orleans Iced Coffee.  Though, I wish they didn't pre-mix the sweetener - it's often a bit too sweet for my taste.  It's great coffee, but not sure it's worth the often 15-25 minute line.
author: Greg B.

description:
Oops I did it again. I managed to have blue bottle coffee two days in a row. Instead of the drip coffee I ordered a cappuccino, which by no fault of blue bottle, was SO milky. And so creamy. Which is probably a great thing for most, but for me, I'm used to soy milk, lite version.

Service, I must say, was much better than what I found on Linden St. The lady in thick rimmed glasses smiled, and the busy barista had a happy-go-lucky bounce in his step when making my espresso. Now if I were truly generous with my money, I'd give more of it to blue bottle for the grass braided bag they were selling - rugged and cool.
author: Cici T.

description:
I'd give it a 4.5 but rounded up since I had such a nice day in The City today. 

Their hand dripped coffee was da bomb. The fragrance of the roasted and grounded coffee was just too delightful. 

Every type of coffee on the menu was just too good to be true. Not the best in the world but pretty close to it. Also the price wasn't ridiculously high for such a renowned shop.
author: Dan K.

description: I ordered a hot chocolate it was delicious super decadent. The line was long but moves quickly
author: Amanda C.

description: This coffee was good.  Not life-changing.  I should have reached in the tip jar to grab my dollar back after the person who rung us up forgot to give us our pastries.
author: Ryan R.

description:
I've been avoiding Blue Bottle like the plague. 

The weekend crowds and the lunch workers during weekdays make me want to run the other direction.  By chance after the lunch rush on a weekday, I finally made my way over at this place.

I wish I'd done it sooner. The Gibraltar is divine, that's probably why it's #28 on the Big Eats SF list. It's served in a shot glass with a pretty decorated heart on my foam. If a latte and a cappuccino would have a baby, the gibraltar would be the result: it's like an espresso topped off with milk but not a huge amount of foam. It's delicious, a must for caffeine lovers and I liked the smooth taste even without adding sugar or half and half.

Blue Bottle, I can see why you a have a lot of loyal fans. I promise not to stay away anymore.
author: Janice C.

description:
if you are a coffee connoisseur, you must try Blue Bottle Coffee. Straight coffee, simple and with a little design for you. I usually get the latte and it is aromatic and strong. 

They have also opened a location in the south bay (YAY!!!!) and have various locations throughout SF and the East Bay. Must try if you are in the ferry building.
author: Stacy H.

description: I really loved Blue Bottle and I'm bummed that I can't get it in Chicago. My friends who lived in SF are obsessed with it - one of them even dressed up as a Blue Bottle cold brew carton for Halloween! Thus, that was the coffee that I tried: the New Orleans style cold brew. It was amazing. Spicy, sweet (a little too sweet, but that can be fixed by diluting the coffee a little), refreshing, and super tasty. Not only that, it was also just a fun thing to drink in the first place - the chicory flavor made it fun and interesting. The service was also great - the cashier was super friendly and made nice conversation with me. Looking forward to the next time I'm in SF and can drink some more of this coffee :).
author: Riva L.

description:
Yeap! Only one sad star for this coffee place .....why? very very simple ....
1. Lets be honest here, their coffee is really meh ! I was expecting to be blowned away with flavor ...yeah it didn't happened...bummer!! FYI ...be ready to pay an extra $1 for almond milk (?)...
2. They only have one size drinks ...if you are going to order a cold drink you will end paying over $5 for a cup fillee with ice and a little bit of coffee and a lot of milk ...dissapointing!!
3. Long lines = long waiting time to get coffee.

Sorry, I am not trying to be negative guys but money doesn't grow on trees ...if I am going to spend over $5 on a cup of Joe it better be the best of the best!!!!!
This place just didn't do it for me ....
author: MB B.

description:
Got the New Orleans Iced Coffee a few days ago and the power of this coffee is amazing. I was literally striding with determination from building to building throughout the entire day! Blue Bottle specializes in drip coffee so I expected something a little stronger than my typical Peet's House or French Roast. 

The coffee wasn't too sweet which is perfect bc often times, cafes will overdo it on the sugar (Starbucks) which totally ruins the taste of the beans. However, the coffee was heavy on the milk side so I felt like I was drinking a melted milk shake at times bc of the thick consistency. 

Make sure to delegate some extra time if you want Blue Bottle as the wait is about 15 - 20 minutes on a good day. It's in the Ferry Building so you'll see a lot of tourists, Ferry Commuters, and other commuters making their daily Blue Bottle stop so expect a line. Just FYI!
author: Jo L.

description:
I've always gotten drip coffee, which was my first time (a while back) seeing coffee brewed that way. Kudos on teaching me a superior and relatively simple method of getting a tasty cup at home.

I've had amazing brews and ones that were a little burnt tasting (I've drunk worse) because I've not mastered the ordering system and they are not "user friendly" -- there's no guide and they don't inquire or try to educate you.

But.

I can live with all that, I don't even mind snobby barristers, or long lines because I'm patient and don't care to chat anyway (plus you can't live in SF and get annoyed by that stuff or your head would explode). No, what ticks me off is the neatly packaged bags of beans with NO PRICE. 

Really? Why? Do you make more sales by potentially shaming people at the reg? 

I have the money, I just resent that nonsense so much that I'm not buying anything.

Forget it.

That's a huge lack of sympathy and class for a place whose coffee labels prattle on about sustainability in struggling communities around the globe.
author: Ziggy J.

description:
Good iced coffee on the go.  My first time at Blue Bottle lived up to expectations - quality taste, but slightly less quantity than I'd like without the ice cubes.  Well, they have to pay the rent somehow.  I don't think I'll try their chicory because I hate chicory (which seems to be what they are known for), but I'll come back for a hot coffee and a pastry.  Decent, and I'll return at some point.

The area where you get straws and lids gets a little crowded, probably all the time.
author: Ben K.

description: Cuuuuute! Way cuter than the NYC Rockefeller shop, which is too small to be cute. My macchiato was perfection and liquid love. I enjoyed my first few sips until I broke the creamy heart, and then sneakily added more milk and a packet of sweetener at the condiment bar - also delish!  We are huge fans of Blue Bottle and receive the bean delivery every 2 weeks. I have to say that somehow getting a cup at the shop is better than our Aeropress at home.  Put the pep in my step to walk over to Chinatown for breakfast!  Will visit again if I am in the area.
author: Siu L.

description: Very very impressed with the coffee here. I hate American coffee, but this was the bombdiggity! Perfectly steamed milk, light creamy. Excellent coffee too, perfectly complimented by a waffle. You really must try the waffles!
author: Timothy H.

description:
I had an hour to kill on a recent SF trip, and a friend recommended Blue Bottle for a quick coffee.  I couldn't bring myself to go to Starbucks and was happy I didn't.  Around lunchtime, the line gets long, but it's worth the wait and moves pretty fast.  I like how they only make your drink when you're up there - makes you feel like they are giving you special attention.  

I had a mocha, and while it was $4, it was great!  Great rich flavor and served at just the right temp.  And how can you go wrong with the design they leave you with on the top of your drink.  Little one-off specialty coffee shops like this make me miss SF.
author: Joe U.

description:
I truly hate the hipster snooty coffee scene, and yet here I was eagerly standing in line awaiting my coffee. SUCKER! I ordered a iced mocha and a scowling barista told me they didn't make iced mochas. Ok- thanks attitude- I guess I'll have the iced coffee. I was aghast when she added whole milk to my iced coffee. I haven't had whole milk since I was 12. One sip and I was sold.. It was awesome!!! I'll take all the attitude in the world to drink this daily.

My husband doesn't buy into any of this elitist coffee BS. He took one sip of his hand poured black coffee, and stated it tasted like Starbucks. My god, we could have been killed by irate hipsters if they overhead him. Thankfully we managed to escape unscathed. I happily washed down a delicious Snickerdoodle cookie (tasted like saffron rather than cinnamon- it was awesome) with my amazing iced coffee.. Yum- I will be back.
author: Ritu K.

description:
This has just become my fav coffee place when in the city. Their drip coffee is individually made and is STRONG and is exactly how I like it. They use only clover organic milk for their coffee. When here you have to try New Orleans Iced Coffee. It's the BEST iced coffee ever said my husband and he is not even that big a coffee person. We liked it so much so that we went there for a second round just before the store closed up. Amazing as it is, there are a few drawbacks to this place- one that the queue is mostly long and wait time could vary from 5 - 20 minutes, and second that it is expensive. New Orleans iced coffee is $3.75 a cup and it's not even large sized. And drip costs $3.5 which is high by coffee standards. But my other fav coffee place in Bay Area- philz charges almost similarly and is an individually prepared coffee place too so I guess I should not complain.
Okay enough said. This coffee place is AWESOME!
author: Finla P.

description: Great coffee, addictive! Do something about the long lines... Hate the wait. Staff is friendly and attentive.
author: Anisha Y.

description: Love the latte
author: Marina M.

description: Coffee was  really sour. The barista did not know how to brew coffee. Hopefully I have a better cup next time.
author: Bryan C.

description:
Meh...maybe a tad bit overrated. 

If you live in San Francisco you have obviously heard of Blue Bottle Coffee...and it is more than likely that you have tried it at least once at one of the many locations in San Francisco. Like I have said before I am no coffee expert but I can tell the difference between good and bad coffee. I am also very familiar and conscious of the flavors that touch my palette. When I saw that they had Iced New Orleans coffee I knew I had to try it. I have been to New Orleans many times and I absolutely love the sweet iced coffee there. When I finally coffee I noticed that it lacked any special flavor at all whatsoever and that I waited in that long line for no reason. In the end I was disappointed in my small cup of expensive bland coffee. All well you never know until you try right?
author: Jacqueline C.

description: Blue Bottle is probably the best coffee you can get in SF, their menu includes the basics: Americano, Macchiato, Mocha, Latte, and House Coffees. I've tried all of them, but my usual is either the mocha or the latte because I love milk and chocolate and there is always a beautiful drip design to top it off! Coffee beans come in half pound bags, they're a bit pricey ~$9.50, but definitely worth it.
author: Elaine N.

description:
I tried waiting in line for this and never succeeded until now. Last time I was in SF, I wanted to come here but it was too out of our way, so we never made it here. This trip, I was in the ferry building on Friday and tried standing in line again, but gave up after it didn't budge. Finally, I came again the following day, absolutely resolute that I would make it through and be able to try this mythical drink.

I split a decaf soy mocha and a Belgian waffle with the bf. Both were delicious on one hand but lacking something that would make it absolutely phenomenal and 5 star worthy. The soy mocha was delicious on the first taste, but soon grew too sweet for me and I could barely finish the drink. The waffle had the perfect texture and sweetness, but lacked caramelized pearl sugar that would make these waffles truly authentic. Overall however, both were still delicious and I would say worth the 20 minute wait, although I'm glad that I had someone to split with.
author: Helen S.

description:
Oh blue bottle...I love you so much!  I love this location cause it's just a coffee stand.  Order your coffee and move on with your day. 
I love the soy latte here!  The coffee bean is strong and has a hint of sweetness. The staff is extremely friendly and super fast cranking out those coffee.  Definitely will try the waffle next time.  Heard great things about it:)
author: Ying F.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee definitely a good stop if you are visiting San Francisco.

This particular location had a much shorter line than the one on Mint.  I think because of limited pastries available and coffee is served in a paper cup.  So what... The Cafe Mocha was rich and delicious - just as good as the one on Mint in a real coffee cup.  

Just order Cafe Mocha and a waffle and you're good to go.
author: Foodking Y.

description:
Drip coffee, black (what else would I order?)

This was my first time trying Blue Bottle.  Not bad, not bad at all.  I wanted this to be as "blind" as possible.  I didn't ask about the origin of the bean, or anything else.  I simply wanted to taste what they had to offer to see what the hoopla was all about.  So I simply ordered whatever they were offering - standard drip coffee of the day.  It came out as a medium roast with a decent body and minimal/slight acidity.  Not sour, not bitter.

Mind you, this was only one sampling of the multiple beans/blends/roasts that they have.

I am more than willing to come back to try their other beans and roasts, since what I had was pretty decent.
author: Herman E.

description: Hipster central.  The baristas take themselves WAY too seriously.  But the coffee is really good.  I had a cappuccino and it was rich and frothy for $3.75 (I think). Its pricey and the line is always long, but if you're here, try it, you will be a happy, hyper camper.
author: Lisette C.

description: I'm giving this place 5 stars because I'm comparing it to what we have in DC.  I always spend 40-50 bucks on bags of coffee here so I can bring it back home to the East coast.  The new orleans iced coffee is really good.
author: Tim K.

description:
A new transplant to San Fran pointed me to the Blue Bottle as the people who know how to roast/brew to perfection. Can't say I am a coffee connoisseur but am always interested in the 'best'. 

The location is very convenient. The staff were quiet efficient and nice. I choose a pour over of one of the special blends.  The vale for this small cup of coffee was a hard item to swallow- no pun intended.  But, it was a beautiful cup of brew. So glad I tried it and now that I have read that Starbucks bought them I might even find one in my city soon.
author: Karen G.

description: Great mocha, good location. Nice place to spend the morning - and the orange cake was good too!
author: Chetan S.

description: We came across this cute little place while walking through the market in San Fransisco. The employees were very nice and helpful. There was a line but went by quick once you ordered your coffee. My husband got the mocha it was good I think they put dark chocolate instead which was perfect and then I got double espresso with a tad of milk which I lovvvved!
author: Cindy H.

description: This is the coffee place to go when you're at the ferry building. There are two separate lines so the wait is not long at all on a crowded Saturday. I really enjoy their latte here. The drip coffee taste so good and it doesn't require cream and sugar because I need it at other coffee places. The News Orleans Iced cold brew taste great as well and they already mix in cream and cane sugar for you already. That's for those lazy days some of us have ;)
author: Nancy N.

description:
I like my coffee how I like my men, sent back for not being hot enough--zing!
Jk
I like the coffee here. It is strong, however, with the right amount of cream and raw sugar, it is a blessing. Smooth and rich. 
The waffles are wonderful and buttery. They've rocked my socks every time.

HOOOOWWWWWEVERRRRRRR, today was Sunday, a slow day for the ferry building. Why did it take so long? The cashier would ignore the customers to slowly do a pour over. So annoying. He was in a total daze the whole time he was helping us too. It was kinda creepy.
author: Natalie C.

description:
What can I say...their espresso is awesome, especially the mocha with the TCHO chocolate.

You can also get an assortment of beans from this place as well.
author: Alice C.

description:
Since frequenting here back when I was still living in San Francisco, I now buy all my coffee online from bluebottlecoffee.com since the closest place I can purchase blue bottle's brand of legal crack is about 1000 miles away in NYC. 

I also now hand drip all my coffee in my little hario nel drip (also sold in blue bottle stores) into an overpriced mug that I bought from Heath Ceramics right next to the other Blue Bottle Store in the Mission.

If this review hasn't done anything else for you, try their NOLA Iced Coffee. It will change the way you think about coffee. Forever.
author: Scott S.

description:
Among the best coffee joints in San Francisco in a great location...The Ferry Building!  Sometimes things are overhyped, but Blue Bottle is not one of them.

The single drip coffee is delicious, and definitely pair it with a waffle (which has earned this place the 5th star).  First of all, it already looks tantalizing with that golden brown exterior, and it tastes just as good as it looks.  

Now picture yourself with a Blue Bottle coffee in hand with it's trademark brown cup, a waffle, strolling along the Embarcadero while looking at the Bay Bridge.  SF experience...made.


Also they have coffee-making merchandise while you wait!  The line goes fast :)
author: Patrick L.

description:
I'm not a big coffee drinker, but I appreciate good coffee. I popped in to Blue Bottle late in the day (I'm not sitting in that line for anything.. ever..) and picked up a macchiato.

Whatever they do to their coffee, I approve. It was the smoothest and most complex flavor I've yet to experience.

Should I ever give in and go full cold brew, I'll be ordering some Blue Bottle to enjoy. In the meantime, I'll just have to look forward to my next trip to SF and/or NYC!
author: Benjamín S.

description: I am pretty sure they served me a shrunken waffle, or they have deliberately changed the sizes.  So, I confronted one of the baristas, he sarcastically commented: "that looks like a big pastry to me."  C'mon, I am a regular at BBC and have had my shares of waffles... I know how to tell if something was off. I am very disappointed. So I watched and compared the other waffles that were served after my teeny waffle and was sure they screwed me over.  I will still come back and get their coffee.  But will not get the waffles.  By the way, to that barista with sarcastic comment... Not the way to treat your customer.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
All of you will hate me for doing this but Blue Bottle Coffee is totally overrated.  

I have stood in this line twice now and both times I've only been slightly amused and never delighted.  

Although now that i think of it my choice may just be wrong...my friend ordered the gelato covered in expresso and that was pretty darn amazing...in fact I am STILL thinking about it.

The service is lame as it comes, there are like 2 people working, 1 register (the cashier is almost always rude and pretentious).  I should have gotten the last guy's name...he kind of upset me.
author: Rimi K.

description: Great cup of coffee down by the scenic boardwalk. If you don't mind the crowd and long lines, it's a nice stop on your San Fran visit.
author: Jesse S.

description:
Sure there is a bit of a wait here but the coffee is pretty good.  I had their mocha and enjoyed it, especially since it isn't too sweet.  

Now what I really love from Blue Bottle is their affogato, which consists of two scoops of Humphrey Slocombe's Honey Ice Cream topped with a shot of espresso. Can we say heavenly!? I wouldn't mind starting my morning with BB's affogato all the time. This is definitely a great choice for both coffee addicts and non-coffee lovers.

I also love smelling their Three Africans coffee beans. I thought those made nice souvenirs aside from the usual Ghirardelli Chocolates.
author: Samantha G.

description:
Sadly, I have to drop down BB one star as I've been several times over the last year and the shots have been consistently sour. Not sure if underextraction or something else is the cause but it is quite noticeable to me.

Also, unlike most 3rd Wave shops, they don't offer a Gibraltar/Cortado as a to-go option. Not really a big deal, just weird (this did not factor into the rating update)

I can't say I'm surprised as they have been expanding their reach and brand at a rapid pace, and usually when that happens the quality suffers, no matter what the product is. Everybody knows Blue Bottle so their marketing is working for sure. Then again, Bose is probably the best known manufacturer of speakers - but they're not very good unfortunately.

I'd still recommend BB (especially their divine waffle), but I can't say that they're at the top of the leaderboard. Thankfully, there are more and more contenders for the throne!
author: Bernard F.

description:
After a great early morning meeting with my mentors about my new project, my friends and I decided to head over to the ferry building to get some of what a local buddy considers to be some of the city's best coffee.  Having a coffee connoisseur on the team, I wanted to see how it stacked up against the rest so we dropped into the busy shop for a morning pick-me-up.

I went with a latte, a drink I don't think I've ever ordered before.  According to my friend, it was actually pretty good and had a bit of extra sweetness on the back of my tongue.  My friend really enjoyed her coffee so I guess it must have been pretty good stuff.

My palette doesn't know the difference between the good and bad stuff so I'm a poor judge of quality here.  As far as I'm concerned it tasted like a latte and I couldn't really tell a quality difference.  However, the stand is located in the Ferry Building and that's one of my favorite spots in the city and that's good enough for me to pass it.  If I worked in the area, I would drop by everyday and look forward to coming back for another cup soon!

Food: 7/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 9/10
author: Joe M.

description:
My goto coffee shop whenever I'm in the bay area. I love visiting the Ferry Building on Saturdays so I head over to blue Bottle Coffee first to start my day. The line's always long. There's a "secret window" off to the side but that line gets long, too. 

My goto drinks are the drip coffee, the New Orleans iced coffee, and the Cafe au Lait. ugh, they're all so freakin good. It's so hard to decided which one I want. You can really taste the quality of those beans. so freakin good. 

Worth the wait!
author: Rose C.

description:
inside the ferry building with a lot of other great places..

i knew i had to try this great coffee when I got to s.f. from friends recommendations and yelp reviews

I got the iced new orleans w soy milk

coffee usually doesnt affect me but this def made me a lil jittery~ thats when I know its good :)
author: Susie L.

description:
Everytime I come here, there's always a long line. Just like the rest of those people, I was also always willing to fall in line. Doesn't that tell you something? 

Always here for the cappuccino! $3 for a shot. They serve their coffees in certain cup sizes. Like the latté is in a bigger cup and the cappuccino is an a smaller cup. If you want 2-shot cappuccino, they won't serve it to you in a latté cup, they'll serve it to you in two different cappuccino size cups. I think this has something to do with measurements and using the right amount of coffee and milk froth to give you a very consistent delicious coffee. This is just my theory. Lol

This place is an answer to one of my many wishes. Conveniently located in embarcadero, close to my gym and close to One Market! I don't need to go to the  North Beach just for a good cappuccino! Service is super fast too!
author: Lora M.

description:
I am no coffee connoisseur, but I do like my daily jolt of caffeine. I popped in and grabbed their iced New Orleans style, with just a hint of chicory. It was pretty dang delicious. But as I said, I personally have low coffee standards.

So how do I know these guys are great? I impulse bought a bag of their Ethiopian Tuktant for a guy back home who works in beverage marketing, and he squeeled in delight! This is a man who knows his coffee, and he acted like I had just given him a bag of gold!

Definitely a little more costly than the average coffee, but it seems to be worth it.
author: Matt E.

description: Super long lines, especially on the weekends! But it was worth it for the New Orleans styled iced coffee. I love blue bottle coffee because they make coffee right. It's smooth, mellow, slightly sweet, and pretty strong. And any of their items are worth the wait and the price ($4 for an iced coffee?!)
author: Sophia Y.

description: I love Blue Bottle and am so happy its finally coming to NYC as well. The NOLA iced coffee tastes a lot better than the Cafe du Monde version (and is available with soy!). Everytime I come here, I'm not disappointed. They roast their coffee beans perfectly. Only downside is that they dislike making macchiatos to go.
author: Nikita K.

description: Super hipster, pricey, and not really all THAT great tasting. Sometimes places live up to the hype, Blue Bottle fell short.
author: Amelia U.

description:
I do like Starbucks. Now, before you get upset and say, "They burn their beans! That's not real coffee," let me explain my evolutionary journey through Blue Bottle. Be warned, I may be the only San Franciscan that doesn't believe that this is the greatest coffee that money can buy.

I have heard, more often than not, that Blue Bottle is the best coffee in San Francisco. Um, okay. All right. I'll play along. After being told this and seeing multiple pictures of the infamous latte art, I decided to finally give this place a try. I have gone twice and have had two different experiences, so listen up.

The first time I went, I had recently discovered the gem that is the Ferry Building. How have I lived here and not discovered it? I really don't know, but it was discovered late in the game. Once inside, I searched tirelessly for that sign that would lead me to the "best coffee ever." Okay, found it! Now, I wait in line, but the line doesn't bother me, because I think I am in for the best caffeine experience of my life. Suddenly, I'm next and I didn't decide what I wanted... Uh-oh. Um, drip coffee sounds good, right? I mean, they make each cup individually, so what could go wrong?

Oh, it was wrong. I don't know if it was because I have been coffee-washed by Starbucks, but this simple, black coffee had an average taste-- not too flavorful and kind of, dare I say, stale? I had to find my Splenda (at Peet's-- shhh!), because, HEADS UP, they don't have artificial sweeteners (only raw and simple sugars for those coffee purists). I finished the cup of coffee (mainly because it was over $2 for about 16 ounces), but I left feeling deceived and empty. I thought I was about to have the most wonderfully caffeinated beverage of my 22-years of existence and... I didn't.

That being said, I kept wondering if I just had hit them on an off-day. Maybe if I got a latte? A mocha? Would that be different? Well, I went yesterday and, while I didn't have THE BEST coffee ever, I had a pretty good and aesthetically pleasing latte. I even Instagram'd it to prove that I went and actually enjoyed Blue Bottle. However, I could probably have bought the same exact thing at any other coffee shop. It was nothing special. It was... Just coffee.

So, in short, I would go with the handcrafted beverages rather than the drip coffee... Then again, maybe that's just me. Maybe the beans weren't burned enough for me.

Back to Starbucks, with my Gold Card, I go.
author: Gabriela K.

description: I'm a huge coffee drinker (thank you college)  but let me tell you.. The Louisiana ice coffee was by far the best ice coffee I've had. I'm not one of those coffee drinkers who put TONS of sugar in their coffee because coffee is too bitter or what not so I really liked that this wasn't sweet and you can actually taste the coffee. Will come back here every time I'm in the area for sure!!
author: Mai S.

description:
Word of warning the queues are ridiculous.  But the wait is worth it.  Now eye up and seat and go get it my friend.

now the coffee chat.  well this is totally what ive been waiting for all my life.  amazingly  good coffee without a doubt.  The rosemary shortbread is another treat.  I had two coffees from this joint and both experiences were glorious!

This is great coffee.
author: Emma W.

description: Stellar location inside the Ferry Building. Before you embark on your walk on the pier or visit the Exploratorium, pause at the Ferry Building to grab a cup of coffee. The coffee is prepared delicately, which I find difficult to achieve given the popularity of this place. There never ceases to be a line for this place, but despite the wait, customers almost always walk away content.
author: Nicki F.

description: These guys have the best latte I have ever tried from any cafe.  That is not hype, that is the truth.  Some cafes can produce lattes that are as good, but not every barista they have on duty can do that and even the ones that are the best can't do it consistently.  There are alot of variables involved.  The machine has to be in top notch condition.  The grinder needs to be cleaned and calibrated.  The coffee needs to be very fresh, like roasted the same day or before fresh.  The milk has to be of the highest quality (and preferably whole).  The barista has to attempt to pull the "God" shot every single time.  That is exactly what Blue Bottle goes for, they go for perfection with every cup they give and it shows.  It's too bad they don't have one in Houston, cause it would definitely be my go to place for a great cup of coffee.
author: Gabriel M.

description:
Heard so much about this place and finally had a chance to tried it. It was pretty awesome!! 

The blue bottle in the Ferry building is under renovation but still open for business. The coffee is definitely richer than many I've tried. The barista were also very nice, friendly!
author: Tiffany T.

description: It was a hot day so I decided to try the iced New Orleans style coffee. It was good, but didn't really stand out from any other iced coffee you'd find at a decent coffee shop.
author: BettyLou H.

description: San Francisco is a 7 hour drive from my current residence, and I usually get there just in time to catch the sunrise behind the Bay Bridge. After that, the first place to check in is Blue Bottle Coffee - their cafe mocha is just right - not too sweet or decadent (like Starbucks or Ghirardelli)
author: Vishal J.

description: The New Orleans Style Iced Coffee is serious stuff -- smooth, creamy, and boldly flavored. Not for those who are afraid of a strong coffee.
author: Kelly R.

description: Nice friendly staff, busy and long line which shows it must be good. Stood in line for 10 minutes only to find out when it was my turn that they don't make vanilla lattes. My fault for not knowing this. Won't be back because of that reason. If you simply enjoy coffee go but if you like sweet flavors don't go.
author: Tony C.

description:
I don't think I have given five stars yet but this place
Certainly deserves one. I drink coffee daily and i hope every day the coffee tastes like this one. Either I am bad at making coffee or haven't found a contender in NY, this place just hits the spot.
author: Hummus P.

description:
A day off from work.
Year-end stuffz to do.
Car getting maintenance.
A need to fuel my caffeine addiction!
Grabbed some coffee love at BBC @ the FB along with their Belgian waffle.

The coffee was the usual...outstanding.

The waffle-dude was making the treats (previous two stops he wasn't working ... frown moments).  Mine arrived piping-hot to the touch. They arrive in a hand-drip filter...cute touch. Mine came with two because of the heat. Crunchy with speckles of sugar...just damn terrific is all I can say.

Fidelity in relationships? Damn straight!
Multi-source coffee loves? Naturally!
author: Derek N.

description:
Of all the pretentious coffee places in SF- this place is the best.

The first time I had heard of Blue Bottle was when I was living in SOMA 3.5 years ago as there is one in the Mint. I remember thinking the coffee was really good, but the barista had a stick up his ass. But I still went back time and again for their excellent Mocha.

Needless to day I was pretty stoked when they decided to build a storefront in the Ferry Building. A pre-work treat is to get there before 9am and grab a drip coffee OR a New Oreans iced- SO GOOD. A drip coffee that is $3 or $4 bucks is worth it and way less acidic than Peets or Sbux. Also at this location the baristas are super nice. Thank goodness! I would pick Blue Bottle over Ritual or Four Barrel any day of the week.
author: Melissa N.

description: During my latest trip to SF, I tried the New Orlean's style iced coffee. So delicious that I had to get it again the next day. Very creamy and just barely sweet. Tastes like melted coffee ice cream. My favorite coffeehouse to date!
author: Jacqueline V.

description:
Vibe: Consistently busy and bustling. This is definitely not a place to open your laptop and do work at (that's not really what you do in the Ferry Building). This is by far the most touristy coffee shop in SF, so be prepared to wait 10-15 minutes in line and another 5 waiting for your coffee.

Coffee: Say what you want about Blue Bottle being a semi-chain, they make great coffee and are very consistent with their quality. I'm always satisfied with my lattes (though Four Barrel's espresso tastes more unique) and I've heard great things about the New Orleans Iced Coffee.

Service: Their nice and speedy, though don't expect to have conversation with anyone behind the counter beyond telling them what you want because they get very busy and need to churn through the line as quickly as possible.

Value: It's pretty fairly-priced when compared to Ritual, Four Barrel and Sightglass, and you'll likely gain more cred from your out-of-town friends for Instagram photos here than at other coffee shops in SF, for whatever that's worth.
author: Luke B.

description: Cold brew in the carton tastes so great. Very refreshing and tastes fresh. Not too sweet either.
author: Diana N.

description:
I knew their coffee was good, albeit overpriced, but man - their waffle!

Blue Bottle Coffee's waffle is an exquisite creation that warrants its name in bright lights. They should call this place Blue Bottle Waffle. Their waffle, priced extremely reasonably at $3, is presented to you hot and fresh. They serve it at the perfect temperature so that your first bite is greeted with a crispy exterior with a buttery, flakey inside. It complements a cup of coffee perfectly as well. My only wish is that there were toppings to accompany the waffle; I'm thinking a spread of speculous butter on top would be mind -mouth?- blowing!

Run - don't walk - to your nearest Blue Bottle Coffee to try a piece of this culinary delight!
author: Mina K.

description:
HOLY CAFFEINE BATMAN!!!!

The cup may be small but it packs a punch, let me tell you. I was wired for hours upon hours! 

I like the fact that they offer a simple straight forward menu. It allows them to keep there commitment of making each cup as best as the last.

The coffee alone is so good that you don't need cream and sugar! 

Overall Thoughts

If it wasn't for those  outrageously long, long, long lines I would gladly patron Blue Bottle Coffee more often!
author: Eddie W.

description: Fantastic mocha, you can even get it iced over some big ice cubes.  The waffles are a great too, perfect size to hold in your hand a nibble on or grab and run away from the crowds in the ferry building.  The trick is to use the window around the corner on the side, rarely much of a line.
author: M M.

description:
I normally like Blue Bottle's coffee - strong, flavorful, delicious. I ordered a cappuccino the other day, and while the espresso was good the milk was not as frothy. But still drinkable.

The beau on the other hand ordered a plain black drip coffee, and it was disgusting! He thought that maybe it was just because he hadn't had coffee in a while, but I tasted it and DAMN was that thing acidic! It tasted like old, stale coffee, that had half a lemon squeezed into it. But having lemon squeezed in might have been better? It was un-drinkably bitter. I don't know what it was, maybe the took some shortcuts with the coffee 'cause they were closing in half an hour. But I was surprised...and disappointed.

This rating gets three stars because I've had good experiences before. But that particular cup of coffee we got a few nights ago? Unacceptable.
author: Emmeline A.

description: The New Orleans iced is almost too smooth. It's slow-dripped right there and all, and very tasty, but didn't have the kick I expected, given the Nawlins name on it. Still, good coffee, and  the setup is right there in the Ferry Building, which is an interesting stroll in a beautiful building on the edge of the Bay. The line moves faster than you'd expect, given the crowd, at least when we were there (granted, that was early on a Sunday morning).
author: Greg M.

description:
Blue Bottle made me the best Liege (Belgian) sugar waffle I have eaten in the US. 

J loves their coffee so much that we get it shipped to Chicago all the time, and we always get beans that have been roasted THAT week. Even my doorman used to comment about how good the package smelled. And I made a friend once when a random stranger stopped me on the streets of Evanston, IL to talk about the Blue Bottle tote I was carrying one day. Blue Bottle, uniting people around the world - pretty neat!

Definitely a must stop at the Ferry Building - the New Orleans iced coffee is a nice little energy booster after gorging on Farmer's Market eats and cones of meat.
author: Yanyao N.

description: Blue bottle coffee is one of my new favorite coffee places to go to. The adffogato is pure bliss 10/10 would get again.
author: Aiden H.

description:
This place lives up to the hype and is worth the wait in the ever-long lines. The coffee is just as good as anything Intelligentsia pours in Silver Lake, but the staff is way nicer and less snobbish (which is true about San Francisco hipsters vs. LA or NY hipsters in general).

The pour-over brews are phenomenal and the New Orleans-style Iced Coffee is excellent on a hot day in the city by the bay. Why did New York already get a few of these places while LA still waits for their first? I know the relationship between SF and LA is shaky and fraught with rivalries (don't tell anyone in the City of Angels that I'm a diehard Giants fan and take pleasure in watches The Dodgers choke), but couldn't you have shown your fellow Californians some love before you sent your delicious coffee off to New York? They've already got so many things, we don't need to hand them another great coffee place to be smug about. 

Bring Blue Bottle to LA!
author: Seth G.

description: Ordered the New Orleans style iced coffee and it was definitely worth a try if you are in the area.  The sweetness of the drink is not overwhelming and it has a very delicious taste.
author: Richard L.

description: The line is always long but the coffee is worth the wait!  Rich bold coffee!  And the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee feels like a decadent treat.  A place like this blows the chain coffee joints out of the water.
author: Mary V.

description:
Coffee!!!! I love coffee!!!! I went here twice in one weekend!!! I want more!!!! I don't care if there's a line!!!! 

My friend who formerly lived in SF sent me a list of various places to visit, and I think  he leaked this to others because it was poppin here. There were two windows, both overflowing. I tried the New Orleans iced coffee with my sister and tried a simple latte with my New Orleans friend-opposites day. Both were amazing. The coffee was good too. Ha. I'm not sure if I enjoy coffee now for the caffeine or for the taste and slow experience. I think it's the latter. Coffee is almost like a companion to me now. Ok, a. I sound like a drug addict and b. I'm veering off course.

Blue bottle, you totally get my vote!!
author: Khathy H.

description:
I ordered the regular drip coffee and my wife got the cappuccino. 

The coffee was ok but honestly i didn't like whichever coffee beans they were using that day,  way too acidity, citrus-ey, and floral.   I did buy a bag of their coffee beans called Giant Steps and it was pretty good.

The cappuccino was good though,  nice and thick foam with a hit of mushroom flavor (in a good way).
author: Ben Y.

description: Excellent customer service! Me and my sister cannot drink too much coffee so we ask the kind barista to spilt the New Orleans in half. We paid paid the regular price $4 and the both the cup was filled 75% in each cup! We got more than we ask for and the coffee was high quality and good! I would defiantly come here again!
author: Julie M.

description:
I pretty much live off of coffee. I die without coffee.

I was at the Ferry building for the Farmer's market on Saturday and decided to stop by here to get some drip coffee. This place is hard to miss...there is a huge line wrapped around this place. 

The coffee was of course amazing. Everyone was very friendly and knowledgeable. I also got to try the New Orleans iced coffee and that was great as well!
author: Phuong K.

description:
Tried their drip, latte, and iced coffee and found them all just okay. 

First things first, it's clean with an open front and modern decor. However there's no seating at the shop, so you need to take it elsewhere. 

As for the coffee itself I think it's just overhyped. It was fine but I waited about 20-25 mins for it which didn't seem worth it. And the guy at the counter was fairly surly and really disinterested in helping; the busy holiday crowd probably did him in but tough shit really. But everything is pretty cheap which is nice.

Also, this isn't something I penalized for but it's worth mentioning that the coffee here follows the recent trends of over-extracting. The drip here was probably 180-190'F and over acidic. Not a fan personally, but whatever floats your boat.

I think next time I'll just go to the Starbucks down the block and get the predictably decent coffee.
author: Jae Y.

description: I am SO incredibly happy that there is one of these in NYC at Rock Center by my office! I had Blue Bottle every day during my visit in SF and was so excited that I could get the same amazing coffee at home! They also have great muffins and cookies but I drank my coffee with a cheese and egg sandwich from Sidekick a few doors down when I was there!
author: Vanessa M.

description: Blue Bottle is a very good place to get your hand-poured coffee. My daughter and I went to Blue Bottle a few days ago. My daughter said that their hot cocoa is delicious and just the right temperature. Also, the staff is incredibly nice. My advice for you is that if you want to get Blue Bottle go early because the line gets extremely long, extremely fast. The only two things that would keep me from making this my daily coffee is 1) its 50% more than Peet's (in the same building and pretty good coffee), and 2) I live in San Diego. :)
author: Mr. A.

description: Best waffles without syrup ever !! Love this splurge :) Only in SF too!
author: Shells M.

description:
Obvi Blue Bottle coffee is always smooth and amazing (Melbourne and Sydney peeps check it out) but also WAFFLES!!! 

Waffles on the pier overlooking the Bay Bridge and Treasure Island is such a cool SF experience especially when they're so caramelly and delicious, and are accompanied by Blue Bottle coffee.
author: Olivia J.

description:
I gave this place two tries. On the first I thought it wasn't worthy of the hype and wondered why I paid 55 cents more here for a regular cup of joe when I could go to Peets and get cup that will get me just as high for cheaper.

I'm one for second chances so I swung by again a week later and got another coffee. I got a waffle to go along with it and you know what. Not bad!

You wait a little bit longer for drip coffee and it isn't as hot as you might want it to be but it gets you pretty damn high. Worth the extra premium you pay for the nice walk along the embarcadero.
author: John B.

description:
Great coffee that has perfect balance of heat and flavor.

I just bought the cafe mocha and only carries one size for all espresso drinks.
author: Jade M.

description:
Long line, as expected, but thankfully moves fairly quickly! Ordered a mocha, which was delicious and very chocolatey but not too sweet (unlike Starbucks). Service was friendly and drinks were prepared efficiently. Just had a huge meal before I came, so I wish I also had room to try their famous black hand-dripped coffee, but that'll have to wait till next time.

The lack of room at this Ferry Building location causes the waiting area to be a messy crowd that takes up most of the "hallway" at that corner.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Hello yelpies! I am alive! So i officially counted I have 15 businesses awaiting for me to write a review on..oh dear.

Anyways, back on topic. I can say I have officially had Blue Bottle and it is amazing!  3 of my friends and I have decided to do a city day with our SLRs, and of course, we visited the Ferry Building.

After some delicious oysters at Hog island, we walked over to Blue Bottle.  Blue Bottle is right across from Ciao Bella Gelato, which i also love.  There was a line to Blue Bottle but I didnt mind! 

I saw that they have the Affogato! If you don't know what it is, it is basically double shot espresso poured over 2 scoops of Vanilla ice cream from Humphrey Slocombe.  It is simply amazing. This was my first time, and I absolutely fell in love.  The ice cream complimented the espresso that words can not explain. The ice cream was fluffy and sweet, but unlike the ones you get from Safeway or something.  The espresso itself is way too strong to drink.  It is  too bitter.  But with the ice cream, it simply became the best dessert.  http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=gmaWUt02_ixItBN2gQsMGQ&select=_nB7ucrHe9yxshvI6C0sqw

The bf ordered a single shot of espresso i believed, and he loved it.  Not to mention the workers here have the best attitude.  Despite the long lines, you are bound to receive your beverage within 5 mins or so.  For $8, bf and I enjoyed some wonderful form of caffeine and was hyped up to go explore the rest of the city :)
author: Stephy L.

description: I got the caffe mocha and oh my word was it great! I'm not sure what sort of special items they use to make the coffee but i paid $5 for an average sized cup. At first i was a little uneasy about it but once i took my first sip man was it worth it! The caffe mocha was so smooth, no bitter after taste, and the art was perfectly done. The wait wasn't horrible but definitely worth it if that's a concern for anyone. Sadly, i went while they were under construction and i was very upset to find that they had no liege waffles because i was really looking forward to it. I'm sure if i did have one, it would have been just as good at the caffe mocha. Recommend for out of towners looking for a great cup of coffee!
author: Alanna M.

description: I dont drink coffee. However, my bf's mom and my bf loves it. So it is a great gift for them whenever xmas, birthday....COFFEE LOL
author: Diem H.

description: My experience here was incredibly disappointing. A friend highly recommended this coffee shop to me and so I had high expectations for it. Maybe I just had a bad blend but the coffee here was not very good: incredibly strong with an overbearing burnt taste. I also had the pretzel with gruyere cheese and that was absolutely awful: dry, chewy, flavorless, and tasted like it was made the night (or two) before!
author: Jason S.

description: just waited half an hour fer a broke-ass liege waffle on my way to dodgers-giants today.  sure, it was fresh and yeasted.  but there wasn't nearly enough sugar in it,  hence no hard outer crust.  also, the sugar seemed granulated and not pearl.  at least, they still gettin the coffee right....
author: Randy D.

description: Had the N.O. styled iced coffee is very light and not too strong - soothing when served at the right chilled temperature. Haven't tried anything else so far but it's a great brew after having a large meal in the Ferry building that sets you in a food coma!
author: Briget P.

description:
Wherever my work takes me, so does my coffee. And so today's morning coffee edition is Blue Bottle Coffee Co.

During my time in San Francisco, and after much site seeing of The Paris of the West, I visited the most talked about coffee shop in town.

My coffee of choice would have to be their lattes. Although their Drip Coffee was quite bold in taste, the lattes are much sweeter-and they add their signature leaf coffee artwork on top.
author: Prince S.

description: So I do not care for coffee but this place makes me crave it! For a place to have coffee so damn good that I actually want their coffee is some special voodoo magic. Their iced coffee is amazing! The flavor is fantastic and it is not bitter at all. I don't know how they do it but well done! I'm sold!
author: M H.

description: Coffee in my opinion can be a hit or miss. I ordered a caffe latte and knowing that they use organic milk, I knew that it was going to taste like the ones they serve in Italy. It was good coffee but it didn't "wow" me.
author: Lariza B.

description: Blue Bottle is one of the best coffee spots in the city & we always stop here before we drive home to Sacramento.  I look forward to enjoying my delicious mocha!
author: Lisa F.

description: Dear Lord! That's some good coffee. I also had the yogurt and a side of granola. Breakfast has never been better.
author: Matt T.

description: My favorite coffee. When at home I drink Novo, but Blue Bottle blows it away. Expect a line if you go during the morning before work or lunch time, but it's worth the wait. The New Orleans is off the chain!
author: Tim C.

description: Tried the infamous coffee and waffle.  It was good no doubt, but I wouldn't fly from Houston to San Francisco just to visit this establishment.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
The best coffee I've ever had.

Seriously.

I only drink coffee about once a week so I don't feel bad about spending a lot on a quality cup. I've had the latte, drip coffee, and New Orleans iced coffee here and they were all amazing. Smooth is the word that comes to mind. I wish the cups were bigger though!

I'm usually opposed to foodie snobbery but the stellar reputation of this place is much deserved even though the price is pretty high for a small cup o' joe. I consider it an occasional treat and generally don't mind the wait in line.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
I've been wanting to try them for a long, looooong time. And I finally got to yesterday!

I ordered their New Orleans style iced coffee with soy. I'm not normally a straight coffee fan, but their iced coffee was very good. The aftertaste that lingers reminded me a little bit of chocolate. It was so pretty to look at, too, because they float the milk right on top of your drink since it's the last thing they add in.

I also tried Boyfriend's mocha. It's not as sweet as I would normally like my mochas to be, but it was still pretty decent. I want to come back and try their TCHO hot chocolate and affogato!
author: Anna W.

description:
CAN'T GET ENOUGH!!!!!!

Best coffee in life. So disappointed in myself for not having tried Blue Bottle sooner although I've always heard about the smooth, rich, creamy, quality, gourmet coffee. Lattes, mochas, Gibraltars...it doesn't matter; they're all amazing!

I've yet to try the drip coffee, affogato (ice cream with espresso?!) and the waffles, but I cannot wait to!
author: Jacqueline V.

description: Got the cold brew and asked them to split into two cups to share. A bit pricey but worth a try.
author: Suzy L.

description: I'm not a coffee snob so I can't give you an in-depth review of their coffee.  All I know is that it's consistently good and people wait in long lines for this stuff.  I'm more pumped about their WAFFLE!!!  Oh yum...it reminds me of those liege waffles that I used to get from the food stand in NYC.  It's a huge waffle that comes out hot from the griddle and has little sugar crystals hidden throughout.  Ours were the size of my hand, just in case you're wondering how many to order.  It's also not a bad deal for $3!!
author: Nina L.

description: Blue bottle coffee is so irresistible, our fatal attraction leads to me drinking 4 cups of it per day. I haven't slept in six years. I'm just constantly awake, emanating an intense aroma developed from drinking too much of that rich coffee. Some of the roasts have a bright, fruity, spiced flavor; others are nutty and caramelly. Anyway, you can be sure that the coffee won't be weak-bodied or watered down. And I read somewhere that drinking coffee gives you super powers and helps bring world peace, so drink away to your heart's content.
author: Monte H.

description:
Probably my wife's favorite coffee bean at the moment.  She looks for decaf whole bean and they carried some Decaf Noir at this time... a strong robust bodied flavor is its main characteristic.  Sold by the half pound, they suggest using it quickly,  especially if you drink it black like she does, to have the best aromatic experience.

Also happened to notice that they carry the Chemex funneled flask coffeemaker if you're into that.

Nice brick and mortar coffee shop.  They also ship.
author: Lawrence L.

description: The New Orleans iced coffee was pretty amazing. Deliciously sweet, but not overwhelming. It was a cold-brewed coffee, rich and smooth, with a deep chicory flavour. Served over ice, there was a perfect amount of milk to make this drink buttery and so awesomely satisfying.
author: Vincci L.

description:
I think I just fell in love with a coffee.

I became a caffeine addict when I left for college.  Now that I'm back home in San Francisco, I was ecstatic to try Blue Bottle Coffee.  I've heard lots of great things about this coffee.. but I thought.. a coffee is a coffee, isn't it?

I was so wrong!  I just ordered a simple latte - and it's seriously as good as it gets.  I usually like my drinks sweetened, but this one didn't even need the added sugar.  It was rich in flavor and extremely aromatic.  

I've definitely become a fan :)  

*Side note for sweetened coffee drinkers: their drinks do not come sweetened, but they do have a station with raw sugar you can add to your liking

*The lines can also get kind of long, but it's well worth your wait.. I promise!
author: Cecilia S.

description: One of my favorite places to get coffee. I'm a flavored cream in my coffee kind of girl but here I could take an ice coffee add a bit of half and half and be in heaven! Definitely a must try if you're in the city.
author: Courtney R.

description:
This place is the one for tourists who made a long line and wanted to believe that it should be good. However, reality is not up to the review. I tried the new orleans ice coffee.  No favor! Taste like a vending machine coffee plus milk.  
I purchased a 1/2 Ib bean bag for curiosity.  When I used my credit card, they mandates 15-20% tips. (Tip for coffee bean?)  My friend told me that there was "no tip" option in the bottom, but I could not see it.  (Please be careful when you use your credit card!)
I would not go there again. In the same mall. there is peet coffee shop which provides better coffee and accomodation.
author: Maria K.

description: Long lines, and not just tourists. In a building that also features Peet's (another great place), the only coffee spot I will wait in line for.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE the affogato here. It's like crack! As if Blue Bottle wasn't amazing enough already, the affogato is that to the next level.

I'm not gonna lie, I like Starbucks and I go there quite often, but Blue Bottle and Starbucks are in two different stratospheres. You don't go to Blue Bottle to stay awake, you go to Blue Bottle to get Blue Bottle and savor the rich warm aromatic coffee crack-y goodness, perhaps further enhanced by the crack-chocolate that is Recchiuti's. Mm mocha latte... How amazing is it that they have a Rechiutti's latte and Rechiutti's itself a few feet away? Perhaps they should consider a Recchiuti's salted caramel latte? I'm getting distracted. Affogato still wins though.

What is an affogato? 

It's 2 scoops of the amazingly decadent Humphrey Slocombe's bourbon ice cream, a shot of espresso, mixed with cornflakes. This might sound odd at first, but it's... crack. The bitterness and unique Blue Bottle flavor of the espresso plays off the perfect sweetness of the ice cream, and the corn flakes add an interesting yet wonderfully complimentary texture. Even when it melts it's still delicious. I always end up scraping the bowl. I've never felt it to be a rip off at $5.50, I only wish I could have it more often... 

I have brought as many of my friends as possible here, coffee lovers and non lovers alike, and they've always loved the affogato. One time, I had friends from out of state visiting SF, and they were going to pick me up from the Ferry Building. When they got there, I was still in line, and they ended up circling the block for maybe 30 min until I finally got their affogatos. All irritation melted away as soon as I handed them their spoons. They still speak fondly of Blue Bottle.

This isn't to say the rest of their offerings aren't great. However this is one of the few Blue Bottle locations that offers an affogato, which should definitely be taken advantage of. If for whatever unfathomable reason you're not in the mood for an affogato, I've never had a Blue Bottle drink that I didn't like...

5(^infinity) stars even though the lines are crazy long and half the time they're out of ice cream. There's a side service window that you can try and check to see if the line is shorter.

Ferry Building is also right next to the Embarcadero BART. Obviously, don't try to park here.

One warning.. as my friend once said, "you can't just 'do' crack ONCE." You'll be back and back again...

Dear Blue Bottle, PLEASE come to LA! I really need my fix.
author: Lana T.

description: I've tried Blue Bottle Coffee in the forms of ice cream and gelato elsewhere and loved it. Now it was time to try the real thing. They probably had the longest line inside the Ferry Building. I saw that the New Orleans iced coffee is popular on yelp, so I ordered that. It was strong. I think I would've enjoyed a mocha more. One more place down that I can now said I have tried.
author: Helen H.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of coffee but I hear the coffee at Blue Bottle is the shizz. 

I came here to try the Affogato dessert:  espresso poured over organic vanilla ice cream. OMG it was good.

The Affogato is $5.50 and one of my co-workers wanted to share one with me.  At the risk of sounding like a pig, I told her that i was feeling super tired and i needed the extra coffee to help me stay awake when we get back to the office.  The truth is, i'm just a fatty. :)
author: Jennifer C.

description: Had Blue Bottle Coffee at another location a long time ago and their coffee is always so tasty. Always order the mocha latte and love those cute little designs they make. Wish they had some Blue Bottle Coffee in Hawaii. Line seems to always be long but it's moves pretty fast.
author: Cheryl K.

description: the best coffee I ever had in USA!!! I become a fan and buy coffee thru internet. Wish the casher and baristas were nicer, friendlier. the place was too busy they all look exhausted.
author: Jessica P.

description: Why go to Blue Bottle at the Ferry Building? Coffee? Nah. I got a cheese and butter sandwich. Not bad, the bread was nice and soft. Think of that episode of Twin Peaks where Ben Horne and his brother are enjoying similar sandwiches and freaking out about them.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
It's true, Blue Bottle Coffee and its smooth, dynamite flavor beats the pants off of Starbucks and its consistently burnt, bitter wallop.

Still, $2.75 for a single drip coffee is a kick in the wallet region and a bit of a time constraint. Think special occasion, not every day use.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
If you like the taste of coffee, you will love Blue Bottle's New Orleans style iced coffee.. It has a slight roasted flavor which makes it so much more unique than other iced coffees. I, personally, found it not sweet enough but I'm sure if I added sugar it would have done the trick. I can't wait to go back and try their lattes also. 

It is clear that Blue Bottle puts a lot of effort and care into their drinks, which I love in a business. The baristas are beyond friendly and helpful.
author: Allie E.

description:
Line way too long on both sides on sat morning.
Overpriced mocha. Wished it was more chocalately and a Lil sweeter. Mind u, im one who never adds sugar to anything so when I'm in mood for a mocha, I'm looking, I guess, for a decadent treat. My craving was left unsatisfied :/.
The chicory coffee in carton to go was $4... Couldn't really taste anything special about it. 

Next day, line was much more acceptable. The drip coffee was strong and delish. Hot chocolate was okay. 
Decided to get in line again and Got a bag of beans. First time there so asked for recommendations and totally got attitude from sales girl. There weren't even that many ppl behind me and the Batista was getting their drink orders on his own.
author: Cara H.

description:
Because of my unusual work-schedule and the Downtown/ Waterfront area being constantly busy, I don't go to the lively Ferry Building Shopping Center too often. With many local businesses including the newest Blue Bottle Coffee Company, (excluding Peet's...I don't know why they are in there) just opened earlier in the month and being close to my crib, maybe I and/or my family should gut it out and come more often!

Well, just like the other Blue Bottle locations, the line is incredibly "long", especially on the weekends. But honestly, with the local name Blue Bottle blending hand-crafted coffees and other beverages, I don't mind the wait. Despite being in the long line with a bunch of cranky and desperate coffee-lovers, many people and I definitely will expect to receive a great cup of joe.

After waiting in that long-ass line, I finally ordered my Latte for $3.50. My drink was made in one of those "sick-ass" espresso machine. And my drink was topped off with the cute heart-shape on the foam. A design that my kids love to see when I'll bring them here for BBC's Hot Chocolate made with Michael Recchiuti chocolate, another local 

I also bought a slice of rice-pudding pound cake made with Arborio Rice for $3.00. That slice of pound cake is not a concrete cake that is made out of a solid brick and can break a window, but it was extremely moist and falls apart very easily. All pastries including mine was packaged in a compostable coffee-filter (Maybe a Melitta #4 coffee-filter). 

Credit cards are accepted here and expect a long wait, esp.on the weekends.
author: Matt G.

description:
Tcho chocolate and waffle is a perfect couple !

Never mind the lines , and the agonizing wait the beverages are amazing and just got bitten by the waffle bug yum yum
author: Nelce S.

description:
Pow! Ping! Pow!

I find it sooooooooo delightfully interesting that I've been the brunt of many a date question and the obvious dumbfounded looks received on my end.  Why?  Because I can't really say no but I can't really say yes either.  This conundrum has put many phrases to the test, especially when they are coming from men.

I have not reached that level yet.  You know, the level where the screen turns slightly fuzzy to let you know a checkpoint has been reached in Gears of War.  The level where accumulating vacation hours increase from the standard 8 hours to 10 hours based on tenure.  The level where a room rating jumps from a 2-star to 4-star AAA scale.  Getting charged $35 for ribs as opposed to the $3 McRib from McDs.    

So in saying, at least I know that whenever I'm out and about with my friend there are no checkpoints or levels to attain: he is the quality control when it comes to coffee and I've never been disappointed.  Today he mentioned Blue Bottle and although I'm not much of a convert to frou frou preparations, it was something different.  This location is Spartan in design, something I was much enthused about, pure black and modern embellishments.  The menu, the same.  Nothing more than coffee, tea, lattes and espresso drinks.  Don't expect anything fancy other than the paid privilege of watching your coffee drip into that little cup.

It was good coffee and we took it out to the benches on the other side and propped ourselves for a good two hours of conversation, advice and welcomed comments from an adept observer such as my friend.  Who has been able to get a date in with you?  What? That's what men are like nowadays?  Ah, I see.

Then again, with good coffee and good friends, who needs a distraction?
author: Miika M.

description: I'm not a huge coffee drinker but I went to this place and had the New Orleans iced coffee and a waffle. It's my new favorite to go to and a must when I visit the bay. My drink had just the right balance of coffee taste and milk and maybe a little bit of a sweetener in it. The waffle was amazing, hot and made fresh to order. There is always a line but everything is made to order so it's worth the wait.
author: Erika S.

description:
Their coffee isn't much to brag about. I wouldn't go out of my way to get coffee from here. Being a coffee lover, I was very disappointed at the quality of coffee that they offer. I was even more disappointed that they only have one option for an iced drink. I really wanted an iced mocha because it was those rare hot days in San Francisco and the barista told me that they can't make iced mochas. wtf?! So i opted for a latte. I was pretty much drinking flavored water. I took two sips and threw it away. 

They get one star for the coffee art. It was nice to look at. 

I recommend taking a 20 minute walk down the Embarcadero to Philz Coffee. Not only does Philz offer a variety of flavorful coffee, they can also make any drink iced.
author: Lisa H.

description:
#28 on the 7x7 List: a Gibraltar 

-Tasty?  Yes - the drink may fit in a shot glass but it's the right size for big-punch afternoon picker-upper from work.  There is some serious foam on this puppy.  Delicious!

-Service:  Nice and prompt.  I was lucky that I was the first one at the counter when I approached because when I was enjoying the Gibraltar, a long line had formed around the small space and when I got up from my seat, someone dove right in.

-Ambiance:  open counter space in the ferry building.   the people next to me was a superior-subordinate pair.  I think the sub was getting an informal performance review - I guess they felt comfortable enough here to do this here

-Worth the trip/try?   If you like coffee and  if you haven't had Blue Bottle, then you can't say that you have been to San Francisco until you get one.  Trust me, Peet's is everywhere, even two coffee and espresso machines on every floor in my office building for free caffeine, but I still go to BBC
author: Winnie L.

description: Place is BEYOND AMAZING. Line is always long, but it's worth the wait. If you're in a rush, tell whoever's waiting to wait longer because you're about to taste heaven. I'm serious. Blue bottle coffee puts coffee on a different level. I can't even put Starbucks, Peets, and Coffee Bean in competition with BBC. I'd say places like Stumptown, Verve, Temple, Intelligentsia, and Forge is probably in competition, but even then BBC is the BEST!
author: Gabriel C.

description:
Affogato with Humphry Slocombe Ice Cream? It's good for breakfast, lunch, dessert, and heck...dinner too. 

Iced coffee is toddy style (cold brewed ice coffee), so it doesn't give the stomach ache that Robbin Williams talks about in his standup. 

I enjoyed some while I waited for my girlfriend in the bathroom line at the Ferry Building.
author: Luke H.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee, we finally meet! I've passed by this spot numerous times, but have never tried their coffee due to the long lines and tight schedules.

Actually, the secret is to drop by their "Secret Counter" located along the side of the shop. I was surprised to see their small list of single origin coffee, and HAD to purchase of cup!

My coffee fanaticism led me to try the Rwanda Kirezi. It was semi-bitter, really earthy, and strong.

I'll definitely try more of their single origins the next time I'm walking around the Ferry Building. Always nice to grab a mean cup of coffee, sit outside, and enjoy the sun with friends! :)
author: Kevin J.

description: Coffee is great but the time it takes to place an order and get your drink is inefficient. If you're in a hurry, do not expect fast service here.
author: Candice M.

description: Hubby liked his cappucino and I really enjoyed my iced soy latte. So happy they had non dairy milk options! Being from Seattle, I can say this place knows how to make great coffee and espresso!  Strong yet smooth espresso and not bitter like Starbucks.  Loved this location too being in the Ferry building.
author: Jewelz C.

description: A simple delicious cappuccino made well, right temperature and delivered with a sweet smile. The husband tried the iced coffee and loved it. We'd go back for more everyday except we live in Chicago !! The hunt for good coffee is always on.
author: PJ T.

description:
New Orleans Iced Coffee, I could drink that all day long.  Served creamy, cold, and slightly sweet, it's the perfect balance of caffeine and tastiness.

Cappuccinos are also frothy and delicious, best with a spoonful of sugar.
author: Minnie M.

description:
Hubby wanted to get some coffee so I suggested Starbuck's or Peet's.  Peet's is in the Ferry Building so when we got there I remembered that Blue Bottle Coffee has a NEW shop location Inside the Ferry Building.

We've been to the location at 66 Mint St. and enjoyed it.  

He picked a Caffe Latte $3.5 - it takes a while to make and they put the nice coffee art on top.

espresso 2
macchiato 2.75
cappuccino 3
caffe latte 3.5
caffe mocha - Michael Recchiuti chocolate - $4.5
Affogato w/ Humphrey Slocombe ice cream $5.5
New Orleans style iced coffee $3.5
hot chocolate w/ Michael Recchiuti chocolate - $3.5
etc, etc.

Neat items I saw, didn't buy:

Firebrand's sweet brioche sour cherry jam filling $4.5
Sesame Absinthe Cigars (cookie) w/ St George Absinthe in it $1 ea
Rosemary Pine nut shortbread w/ Eatwell Rosemary $1 per cookie
Olive oil shortbread w/ Bariani olive oil $1

Can get busy & long lines.  Expect it & have lots of patience.
author: Ann L.

description: A really good latte, I'd say worth the 20 minute wait in line.  Limitless people watching courtesy of the Ferry Building makes the time go by pretty quickly.  Hmmm....those waffles looked good. Next time!
author: Kristi C.

description:
They serve good decent coffee... but seriously is it worth the wait? I've had better coffee. Not that theirs isn't good. I think it's just over hyper-ed since they bagged the $20M in VC money. 

I had the latte and wanted to have the mondrian cake but sadly they do not sell it at their stores! WEIRD. You have to order in advance. I would think that they would at least offer a taste of it... otherwise, how will people know it's good enough to warrant a whole CAKE order??? This is one bet I am certainly not willing to take (especially at $75 a pop). Left disappointed that I didn't get to pair my coffee with their signature cafe.
author: Amanda L.

description:
Drip drip drip!
Always a huge line in the ferry building but its worth it.
