I have found that if I leave the city for a few days and especially end up in a place with bad coffee, one of the first places I go to when I get back is to have some palate cleansing BB coffee. 

Only downsides of this location (minus half star) are the pastries are just ok in comparison to other places that serve BB, and while I'm usually a very patient person and lines don't really bug me (you can't rush good food, drinks, or coffee or sex, but I don't stand in line for that last one), standing in line with cranky people fiending for coffee, especially a line that sometimes gets disorganized on semi-busy to busy days has tried my patience. I've also had someone with a similar name try to steal my drip at the farmer's market cart. For the THIRD time blonde lady who *just* ordered your drip, the cup says M-y-l-a and the barista just poured your hot water. That is why he is not handing you MY drip coffee with my name on it. Sometimes it helps to have a unique name.
author: Myla A.

description: Who queues for coffee? You do. I was sceptical because of the long line but the smell of strong, chocolatey coffee lured me in. I didn't order anything fancy, just a black drip coffee, and it was definitely worth the wait. Go now and get in line.
author: Ellen G.

description:
Coffee= 10 stars  Excellent!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Liege Waffle= 0 Stars
You do not use the correct Pearl sugar to make your waffles.  Please drop the LIege from the waffle description.  The waffles should be slightly caramelized after the baking process from the Pearl sugar.    I cannot recommend calling this waffle a Liege waffle.
author: Dennis S.

description: Nice location and nice setup but the coffee is way overhyped. Not sure if it's the way they brew it or what, but their prices aren't too ridiculous compared to other places. I got their drip coffee and it tasted just like a black coffee from Starbucks or coffee bean, a bit bitter and burnt tasting.
author: Eric K.

description: Great place to stop while browsing the ferry building and the Saturday farmer's market. Coffee is phenomenal. I got  my usual cafe au lait, but I tried my friends New Orleans Style Coffee and it was fantastic. Coffee is very high quality. Worth the wait!
author: Lisa R.

description: Warm staff, great coffee and a good spot for a touch and go drink. Their New Orleans iced coffee is one of the best I've had and it makes for the perfect drink when you want to take a walk by the ocean or through the Ferry Building. My new favourite coffee spot.
author: Shruti D.

description: Always a freakin line at this place! But their tcho hot chocolate is one of my favorite things ever. TRY IT!
author: Callan B.

description:
Double fisted latte and drip. I know, I'm so naughty, but I had to try both. And they were both wonderful. Line a little ridiculous though.

Great waffle too.
author: Eric B.

description:
I love Blue Bottle Coffee.

Sadly, I'm a Starbucks guy on most days. They're everywhere and I've been used to settling for "adequate" cafe drinks. But, when I can, I make a trip to BBC and indulge a little. I'm not a fan of complicated coffee drinks, so I always go for the drip coffee. It's smooth, creamy and uncomplicated, and it feels great on cool San Francisco days. Of course the line is intolerable at times, but there's nothing an iPhone full of apps can't get you through. Once you get close enough, you can pass the time looking at the cool alternative coffee-brewing contraptions they sell. Everyone who works there is nice, and they do simple latte foam art for every drink, as busy as it is. I'm not a coffee aficionado but I like how BBC has decided to specialize in quality coffee. Starbucks isn't a coffee shop anymore because they've tried to diversify to be everything for everyone. BBC has a much simpler goal, and they've achieved what they tried for.
author: Reid K.

description: 5 stars for the excellent Cappucino I ordered, 3 stars for the NYC style line and the 30 min wait.  Seriously, I fly all the way across the country to stand in LONGER lines than what I experience in Manhattan??   But yeah, it was worth the wait :-)
author: Devin D.

description: Great coffee made with care and terrific service.
author: Brenda M.

description:
The iced coffee was fantastic. One of the better iced coffees I've had. Perfectly finished with some whole milk to give a little smoothness, richness and oomph. 

Don't be in a hurry though. I'm from Austin, which is notoriously laid-back (and/or high), and most Austin baristas would zoom right by this crew.
author: Cory B.

description: Delicious and comforting coffee! Recommend latte and iced coffee. -1 star for the long queue.
author: Kai-wing B.

description:
The Ferry Building is always pretty busy, which makes for some long lines at Blue Bottle. The good thing is that they have a "secret window" around the corner from the main register for a majority of the day. Coffee is pretty decent, latte art is always fun, and it's overall a great SF treat. I like this location better than some of the others.

My suggestion: Grab a cup and go behind the Ferry Building for a relaxing chat along the water.
author: Brad Y.

description: Blue bottle is a great place to visit because they truly care about each cup of coffee that they make.  It takes a pretty long time for them to make each cup, but for coffee lovers, the quality definitely shines through.  My fiance got a latte and I got a hot chocolate (I'm not a huge coffee fan except for Philz Coffee!) and both were great.  I love the attention they pay to the details.  My hot chocolate had the most beautiful milk heart "drawn" on it.  I recommend stopping by if you are looking for a coffee experience that deviates from the typical Starbucks experience.
author: Alyx F.

description:
I am not a huge coffee drinker... but man, their Mocha with TCHO chocolate was SO GOOD. 
If you love coffee, I do recommend you to check it out. When people visit me from out of town, I love taking them here if they are a coffee person. If you are used to Starbucks etc, not the place for you, because you will end up adding hella sugar. 
You want real coffee? Here you go! DO IT.
author: R M.

description: The wife really liked the coffee...I on the other hand thought it tasted like Starbucks espresso....that is to say a really strong burnt taste. Not a fan, but my wife bought a bag of it so I may revise this rating in the coming days....or not. We'll see.
author: Donald P.

description:
Recommended by the doorman at the Hyatt across the street.

Latte was smooth bordering on watery.   The cute little picture in the foam was sweet.  The real treasure here was the fresh berry coffee cake in individual paper holder...yummmm.  Line not too long but waiting for order was a pain.

For coffee in the Ferry Building though, will go back to Peets.  In fact I did, right after, for a more satisfying latte.
author: Li Y.

description: Excellent coffee.  A must try if you are a coffee aficionado and happen to be in the Ferry Building.  My usual is the drip. It is worth the wait.  Delicious and smooth.
author: Donna P.

description:
Blue Bottle is my absolute favorite coffee and this is my favorite Blue Bottle location! :) 

The outrageously long line is worth the wait. Trust me.
author: Chris W.

description:
*Blue Bottle Café
Ferry Bldg
Perfectly deadly café mocha with Tcho chocolate and soy
Friendly food service
author: Rosquete B.

description: Mr. M and I recently stayed the night in the city.  I wish it had been a romantic getaway...but he had work meetings.  A friend suggested I head over to BB for a waffle as my breakfast.  Now, I have long been a fan of blue bottle...but I had NO IDEA about the waffle.  Good grief.  A made to order slice of heaven.  All fluffy and warm.  A litte crisp. A hint of brown sugar.  Wrapped in a napkin.  Combine it with a BB coffee.  Wow.  Guess I did have a romantic morning...with a waffle.
author: Linda M.

description:
I heard about Blue Bottle Coffee and had to try a cup. I knew it had to be good when I found myself waiting in a long line and my fellow coffee enthusiast both in front and behind me in line had their arms overflowing with Blue Bottle Coffee beans. It's extremely crowded on a Saturday afternoon in the Ferry Building with the Farmer Market bustling outside.

It was exactly $2.50 for drip coffee. You can literally watch the baristas pour hot water over the beans and see each drop fall into your future coffee cup. It takes a little while but the result is a strong, fresh cup of coffee. The only downside is that it comes out only a little better than warm after all tha time it takes to drip. I like my coffee hot! The long line and the temperature are my only reasons for not giving 5 stars.
author: Samantha L.

description: After recommendations, me and my wife went here as soon as we could. When we got there we saw that it was really popular, and there were 2 different sides to the cafe to get your drinks and they both had pretty long lines. The coffee was right, but the service was not top notch, they were obviously stressed from the long lines and they were not very helpful at answering questions and making suggestions. Still the coffee was the best we had in San Francisco, and just about anywhere else.
author: Aaron D.

description:
Food: 4
Decor: 3
Service: 4

Waited 20 min in line Saturday morning around 10am. 

Had a couple sips of the decaf soy mocha, which wasn't bad, and a Belgian waffle, which was pretty good.
author: David L.

description:
Must have coffee... !!!

If you've never had a properly made latte, you're missing out.  Lattes should be made to the precise temperature without any burnt milk.  Fancy design with the foam is an additional perk, but not required.  But you get all of this at Blue Bottle! 

The lines here can get long during the day, but the coffee is phenomenal.   My go to's are the ice coffee and lattes.  Their coffee is on the stronger side and is a welcomed treat once in a blue moon, rather than an every day venture. 

Start your day here - I guarantee you won't regret it!
author: Lisa L.

description:
The Partner trotted off to Blue Bottle, at the Ferry Building, to get a couple of coffees for us, while I tended to business at Prather Ranch.  I finished and went looking for him and there he was in line.  One of two lines at the Ferry Building stall for this much talked about coffee company.  I went to the restroom, looked at the pastries and cakes at Miette;  went over and bought bread at Acme, and perused the olive oil McEvoy ranch, and M was still in line, waiting.  Normally we don't do status lines, and certainly don't wait in long lines for something that is sold elsewhere in the area, in this case, within the building.

Finally though, the coffee.

I took two sips and was about to dump it in the gutter when M said to give it to him.  He then walked about, maybe twenty feet down the Embarcadero with two cups, sipping from one, before he did what I've only seen him do once, ever:  Dumped both cups, still full, into the gutter.

Blue Bottle has to be one of the most over rated products in the Bay Area, possibly tied with Philz.   A light bodied coffee, it reminded me of the brown water my parents made from corporate tins, two of which were roasted just down the Embarcadero, in a different age.  The after taste, an astringent bitterness, stuck to my throat like that free sample of Starbucks Instant I also dumped.  

No thank you.   It may be trendy to stand in line for this sort of thing, but it's a lot like listening to your iPhone without ear pods:  You think it's cool, everyone over thirty thinks their dad's transistor radio had better sound.  This coffee tastes like canned coffee from the past, under roasted and bitter.

But don't listen to me, keep waiting, drink on...
author: Paul T.

description: Got a cappuccino to go with my Miette cupcake. YUM.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I always love coming to the Ferry Building, specifically for places like Blue Bottle. The design of the store is modern, clean, and organized. The open feel is really neat. It's very unique - I appreciate the Heath ceramics for espresso demitasses that you don't see other places, and that they offer little found home espresso machines like The Ponte Vecchio lever.

With that said, I've found the espresso to be not quite as good as their other locations. Which is a bummer because I love the design of the Kees lever machine, but the espresso is always  on the hot side, with a little too much earthy notes for my taste. Still very good espresso, just not as good as their Mint or Hayes Valley locations.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Not a fan of the iced coffee. Everybody raved about it on Yelp, but I couldnt get in to it.
It was a bit too sweet in my opinion and had just a strange flavor.
author: Charles S.

description:
BEST coffee, hands down!!!

I love this place. Consistently good. Great customer service. 
The lattes are amazing. I live far away and visit the city a couple times a year. Blue Bottle is always on the top of my list.
author: Mather, M.

description: Well. After buying their book and looking foward to coming to the city, I was let down. Yesterday, in oakland,  I had a black sigle origin black coffee. While the flavor was ok, not bitter; although, was cold and very, very  watery. The worst was cost,  north of 3 dollars for that a 1 star. Then today staying in SF. Went to Ferry Building and order a 8 oz cappuccino. Again, it had ok flavor, mostly of milk and just a little bit of smokiness.  However, again cost to flavor and with all the hype. I have to say huge let down. If you have the money, it is ok.
author: Jeff W.

description:
I went back on a sunny April afternoon with Scott L, Rose J, and some non-Yelpers.  Instead of the New Orleans-styled Iced Coffee, I got the Affogato, which is made with Humphrey Slocombe Secret Breakfast ice cream and satisfied the sweet tooth and caffeine craving.

Affogato pic http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/vJaF4HdnmSVF_V0BjeKjtg?select=ra5tR9kNGSGq_9mCW24XsQ

It's a little pricey at $5.50, and one of the Yelpers told me that the Affogato used to have more ice cream. =P
author: Pam L.

description:
After wandering through several mediocre coffee/espresso spots in the Embarcadero and Financial Districts over the last  month or so, I was happy to finally find a place that takes its coffee seriously. 

Blue Bottle makes a handcrafted espresso shot, tailoring the brewing temperature precisely to the particular bean they are using.  They even make those kinds of water temperature recommendations on the dozen or so different types of beans they sell.  Talk about coffee compulsive . . . but it's worth it. The best espresso shots and lattes I've so far had in your beautiful city. And ya gotta love those barista designs that dress the top of your lattes. This morning I got the outline of a rooster. Incredible!
author: David M.

description:
Amazing coffee!!

If you are a coffee lover, you will absolutely fall in love with this place. I always thought Peet's Coffee was the one of the better places around, and when I had coffee from here, it proved me wrong. The coffee here is definitely very bold, but it doesn't taste like dirt. You can enjoy the flavor of the coffee here. I've gotten the lattes and tcho chocolate mochas here a few times. These drinks are always presented so nicely with designs drawn on the top with the foam. I've seen a few variations of leaves and sometimes hearts. The designs are so pretty, I always feel bad for drinking it because you know some TLC was put into those drinks unlike Starbucks and Peet who are all about mass production. 

One thing to me that sets this coffee shop apart from the others are the mochas. They use Tcho semi sweet chocolate which makes the it not as sweet, and I love it. I don't feel as bad drinking a mocha because I know this one isn't loaded with sugar. 

I've came here at different times during the day, but found that I have to wait in line just about everytime. There are two lines to order. In one line which forms at the side of the store, you order through a window. Somtimes that line is shorter. Honestly, even if there is a line, just relax and wait a little bit. You will not be disappointed with the coffee you get.
author: Ayaka S.

description:
ORDER THE NEW ORLEANS ICED COFFEE. Before I came to blue bottle, I was reading yelp and everyone recommended either the drip coffee or the iced coffee.

I see myself as a coffee snob. I like to try every possible coffee shop I see and I like to grind my own coffee beans in the morning. After a long search, I found my favorite coffee (Phoenix Coffee Shop Brazilian Blend in Cleveland, OH). Assuming that SanFran will have a better coffee, I was excited for Blue Bottle. The drip coffee tasted just like Phoenix's coffee so I wasn't too impressed. But, I tried a sip of my friend's new orleans iced coffee and that is why blue bottle earns a 4-star from me.

The New Orleans iced coffee was amazing! There's just the right amount of sweetness to it but also a taste of boldness in the coffee. It's simply amazing. 

In addition, what I love about this place is that the barista decorates every coffee using the cream! They were able to make flowers and heart toppings and I loved it! 

PROs: BEST new orleans iced coffee, fast and great service, decent drip coffee, friendly barista!!!

CONs: ...none yet!
author: Funglin W.

description:
Visited on 3/21/15 @ 3:00pm

Coffee was spectacular! 

Cookies - not so much. Ordered a Double Chocolate & a Snickerdoodle. Two completely different types of cookies. BOTH taste like someone melted a plastic bag into the dough prior to baking.  I know it's weird of me to relate it to that, but hey I didn't bake these cookies! That smell when you have some object that's made of plastic/polyurethane; THAT smell, it's in both cookies. I bake A LOT - specifically cookies & cakes. This is not normal. For $2.25 a cookie you'd think they'd be just as spectacular as the coffee.

So, to sum it up: 
Coffee: Awesome
Cookies: DO NOT EAT THESE 

And if the owner reads these reviews and thinks I'm crazy, respond in the next 2 days and I'll bring them both back to you so you can sample them (but you'll be compensating me for the 20 mile drive in some meaningful way) I am almost convinced something got spilled into the batters that shouldn't have because there's no way this is normal.

Love the coffee!!
author: T W.

description:
+50 hipster points if you come here and order something unconventional.
+100 if you're wearing hipster glasses.
+150 if you're slinging a dSLR over your shoulder.
+500 if you've already moved on because you came here before coffee was cool.

Now, if you're not very hipster and you know little to nothing about good coffee versus bad coffee, and if you're usually content with Starbucks, the mocha is a delicious way to go - even my coffee noob self could tell that it was fine, fine quality. I want to try the affogato, next. Real coffee (real, black, bitter coffee) personally is not my thing, but if it's yours, you will ADORE Blue Bottle.
author: Chrystal Z.

description:
Whoa whoa, put down your pitchforks! Let me start off my saying that I don't drink coffee everyday or every other day like many of these other Yelpers do. If you're not a coffee fanatic, you might not see what the deal is with Blue Bottle Coffee. A coworker treated me to a $4.75 mocha, and that was the most expensive coffee I've had in a long time. Taste wise, I don't see why it's so special. For me it's just a combination of espresso, milk, and chocolate.

The wait was about 10 minutes around 4pm on a weekday, and when you combine the cost with the wait time you can see why I'm a bit confused at why everyone is raving about Blue Bottle.

I think I'll probably be able to enjoy expensive coffee if/when I become a coffee addic... uhhh coffee connoisseur. With all that said, the baristas are very talented with what they can do with the coffee designs. Props to them.
author: Jason T.

description:
The heart foam made me HAPPY.  The cart service was a bit awkward and odd.  The espresso kept me peppy. 

If you're a vendor at the Ferry Bldg, BBCC will trade.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Blue Bottle, I love you.

New Orleans style iced coffee. Mildly sweet with a hint of chicory. Rich, refreshing and so delicious. I'm so sad I can't get this at home in LA.

I came on a busy Saturday mid- farmer's market so the line was very long. Per other reviews this seems to be standard on weekends.
author: Ashley K.

description:
UPDATE: Just had their affogato here, and oh my god, never thought ice cream could ever taste that good. They pour a shot of espresso over the ice cream and the combination is just unbelievably incredible. This will be my go-to guilty pleasure =).


After all the hype i've heard about this coffee shop and their New Orleans Iced Coffee, I decided to try it out. When i got there they sold out!! So sad, I was really excited to see what was so good about this iced coffee. Apparently they sell out of it around 3pm everyday, guess I'll try my luck next time by going earlier. I ended up getting a latte (i thought it was weird that they had no type of syrups, I usually add hazelnut) which was pretty good, but a bit pricey. If you like bitter coffee, you'll love this place.
author: Angela K.

description: Its good yes. I'm sure to people where coffee = life, they can taste the difference, but to the average consumer of coffee, this is going to be excellent but not as life changing as everyone makes it out to be. I wouldn't give Starbucks 4 stars, so theres your frame of reference. Blue Bottle makes the coffee the way it should be, pour over, by the cup, top quality beans (I'm told, but I don't know enough about beans), so its quality that you pay for. Its damn good, but then again, I make my coffee at home with a conical burr grinder and press, so is my life changed? Maybe. But do yourself a favor and try Blue Bottle, then go home and realize your Starbucks or whatever is not holding its own against this type of coffee. But for me, someone who is more than average consumer but not nearly the obsessive level, this is a good cup of coffee. But I won't pretend to know more than what it tastes like.
author: Jon H.

description: No matter how long the line, wait. It is worth every...single...second. Crave this coffee constantly. Heaven in a cup.
author: Kelly M.

description: Love this stuff. Doesn't matter what you get; espresso drinks and pour over coffee are both incredibly smooth and tasty. When in doubt, get a Belgian style waffle with your coffee. And when you're feeling adventurous, get a New Orleans iced coffee, only your waist line will regret it.
author: Dustin B.

description: Best coffee EVER! No need to add anything to the coffee, flavor is amazing, latte is to die for and mocha is out of this world! Blows Starbucks out of the water! They are also one of the few places who have plain soy milk which I have a hard time finding these days... Perfect!
author: alex a.

description: I heard about Blue Bottle from my cousin, so figured I would try it. We went on Wednesday mid morning, not crowded at all.  I ordered a drip coffee and it was strong, but not bitter at all.  Very good coffee. I really enjoyed the full flavor. My only gripe about this location was the lack of customer service. The three employees did not seem happy to be at work, may be just a bad day.  It was raining outside.
author: Merilou T.

description:
Of all the places we went while in the bay area, the coffee at Blue Bottle was all we consistently talked about. Every morning after we tried it, we would start the day off by discussing how badly we wanted to go back for more.
There was something about the slow-drip, cup-by-cup method of coffee brewing that really brought out the essence of the beans. Quite amazing!
author: Kyle C.

description: I am not a coffee connoisseur but the Blue Bottle Coffee Co. Serves up a good cup of java.  I learned of this place from my brother as we wandered around warf.  Their process of drip coffee is a good way to make coffee.  It taste way better than Starbucks.  If you drink coffee or love the flavor of coffee, give the Blue Bottle Coffe Co. a shot.  Get it?  A shot. ... ..... Oh never mind.
author: Dean N.

description: You can't fool a coffee geek from Seattle. Do not ever try to open a store in the Northwest, FYI.
author: Nikita H.

description: From the really long line, you'd think that we were waiting for the bathroom at halftime at a football game.  Nope...just for some individually dripped coffee from the roasters at Blue Bottle Coffee inside the SF Ferry Building.  I expected some mind-blowing liquid caffeine, but what I got was a decent tasting, full-bodied and bold cup of coffee that didn't stay hot for very long.  I enjoyed it as I walked along the cold and windy Embarcadero, but I honestly couldn't distinguish it from any other cup of joe from any other cafe along the wharf.  I do appreciate individually dripped coffee, and I always choose small, local, independent roasters over Starbucks when I can.  I guess I just didn't think it was worth the wait, although I give it to the efficient baristas.  They handled that ever-growing line as fast as they possibly could.  Definitely recommend if you're cruising around the Ferry Building and want to try something different other than the familiar Starbucks, conveniently located at the next port.
author: Carol P.

description: This goes without say, coffee here is the best! My favorite is the cappuccino but next time I'm definitely getting their affogato! This place has a long line no matter what time it is, so their coffee is much more enjoyable if you are not in a rush and just spending the day with sunshine and ocean :)
author: Ruo Yuan L.

description:
Great Coffee, Great Service
Whenever I make it to San Francisco, coming here is always a treat.  Despite the typical wait for coffee, it is definitely well worth it.  Their coffee is always excellent.  My favorite drinks are the mocha and Iced New Orleans style coffee.  The Mocha here is very frothy, smooth, and rich tasting.  The Iced coffee is also an awesome choice to get if you're walking about the Farmer's Market on a sunny morning.  One thing I really do enjoy about their Iced coffee is how cold you get it, granted there is a lot of ice in the cup, however it doesn't ruin the strength of the coffee.

The service is also great when I come here, always greeted with a smile and friendly service.  The simplicity of their menu also makes it much easier to choose out a coffee (and make the line move a bit quicker as well).  It is truly the little things as well that make this place one of my favorites.

*One other tip, if this is your first time going here, there are 2 windows you can order from, check and see which is shorter.
author: Bryson L.

description: As a self confessed coffee snob from Melbourne, Australia I have always struggled to find a decent latte in the states. Blue Bottle Coffee was hands down the best bloody latte I've had outside of Melbourne. And to top it all off, the staff were super friendly and down for a chat. Love this place! Will absolutely come back next time I'm visiting San Fran.
author: Carina W.

description:
I drink a lot of coffee.  mostly out of necessity.  oh who am I kidding - almost always out of necessity.

That being said, I've had a lot of coffee - Starbucks, Peets, Coffee Bean, random mom & pop shops, Jamaican Blue Mountain, cafes in Paris, etc. 

Of all the coffee I drink, Blue Bottle Coffee has hands down, the BEST latte I have ever had.  It was potent, yet smooth and not bitter.  

After describing it to my friend, she asked me, "like a dream come true?" YES! HELL TO THE YES.

ps. it doesn't hurt that they make it pretty too.
author: Jessie H.

description: Love this place but it might be busy at times! It's cool though, I like the embarcadero. I work there and sometimes it's nice to go for a walk and get coffee from here. They also have really good waffles! Try it out!
author: David L.

description:
Yah, holy shit. 
The little bean that could. Blue Bottle owns it! 
Why else would you wait 10 minutes for a cup of coffee?
With two ordering counters too! 
Just WOW.
author: Roanna Z.

description:
Blue Bottle... why do you not exist in Los Angeles? I think I love you. I have had dreams about you and your delicious hand pour coffee. I need you inside of me again.

(And I need to eat your waffles. I need your warm waffles in my mouth like I need to breathe. I'm dying over here in Southern California. Why don't you love me?)
author: April K.

description: I don't understand the hype. Why wait for 30 min for a cup of coffee? WHY? I cannot handle the obsession with this place. The staff is nice, the coffee is fine, but people treat it like their religion. Very overwhelming to me!
author: Julia D.

description:
Love, love, love their latte.  It's so rich and creamy with a beautiful presentation.   It's definitely worth the time that they take to make it.

However, I'm not sure if it's worth the wait on a Saturday morning  I never would have waited 40 minutes (yes, 40 minutes) for a latte if I hadn't been there early for my ferry.

Note to self:  If you go on a Saturday, go REALLY early. Like "when they open" early if you don't want to wait very long.  Otherwise, bring a book and go with an empty stomach so you can order a pastry, too!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
I am a very, very picky coffee drinker, some call me a snob.  I will except that since I have found only a couple of coffee companies that know how to magically roast their beans.  I say magically because the major are just crap.  My motto is, if you can't drink it black then it is crap.

I make an effort each time I am in San Jose to trek up to San Francisco to pick up my beans and bring them home.  It is so worth it.

This truly as good as it gets.  Hope to make it for a cupping someday.
author: Ron S.

description: Did a Cappuccino And a New Orleans Iced (couldn't resist the reviews) and can say the Cappuccino rolled my eyes back.  Only a few places in the country make that list. New Orleans iced was excellent and i rarely drink iced..and it was a cool morning.  They Do take credit cards And it is worth the wait..which was negligible. Yum!
author: Scott W.

description:
The lines are seemingly continual as one would-be patron wasn't willing to wait as he pointed out at 1:30 pm that he thought most would already be caffeined out by that time of day.

But, he was wrong.

On the other hand, they move people along at a decent clip.

Very wise of these guys to set up shop in the Ferry Building. 

Not a ton of options (maybe just at this smaller location?), but what they serve is excellent quality. The latte, in particular, was swell.
author: Miguel S.

description: one of the best cappucinos Ive ever had. The foam and the awesome flavor of the coffee beans make a great combination. The barista is super efficient and makes great designs.
author: Moby K.

description: Blue Bottle is NOT a hype. It's good. It's creamy. It's frothy. It's what you crave when it's 30 degrees in the winter (mocha) and 75 degrees in the summer (New Orleans iced coffee). The waffle is good on any day.... or every day. Come before 1pm to get the waffle though! The lines are aggressively long but patience is a blue-bottle virtue. Man I am going to miss this place when I have to go back to school in the fall and I have to resort to Starbucks again..... the world is so unfair sometimes.
author: Emily C.

description: The affogato, with ice cream from Humphry Slocumbe, will change your life.
author: Richie T.

description:
amazing, flavorful coffee that is done right and roasted beautifully.

affogato - best, the coffee complimented the ice cream perfectly
capuccino
cookie - not good

worth the line and wait.
author: Char Y.

description: Always a line but worth the wait if you haven't tried it before. Typically order the classic drop and it never lets me down!
author: Stephanie E.

description:
Just make sweet love to this coffee already! You will have no regrets. I'm in full-blown stalker mode on Blue Bottle. We are forever friends. Oh god do they love me back?

We went to three different locations - too many times to count over a two week period - and they were all great. The Ferry Building location, while busy, wasn't out of control weekdays around 5pm or on a Sunday afternoon. Even with a long line the time between paying and drinking was short.

Drinks I tried at various Blue Bottle locations:
Caffe Latte
Hot Chocolate - with TCHO chocolate
New Orleans style iced coffee
Single Origin Drip Coffee
Cappuccino

Stuff I brought home:
Granola
Honduras Yarasquin Farms (whole beans)

I give all those items 5 stars. The staff seemed quite knowledgeable and even the hipster vibe was so fitting it made my day.
author: Phoebe R.

description: I love Blue Bottle Coffee and am a Blue Bottle advocate. I cannot express how much I LOVE Blue Bottle coffee.  Normally, I would order the New Orleans iced coffee when I need a nice pick me up for the day (its usually sweetened just the way I like it), but the other day I was just killing time. I ordered the affogato that comes with Humphrey slocombe's brown butter ice cream and a shot of espresso. My experience was heavenly ! I loved it. I engulfed it in 3 minutes flat. It was so delicious. The affogato was served in a bowl so the ratio between ice cream sweetness and bitter coffee flavor can be adjusted according to how you eat it, which is convenient as well since some people serve it in a cup to have the ice cream melt into the espresso and the drink just gets sweeter over time. In this case, you could eat how you like it! The ice cream served with the espresso was well thought out because it was not overly sweet and the buttery ice cream flavor and texture that came with it made it nice and smooth. Can't wait to try more of their menu. Great first time affogato experience here at Blue Bottle Coffee!
author: Lyra C.

description:
I drink my coffee with some half-and-half.

I was visiting my friend in SF and we decided to go to the Ferry building. We grabbed some lunch and saw a huge line by Blue Bottle. My friend says, "I've always wanted to try this coffee." We wait in a huge line and get probably the best coffee I've ever tasted.

Will definitely come back to get some joe here.
author: Jonathan P.

description: Great coffee and oh my the waffles, crispy, tender, yeasty , and simply one of the beast waffles I've ever had, every time we come to San Francisco this is our first stop
author: Denise H.

description: I absolutely LOVE this Blue Bottle because it's super close to work and everyone that works there is super cheerful and kind! Not only do I leave with a perfect cup of coffee, a deliciously simple waffle (or both!) but I also leave with a big smile every time! Demart is one of my faves! Be sure to give him a high five if you ever have the pleasure of drinking a coffee made by Demart!
author: Mallory A.

description:
Awesome coffee, awesome staff, awesome location.

I like my coffee a tad sweeter than most people so at Blue Bottle I enjoy their soy latte and iced New Orleans style coffee. Both have the right amount of sweet and that extra 'umph' of espresso you can't get at any other nearby coffee shops other than Peet's, maybe.

Snack on their hot and fluffy Belgian waffle served uniquely in a coffee filter, with your drink in the opposite hand as you stroll along the Embarcadero. Everyone will be jealous.
author: Colleen V.

description: From there unique and simple cafe designs to their basic menu,  blue bottle coffee knows a thing or two about fine coffee. The hot latte's are exceptional as is their drip coffee,  however the greatest menu item they possess is the iced coffee. I never drink coffee without sugar,  this iced coffee possesses a sweet and full flavor experience unlike any other. There is nothing more to say..... There waffles are also addicting-damn good.
author: Waleed A.

description: I love the coffee here... hands down it is the most delicious coffee I have had.  The new Orleans iced coffee is so delicious ! There mocha is amazing and there cappuccinos are good too ! My parents and I shared a liege waffle which goes perfectly with there coffee !
author: Niloo S.

description:
While visiting SF, I always love going to the Ferry Building for a big dose of deliciousness. I saw a line, and figured I should probably get in it. The hipster crowd did not lead me astray... I got a latte and a strawberry-raspberry-filled brioche. There were a lot of latte orders, and I got skipped, so they gave me a sesame seed cookie too. The brioche was fluffy and sweet, and chock full of jammy berries. The latte was light and frothy - just how it should be, and gorgeous!! I love that they make the pretty little milk designs even in to-go cups. 

I am jealous of people who get to go here every day. If I could, I probably would...
author: Colleen L.

description: I got a delicious iced coffee, fast & fresh. Loved it.
author: Alyssa K.

description:
I have a confession:
Peet, you've been so good to me over the years but I have to tell you 
that Blue Bottle puts an extra spring in my step and thrill in my heart...
I have to go with passion over pattern this time around - I love you BBC!
author: Bridget W.

description: Best coffee in SF available here. The line sucks and there is no need to wait unless you like coffee.
author: Justin S.

description:
Considering I became addicted to coffee via Dunkin Donuts, my coffee standard probably isn't as high as it is for some.  

Despite my humble beginnings, I quickly developed a palate for some of the finer coffee-type things in life, and Blue Bottle Coffee quickly shot to the top of that list, via my neighborhood coffee shop which proudly serves it.

As the Ferry Building is relatively close to my work, and a shot of caffeine is always in order, my work spouse and I came over here to see what the fuss was about.

The coffee is delicious, no question about that.  The woman who helped me was very nice, even though she did overcharge me.  The bacon/cheese pastry thing I got was cold and not that good.  Not horrible, but mediocre at best.

If I am in the ferry building, I'll definitely make a point to come here to get my java fix, although a special trip may not be in order.

We'll see.
author: Pam S.

description:
I love Blue Bottle Coffee.

I've become somewhat of a coffee snob after I got my Nespresso.  I need my coffee to have flavor.  I need my beans to be freshly roasted.

Yes I know the wait for lines are pretty long but it's well worth the wait.  If you are going to the Ferry Building definitely hit up the BB Coffee Bar.
author: Christine K.

description: I got the americano and it was just alright. Not the best I've ever had. It was just kinda bland for me.
author: Amanda L.

description:
A cartoonishly-long, thirty-minute line for three minutes of pleasure with a $5 iced coffee? Yes, I played the fool. It's tasty stuff, but I think the tech bubble may have extended a bit to the blue bottle. 

I must contend that the little Melitta filter I've been oh-so-slowly pouring coffee through (ahem, "over") after I've pre-wet the grounds oh-so-carefully (probably since before the blonde barista was born) might not require a fifty-dollar, fancy-necked Japanese kettle (though cute as the barista) to create a breathlessly-beautiful brew. It's just a little harder to have an attitude when my Melitta is plastic. 
 
Come to think of it, for those preparing "pour over" coffee and not espresso drinks, are they not coffee "pourers" and not baristas? 

That having been said, I'll probably be back.
author: John I.

description: There are only a few actual shops in SF. I think 3? Don't be scared. Just let it happen and succumb to the inevitable line if you are at the ferry building. If you happen to get your butt closer to the mission district it is not as traumatizing. The New Orleans style iced coffee is absolutely fantastic and worth your wait and perfect for the random heat wave we hit last week. My friends and I ordered it with soy. I wouldn't change one thing. Just watching them make their coffee proves how good this stuff is. So. Do it. Don't look back.
author: Lindsey R.

description:
Perfect cup of coffee.

I regeret not buying a million pounds of beans, and, bringing them back home with me.
author: Ramya M.

description:
Amazing lattes.  As cliche as it is, it's true.  My wife is a self-proclaimed latte connoisseur, and the foamed offering from Blue Bottle is tops according to her.  It's a good thing we live in San Jose, as we could do some serious damage if we were closer!

Helpful hint:  If you visit the Ferry Building and are discouraged by the line, step around the corner to the side hallway - there's a counter there that many people seem to not notice.  It's almost like cutting the line, only...not
author: Aaron J.

description:
I'm a huge coffee lover, so I have high expectations for my coffee. Thankfully Blue Bottle didn't disappoint. We had to wait in line for around 15-20 minutes but it was so worth it! The BFF and I both got the New Orleans iced coffee. I like my coffee a little sweet but I didn't have to add anything to Blue Bottle's. It was a little bitter, but perfect after it diluted with the ice. The way it tastes (and the way it's made-- with the drip) reminds me of Vietnamese coffee. I'm giving it a 4 for now because I'm going to come back and try something else off the menu to make sure it's a solid 5!

P.S. I noticed that there was the Saturday morning Blue Bottle Co. cart outside? Perhaps to shorten the overwhelming lines?
author: Allison S.

description: Even if you are lactose tolerant, as I am, and find vegans insufferable and sad, as I do, give the Soy Latte a try. It is absolutely delicious, and ranked next to Intelligentsia as the best coffee I have ever had. I particularly like this location because, latte in hand, I can browse and sample the numerous bakery items in the Ferry Building. If I lived in SF, this is how I would want to spend my mornings.
author: Paul L.

description: Finally went to the infamous Blue Bottle. I have to say, I enjoyed the coffee - no real bitter aftertaste, very impressive. I would probably buy coffee from here again if the line is not too long.
author: Adrian J.

description:
So I just had my very first Blue Bottle Mocha.....

Got there before they opened & took advantage of the time to indulge in an Acme Apple Turnover & man, oh man, it was 1 of the *BEST* I have had - but that's another review....

Ordered my Mocha & watched the barista pour this ultra-decadent melted chocolate into my cup & am thinking wow, this is going to be gggggggreat

Apparently she poured too much chocolate b/c I then see her go to the sink & pour some out (NOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!)  Why pour it out?!  I'll take the extra chocolaty goodness or just pour it back into the pitcher - it has not been contaminated in any way, why waste it??

Then as the espresso is just at its crema stage (which everyone knows is the tastiest part of the espresso shot), she pulls the cup away - again, wasting a lot of espresso that continued to come out of the Espresso Pull.

The milk was not hot, not even warm, & I'd go so far as to say it was still cool...had to pop my Mocha in the microwave when I got to work

There's only 1 cup size (12 oz) & prices are way steep.  This could not be a daily ritual for me or I'd be bankrupt in no time flat.  W/ prices of $4.50 for the Mocha & another $4.50 for a small Brioche - of which I did not partake (think basic, average-sized cupcake), you'll still be hungry, thirsty & incompletely caffeinated.  Good thing I had my HUGE, honkin slab of delicious Apple Turnover at Acme for $2.80 instead!

While not enough espresso to satisfy my morning requirements, I'd recommend coming here for an after lunch / after work / after dinner indulgence.  The taste is absolutely outstanding & as an after-insert-event-here, you'd be completely satisfied w/ this chocolatey treat

So after all this whining, here is the rundown:
Taste = 5 Stars
Price vs Value = 2 Stars
Wasting precious ingredients = 1 Star

So I think I am okay w/ 3 Stars & an A-Ok.  Blue Bottle Coffee is a fantastic, yummiliscious coffee experience - to be enjoyed in moderation.... until you win the lottery
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Dear Blue Bottle,

Thank you for opening up inside the Ferry Building. Now when I come on Saturday mornings to the Farmer's Market I have two places to get your crack filled* goodness.

I also want to thank you for offering an affogato made with Humphry Slocumbe's Secret Breakfast ice cream...although my ever growing muffin top may feel otherwise.

Sincerely, 

Phil H.

*I don't think they really put crack in their coffee - or do they? (insert evil laugh)
author: phil h.

description:
My girl friends and I stopped by Blue Bottle Coffee Co. for a quick coffee before the Peter Pan play in Ferry Park.

ATMOSPHERE
It's located in the Ferry Building, which reminded me a lot of an upscale food court. It's very cute and small. Like others have mentioned, there is usually a long line at the main counter, but if you just go around the corner, you'll see the "secret" window where you can order from.

The baristas are quick and creative with the foam art. The cashier who happened to serve us was a little weird. He couldn't keep our orders straight and kind of creeped me out with his eccentricity.

There is a small area where you can sit. It's located right around the corner next to the "secret window." 

DRINKS
1) Drip coffee
2) Cafe latte
3) Cafe au lait (substitute for soy milk)

All 3 of us thoroughly enjoyed our coffees. This is definitely high grade coffee. It didn't leave a funny aftertaste like most coffees do. Instead, it felt very clean and it wasn't too sweet nor was it too strong.

We were bummed because the affogato was sold out! (We arrived at 6:55 PM and they close at 7:00 PM) Next time, I'm going to come back for the affogato and of course, the hidden item: the Gibraltar!
author: Krystie M.

description:
If the long lines of dedicated people are any indication of how good this coffee is, then I don't know what else is! Blue Bottle is everything it's cracked up to be. It's simply the best coffee you'll get in the city.

If you're looking to get coffee, forget Starbucks! Walk a couple of blocks to the Ferry Building and treat yourself to a coffee that's worth the money!
author: Taylor L.

description: Great coffee!  I was told that I had to get their coffee but the lines were horribly long every time we went by.  I finally got in the long line and it took about 10 minutes to get my coffee in total.  I enjoyed it but it wasn't worth the wait.
author: Denise B.

description: This coffee shop had good service but the coffee was weak and the waffles were nothing but a rip off of Julian's waffles microwaved.
author: Andreas C.

description: Don't be deterred by the queue! The coffee is worth the wait. This is a great place to take visitors for a San Francisco experience. The views from the Ferry Building are spectacular.
author: Amy M.

description:
Brother:  "Hmmmmmm...best damn Latte I've ever had!"

$3 Latte...Walk down the Embarcadero with my favorite boys?  Priceless!  :)

They've also got a few cool looking gadgets for the serious coffee fanatic:  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/vJaF4HdnmSVF_V0BjeKjtg?select=8OjCPWt7dZ4HVWsmJYseoA
author: Judy K.

description:
I really liked their machiatto (I wanted to order their hand dripped coffees, but next time..) .  The brew was bold and slightly bitter, but not so much that I even needed to add any sugar. 

 the line can get long, but there is so much visual stimulation watching the friendly staff work, that the time flies.

-ask them to make you a milk-hearts Christmas Tree!
author: Chris L.

description: I've been here a handful of times now but this just hasn't wowed me in the way I've been lead to believe I should be. The area is a madhouse, even on a Thursday afternoon. If you think you're at the back of the line, double and triple check because you might end up standing around in the cluster of people waiting for their orders and you'll have ended up unintentionally letting 20 people in ahead of you. In the times I've been, I was never able to order what I wanted because they "ran out of it" or "coudn't make it because supplies weren't restocked". Ok...so no simple iced coffee or mocha for me. Fortunately, I've been able to walk away with a strong, iced double Americano and overly-milky latte which weren't up to par with the prices. Better than Starsucks for sure, but nothing I'll stand around for 20mins for again.
author: Kim C.

description:
Ok, so, let's all be real for a second...

We love our coffee.  We love feeling a little exclusive or a little snotty when it comes to our coffee.  I feel like this was one of those experiences we live for (to our fault....)  Trying the thing we've never had or heard about or wanted to try because we wanted to be in the first 1% of people who tried it, we just can't stand to be be in that 99% for anything, can we?

All that being said, I stood in line for about 20-25 minutes for my first New Orleans Iced Coffee on a Monday.  It was great.  I didn't fall to the floor in love or throw my head back in absolute caffeinated glory.  But it was great.  I'd five star it but it was difficult to figure out the beans I wanted to buy in some sort of expeditious manner and it was a bit messy to figure out what was what.

I could have looked it up before online but... I shouldn't have to!  At some point the business needs to cater to the buyer and we should stop bending our knee to the god of materialism.
author: Ramy S.

description:
The coffee at Blue Bottle is good. Normally it takes a while to get during the weekends or during lunch on a weekday. It's nothing worth waiting in a long, long line for but still pretty good coffee none-the-less.

I've had the Cappucino, Drop-Coffee, Gibraltar, & Affogato~ all are really good. I loved the little heart-shapped design they whipped up on the Cappucino. Cute!  The Gibraltar was SUPER strong for a caffeine-lightweight like myself. The Affogato is really sweet and yummy.... something I've never had at a coffee house, more like at a dessert spot, less the espresso immersion.  It came w/ 2 generous scoops of ice cream, from Humphrey Slocombe even (nice!), immersed in a shot of espresso.  It was so refreshingly strong and sweet!
author: Joy A.

description: Definitely recommend the new Orleans iced coffee. Everytime I'm in San Francisco,  I make sure to get a cup of blue bottle coffee.
author: Derek T.

description: Been here a few times now..i pretty much make a habit out of waiting in this 20min line for a sweet taste of coffee.  The cappuccinos are strong and delicious as is the lattes.  If you prefer more milk go with a latte, I actually enjoy the latte much more.  The lines are long, especially on Saturdays due to the Farmers market.  I really find it amazing that there is always a line no matter when you come on a weekend.  The coffee is good, but if you in a rush i wouldnt wait.  The lines can vary from 15-30min, and we all know there's a ridiculous fee for metered parking.
author: Terence N.

description: Umm I should probably update my review, as BBC has really grown on me. I usually come here first thing in the morning before all the other worker bees and definitely before the lunchtime tourists. I love the latte but find the New Orleans iced coffee to be disgusting. The beans are a great gift when I'm traveling to visit friends and family. The waffle is also delicious and I'd love to get the affogatto but it just seems wrong at 8am!
author: Bella L.

description:
Sorry people, I'm a coffee/espresso snob.

Blue bottle doesn't live up to my standard, but they are really good as far as San Francisco espresso goes.  The ferry building I think has the best service out of the Blue Bottle cafés I've been to.  I'm not really big on their beans.

You will have an above average experience with them, and if someone asked me where to get espresso nearby, I'd say "Blue Bottle".
author: Oren F.

description: The New Orleans iced coffee is delicious. Not overly sweet and with the right kick for a perfect afternoon pick me up
author: Matt H.

description: Friendly customer service, accommodating to individual requests (i.e. Adding extra chocolate to my mocha), and cute whipped leaf/heart design. Mocha was not as sweet as I'm accustomed to, but I was glad that it wasn't overly sweetened either. Would like to try their hot chocolate next time!
author: Phoebe C.

description: Classic. Can't go wrong with blue bottle. That said, the ferry plaza presents it's own challenges so be forewarned that you would be wise to avoid peak hours
author: Martin R.

description:
The secret to their great espresso: they use a naked porta-filter (see my photo), which allows them to maintain perfect quality control.  The macchiato was perfect.  The Gibralter (a very short cappuccino - see my photo) was good.

their double chocolate cookie was very good.

But:  The arborio rice cake was meh.  Also, I am sad to report that their hot chocolate is a big disappointment.  They use Recchuiti chocolate, but it does not have the deep, rich flavor I was expecting.  Not nearly as good as the hot chocolate at Schoggi.
author: Scott F.

description: omFg. The best affogato I ever had - Humphrey Scocombe brown butter ice cream w a shot of Blue Bottle expresso. Decadent and refined.
author: Ly N.

description: A simple cup of drip coffee is all you need from this place. It was simple and extremely good. It was packed with a gang of caffeine as I felt it once I downed my cup. Didn't mind the long line, as I was excited to buy some beans for home. A very nice place to have a great cup of coffee hanging outside of Embarcadero. Can't wait for it to come down to LA, so I won't have to order beans online.
author: Kristina and Raf V.

description: The line is ridiculously long on weekends but  the coffee is delicious. I usually get the drip and there's a deep roasted flavor to it. I also don't feel like a crackhead after I drink a cup. It puts me at a good level (energy wise)
author: Sabina C.

description: We waited about 25 minutes in line, but the New Orleans Iced Coffee was absolutely worth the wait! We also had to try the delicious smelling waffle (spoiler alert: it was even better than we thought it would be).
author: Krissy M.

description: Artwork Presentation steals your heart.Great coffee.Had Macchato.Decent in price.You won't find parking closely.Come here by public transport.
author: Priyanka L.

description:
Finally,

I've been waiting for this place to open.  This coffee is no joke.  When you're having one of those days and you want to feel the coffee running effortlessly through your vains take a nice walk down to the ferry building and grab a cup of Blue. 

This is coffee with soul, and I'll pay $1 to support a local product any day.
author: Adam L.

description: The New Orleans Iced Coffee will spring you out of that post-weekend funk in no time. So delicious and refreshing. Worth the wait.
author: Casey M.

description:
This place KNOWs their coffee!!!  Seriously, if you love caffeine like I do and need a fix daily, please stop by here when visiting the area.  You will not be disappointed!!! I promise!  I tried their Cafe Mocha ($4.50) made with Michael Recchiuti chocolate - deliciously rich & super strong, any caffeine & chocolate lover's ideal drink!  And honestly, you just CANNOT go wrong w/ anything that's made with Recchiuti's products right?  :D  They also do really pretty latte & mocha art, check out the pictures I took.  Will definitely come back & try more of their drinks & pastries!

Beware of the long line during weekends, I came on Sat for Farmer Market and we waited about 30 minutes before we got our drinks...but if you're w/ good company, time flies.
author: Vivian W.

description: Great cup of Coffee! The line was very long waited 25 minutes! Not sure I'd wait that long again but what the hell. Cafe au lait, drip coffee excellent!
author: Rick F.

description:
This was my first spot having Blue Bottle and yes, I've even gone during Farmer's Market and waited in that ridiculous line just for some coffee...still worth it. Tourist and business people alike will line up on typical days, so be prepared. 

Their drips are a sight to watch, and their mocha's are a perfect blend when I want something sweet when opting not to get their waffle. New Orleans Ice Coffee was a nice alternative, but I tend to dump too much sugar to make my coffee sweeter. 

Their waffles though not stated is more like belgium/liege waffles, because it is more richer or denser with a candied or sweet taste. It's nice to eat when you have strong bold coffee and makes a perfect snack on the go. 

Blue bottle is the way to go, and I'm sure I will be back whenever I'm in the area.

P.S. Affogato is something I must try next time, two scoops of Humphrey Slocombe's ice cream topped off with a shot of espresso? This sounds amazing, especially if it's anything to Humphrey Slocombe's Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee Ice Cream =).
author: Casey L.

description:
My buddy and I were talking about the whole "artisan" movement--if it is even still a movement, as movement is classified as "stages", no?--and noticed how San Francisco has not needed to jump on this sort of grassroots food trend, as they have always been all about perfection in their goods, whether it be food, drink, or assorted edible goods.

So, along the topic of coffee, we discussed how beans come from all over the world, namely tropical climates and NOT anywhere specific in the US. Wouldn't it take eons to get workers out to the boondocks of Iowa just to pick some mediocre coffee beans?

Anyway, why do people all across the US seem to use coffee from California and Washington? Why, oh, why? Why not get them from a local roaster, wherever you are? Well, no one in your area finds it to be worth it, much less profitable! Alas, everyone gets their caffeine-laden beans from institutions that craft well and know how to make a business out of such a simple industry.

Alas, in comes Blue Bottle Coffee to top off the conversation--no pun intended on "top off." The overall summary of the story: Blue Bottle takes in beans from somewhere PAST Texas or New York... with California being farther from the point of origin than the aforementioned states. They roast, then distribute back TO those states. Why? Because they are boss at roasting up fine coffee. Isn't this "unsustainable", though? That certainly begs the question.
author: Solomon W.

description:
Coworkers swear by Blue Bottle, and when I confessed that the only BB I've had was at Boxed Foods Co, I was directed to several nearby (sorta) locations to rectify the matter.

Sadly, though the staff was super polite and friendly, the coffee was unimpressive.  It was also on the cold side (I was afraid to mention it to the staff, figuring they would roll their eyes and point to the chalkboard with carefully measured temperatures).

I'll try again at another location, but count me unimpressed so far.
author: dan s.

description:
I now understand why they have 2 windows running, and outrageously long lines!

At first I was to full to appreciate the iced coffee... but a quick trip down to Pier 39, and a bag of hot mini donuts, YUM!!! it was definitely a match made in heaven!

after the visit to the Ferry Building, I started seeing stands at the mall even... so, good to know there's more than one location... definitely on my must return list... right up there with the mini donuts!
author: Bernadette D.

description: I feel bad about this, but, each and every time I go here, the coffee is, well, it's just not HOT! It tastes good, but I don't want lukewarm coffee. I want HOT coffee. I understand it's because it's drip, but I just cannot wrap my tender taste-buds around lukewarm, albeit tasty, coffee.
author: Kevin F.

description: Great coffee and one of the best in SF.  The only reason I'm giving it four stars instead of five is because it is always busy and I've never had much time to interact with the baristas.  Overall though, one of my favorites in SF.
author: Johnathan W.

description: I refuse to stand in line for half an hour for their coffee, so next time I'll come back for their Affogato or Iced-coffee when their "other line" is open.  I was definitely not happy when they announced for the second consecutive time when I stepped in that line that the line was closed.  So minus 2 stars for service.
author: Caitlyn C.

description:
Good espresso, definitely the best I've had in SF, but my SF coffee crawling has been limited. Solid baristas with good latte-art skills. 

The line's a little long, but this location IS in the Ferry building, so I guess it's expected. 

I tried the New Orleans Iced Coffee, and maybe I'm missing something, but I really didn't think it was anything to write home about, although I'm more of an espresso drinker than anything else.
author: Caro D.

description:
My favorites here are the New Orleans iced coffee or a single origin cappucino. Cannot go wrong with anything here. Also a must order is their waffle!

Pretty packed on the weekends though, but I will wait even if the line want out the building! Pecking order wise, BB trumps all other spots in SF, including Ritual and Four Barrel.
author: Andy L.

description:
11.18.10

Every time I step foot in the Ferry Building, I must get Blue Bottle.  It's strong and flavorful, and each cup is made individually.

Yes, the lines are long, but if you have the time and don't have to rush back to work after lunch, it's well worth it.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Pretty long line...I enjoyed my latte, and the nice leaf design in the foam. The coffee is not bitter, it is smooth and the latte is caramelly soft.

This place keeps it simple with one size offering, and prices are slightly high. I didn't get their mocha, but it is $4.50 -- but I am sure it is worth the price as the chocolate they use is Recchiuti which is unbelievable chocolate!
author: Amy O.

description: Their coffee is really good.  Way better than Starbucks, Pete's, and other major coffee chains.  Their lattes are good; I really like their New Orleans iced coffee, I wish they offered a bigger size.  It was smooth and just delicious.
author: Sandy J.

description:
It's just sick how good the coffee is at Blue Bottle. Really unfair, especially the whole part where it's thousands of miles away from where I live in Brooklyn. Every last espresso drink I've ever tried from these guys over the last few years has been my new favorite. Maybe that makes me a hipster coffee snob. I'm okay with that.

The Ferry Building location has the distinct advantage of the palm-lined Embarcadero and all the benches overlooking the beauty of the Bay Bridge.  Grab a latte / mocha / whatever your pleasure and sit on the benches as the sun sets (or as you wait for your ferry home).

Get thee there for coffee nirvana!
author: Jill H.

description: I ordered the drip coffee. It was good, but not worth the price or the hype in my opinion. Just to put this in perspective, I love McDonald's coffee, I think it has great flavor and strength and is good enough to drink black. I wouldn't drink blue bottle without adding cream and sugar.
author: Maleenee B.

description: Waited about 15-20 min in the line. Got the Cappuccino and New Orleans Iced Coffee. I loved the cappuccino!!! The barista made a heart with the foam too. Very rich, creamy, and smooth. The New Orleans Iced Coffee everyone raves about is good - very smooth and creamy. Sort of like coffee ice cream in a cup. I would definitely come back! Its great coffee! The baristas are very friendly too and told me a story how her credit card company shut her credit card down because she forgot her billing zip code and tried re-entering it a few times during a checkout. hah!
author: Annie K.

description:
Gonna really disappoint the lovers of this place. Had a horrible experience this morning and had to write about it. Was busy, took way to long to get a cappucino, it was cold (probably due to the barristas constant chatter with each other) and the worst is yet to come. 

Ordered the waffle, which looked so good. Unfortunately, I never got it. After waiting longer than 15 minutes, it was clear they forgot my order and I asked about it. Was told it would be right up as I watched the kitchen help making and yes, eating waffles, my waffle in back.  At that point, I asked for a refund and got the cash quickly with no apology, comment or even acknowledgement that they goofed.

You can keep the trendies and toursists, I'll continue to go to Martha's and Philz where the coffee is hot, amazing and served by friendly staff.
author: phil b.

description: I've wondered what's the hype with Blue Bottle Coffee because there always seems to be a long queue. If you look at the menu, it's short and simply, unlike Starbucks. But a lot of times, our coffee are masked with flavourings and cream and caramel bits that we forgot what we were there for--the coffee. I ordered a macchiato and the coffee flavour was clearly front and centre. Robust and fragrant, it was complemented by velvety steamed Clover foam. All in all, an excellent mid-day pick-me-up.
author: Kwoky L.

description: Great coffee that's worth the daily 20-25 minute wait.  Food, service, and coffee is consistently good.  Great, and happy staff who take pride in their work.  Love this place and building they are located in.  Highly recommend!
author: Logan B.

description:
Already worshiped for their coffee, recommending our allegiance expands to their breakfast and dessert offerings too. Discovered their Belgium waffles are incredible, a cinnamon accented beauty that is big enough to be sliced into two. At only $3, it has one of the best ROWI (return on waffle investment) around.

Also unexpectedly fantastic was their fruit buckle, a dessert combining seasonal fruit, cake batter and a streusel topping. Looks like a muffin. Tastes delicious..

Granola was good but not as rave worthy, didn't matter, five star had already been achieved. Pair all this with a one of their signature coffees, and you've got something amazing.
author: Jason B.

description:
Best coffee in The city. 
Go to the manual espresso machine off to the left side of the place. 

Coffee 5
Service 5
Cleanliness 4
author: Foodie C.

description:
I noticed there was a nice line forming at the Blue Bottle Coffee and figured I try it out. It was worth the wait. My friend said to try it out and it'll be worth the wait. And boy was she right, it's one of the best cups of coffee I've had in a while. They grind your coffee on the spot and brew your coffee in a nice ceramic dripper cup filtering the awesomeness before it goes to your cup. 

It takes time to make a cup of masterpiece, that's why their lines get so long. They have two lines, the one on the left side is the best to go only if you want coffee since it rarely sees traffic. While the main one, you can purchase both food and coffee. 

I went to come back for another round of coffee, but that wait of 4-people ahead of me my first visit, tripled to 12-people, next time Blue Bottle... Can't wait to come back and experience coffee heaven again!
author: Ryan L.

description:
The best cup of coffee on earth.

I am a coffee fanatic and grew up in Portland,OR. preferring Coffee People over Peets and Starbucks and I traveled the world, from Johannesburg to Paris, trying different coffee blends. I was given a bag of Blue Bottle Coffee Co. whole beans by my sister years ago and could not believe how smooth and rich it was.  The roast was Bella Donovan and it was as smooth as a cup of Hawaiian Kona but with a more subtle, dark and complex taste. Masterpiece.  Now, I am working a couple blocks away from the Ferry Building and I love the ambiance and simplicity of the Blue Bottle coffee stand and its artisans taking the time to craft the perfect cup of joe.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Good coffee takes time.  Great coffee takes an eternity.  For Blue Bottle, I just might wait an eternity (or something like that).

If I'm ever in the area, I vow to always treat myself to a cup of Blue Bottle.

As for price, on the regular, I probably wouldn't do this everyday.
author: Rochelle D.

description: Coffee was good, but my issue was with the service.  The people working gave my husband a hard time when he asked if there was any vanilla flavoring for my iced latte.  We were met with an "Are you kidding me?" glance, and "We don't have flavors here, there's sugar over there if you want it..."  Sorry that I prefer vanilla flavoring in my brown liquid sludge...didn't know that made me a lesser human being.  Was also made aware that if I wanted cold brew coffee, I would have to have it with real milk instead of almond milk.  Come on Blue Bottle, what about us lactose averse customers who are willing and fully able to pay for your cold brew goodness, and could, gasp, pay extra, to have a non-dairy alternative.  We were also met with a blank stare when my husband ordered his coffee with whole milk instead of skim milk and JOKINGLY (and with a chuckle) asked, "Does anybody actually prefer the flavor of skim milk?".  Lose the pretension Blue Bottle.  Just because you brew a good cup of joe doesn't mean you can treat us corporate slaves (aka, Starbucks drinkers) like we are the gum on your shoe.
author: M F.

description: If you're a huge coffee drinker, this place has really good coffee! Amazing quality. Not too sweet or creamy--tastes just right.
author: Carmen T.

description: What sets this location apart from all the other ones, other than it being in the Ferry Building and swarmed with tourists, is that it serves an affogato. There is another window called the Secret Window located right around the corner on the other side, but the lines is just as long and the menus are just the same. The affogato is comprised of a shot of the daily espresso poured over TWO scoops of the Secret Breakfast flavor made by local ice creamery Humphery Slocombe. I had thought that it was only one scoop, but when I found out it was two, thought it was a pretty good deal for $5.50.
author: Jennifer W.

description: The best coffee ever! Worth the long lines. I hit this place every time I'm in the area. They drip brew each cup.
author: Nate M.

description:
Being a fan of coffee, I had to stop by Blue Bottle Coffee when I visited Ferry Building last week.

I realized that the menu was not overwhelming and quite generic (unlike Starbucks and etc) I decided to order a drip coffee. Nothing too crazy, yet the coffee was amazing! It had the perfect boldness with a slight tangy taste. 

Will definitely come back when I visit San Francisco again.
author: Wakana I.

description:
Dear Yelp Journal,

Let me tell you a story about how a great day with great people and great coffee starts...

"You're getting an iced coffee?"  I asked my friend.

"Yeah, it's good.  What're you going to get?"

"I don't know, I need something warm."  That's what I said anyway.  After having sparkling wine and loads of oysters at Hog Island, my group and I went over to blue bottle.  Shivering, I read the menu and one friend agreed that we needed something warm.  We read the menu and came upon the affogato.  Espresso with ice cream?  Who thought of such a genius combination?  Forget logic, forget what I had just said.  This "affogato" sounded intriguing.  I HAD to investigate.

"Go figure you would want the most expensive thing on the menu," fourth person remarked.  IGNORED!

After waiting about ten minutes (seriously, long wait), we reached the front, and I got to ask the barista if he recommended the affogato.  He said it was "delicious."  Sold, total order: an iced coffee, a mocha, and TWO affogatos (one for same friend that said she needed something warm).

When our order was delivered, the presentation wasn't the grandest, but all was compensated in flavor.  The affogatos came in paper bowls, two scoops of vanilla ice cream were popped in and rich espresso poured over them in front of our awe stricken eyes.  We grabbed spoons and took a dive.  The creamy ice cream balanced with the strong espresso danced upon our tongues, and as a coffee elitist, I was totally enchanted.  My co-affogato orderer took in a delighted breath after her first bite and we agreed with a nod that we had made the right decision.  

While I put lids on the mocha and ice coffee, a stranger from the end of the line approached my friend and asked, "What is that and where do I get it?"  We were officially the envy of the line.

Well, obviously, you get it right here, journal.  And that's how I started my great day with great people and some great coffee.
author: Wilson K.

description: Their coffee is magical. 6 out of 5! The best cappuccino I've ever tried. Staff is very nice as well!
author: Ksenya U.

description:
Decent coffee; poor service. There wasn't much of a line when I walked up, but it took them 10 minutes to make a cup of drip coffee.

As I waited, I had plenty of time to watch how the three women behind the counter went about their jobs. All three were very chatty amongst themselves, but that didn't seem to slow down the two making cappuccino and espresso. Unfortunately for me it was the third who was making drip coffee, between taking orders at the register.

She is not good at multitasking.

While waiting, I positioned myself right in front of her, hoping she'd see me, and that it would serve as a reminder of my half-poured coffee sitting idle behind her. She made eye contact once or twice, but apparently never did ask herself "why is that man still standing there?"

I finally let one of the other women know that I'd been waiting, and had coffee in hand 30 seconds later.

If I walk by again and see today's cashier behind the counter, I won't be stopping.
author: Rick F.

description: super long lines but worth the wait. I always get the latte! I really wish they would open up a location in the south bay!
author: Anna H.

description:
My quest for delicious coffee led me to try Blue Bottle Coffee. Luckily there is a location close to where I work. I walked to the Ferry Building before heading home and ordered a latte. 

When you first enter the ferry building, make a left and keep going towards the end. You will see BBC on your left hand side. 

The space is small, yet the layout is open so you don't feel crowded. 

I ordered the soy latte. The barista asked if I wanted something else. I hate being asked that because I start questioning myself. "do I want something else?" "should I get something else?" "are other people getting something else and am I going to be judged if I only get the latte?" so I asked the barista if they had vegan pastries. He suggested the arborio rice cake. It was baked in it's own mini cardboard loaf pan. So cute! I loved that when the barista handed it to me, he had placed it inside a coffee filter. It was a clever little detail and the filter doubles as a napkin. 

I can see what all the hype is about. The latte was so smooth and slightly sweet. It was pretty much perfect. I appreciated that it was ready to drink since I don't like waiting for my drinks to cool down. 

The arborio rice cake is unforgettable. I'm going to be telling my grandchildren about it- after the Alzheimer's kicks in this might be the only thing I'll tell them about. The cake is moist and sweet and firm but soft and perfectly cooked through. There are almonds in there too for a nice surprise (sorry for spoiling it for you). The best comparison I have is that it tastes like corn cake. Oh and there is a slight hint of lemon flavor in there too. 

Soy latte + vegan arborio rice cake was heavenly. 

Only thing that didn't leave a good taste in my mouth was that the cashier and the barista were carrying on a conversation and were speaking in code. It made me feel a little uncomfortable since I didn't know what they were talking about and felt a little like I was interrupting something.

I can't decide whether I liked it more than ritual coffee so my quest for the best cup will continue.
author: Daisy S.

description: Went in there first time with friends and loved the taste! Best latte I had since birth!
author: Kat H.

description:
The Ferry Building has many options for tasty treats, but not many options for coffee. Blue Bottle seems to be the most popular option so naturally it has the longest line. I had the time to wait, so why not I thought. It must be good.

The line took forever! But the coffee was pretty good and the girls working there were so friendly! They were so sweet that by the time my impatient self got to the front of the line, my irritation dissipated. They were THAT friendly!

The coffee takes a little bit of time because they are all dripped with care and finished off with cute little coffee art in the foam.

It's a long wait, but worth it if you have the time.
author: Carol S.

description: I thought it would be silly to wait in line for 40 minutes for coffee but I couldn't help but want a pick-me-upper after a delicious porchetta sandwich from the Roli Roti. Oh Boy was I happy we grabbed some coffee! The coffee there was strong and delicious! I ordered the iced latte and I must say it was def worth the wait!
author: elizabeth t.

description:
I'm not a coffee nut, so I can't judge properly, but I do know that I love the latte and that a lot of other lattes pale in comparison.

PROS:
+ Simple menu.
+ The latte is absolutely amazing.
+ Friendly staff who are patient and willing to help you decide.
+ Nice foam art based on who makes your drink.

CONS:
- At the Ferry building lines can get pretty long, so be ready to wait.

NEUTRAL:
- Prices are average.
author: Shamim I.

description: Went there for my first time, by a freinds reccomendation. Coffee turned to ART. I had a waffle and a drip coffee. It was off the hook, best yet. Starbucks watch out, something new in town. Does take a while since they have lots of people waiting, but worth the experience.
author: Lex L.

description:
Seriously...what's the hype???  My latte could have been made at Starbucks or Peets.  I think people have been brainwashed because of the notorious lines.

Ferry Bldg is totally pet friendly so at least you can enjoy that over-hyped joe with your pup.
author: Kim W.

description: Overrated, my espresso was really short and way to bitter. I had such high expectations but was not satisfied. There are better places for coffee in SF
author: Jonas K.

description: The New Orleans Iced coffee was amaz-ballz.  I'm a fan of great coffee and this place is the real deal.
author: Tina C.

description:
I'm kicking Peet's out of my bed and dumping him for Blue Bottle.

They say the best things in life are worth waiting for, and by golly, whoever 'they' are wasn't kidding!

I stood in line for about 15 minutes - while standing in line, I wavered on what I would order about a million times...standard drip, New Orleans Iced Coffee, espresso, macchiato, latte, OOOOOOOH....affogato with Humphrey Slocombe ice cream....WHAT DO I WANNNNTTT????

Finally, when I got to the counter, I settled on a macchiato for me and a drip for the BF.

When I finally received my little cup up heaven, I knew from then on Blue Bottle had ruined me.
