Truly worth waiting for! There was even a heart on the decadent crema and milk, just for me. A heart!
author: Christy L.

description: It's hard to say if the hype is really justified because there's really just so much of it but you can't knock the taste. Blue bottle coffee is really good. That being said I prefer Philz
author: Misha T.

description:
Um, can anyone recommend to me what I was suppose to try? I had the macchiato. Served like an espresso, it wasn't memorable, but what the heck do I know of coffee? 

I don't even drink it as much anymore. I want to taste this "best coffee" as highly recommended by many I know.  This is very short and sweet, but I do want to try out what is said to be out the door and around the corner, "its THAT good" coffee.
author: Jamie L.

description:
I love their coffee. Tried their New Orleans Ice Coffee a couple times and like it every single time, it's not too sweet and has a chicory taste to it (at least i think that's what it is). Would probably ask them to add less ice next time though. Also, a little pricey for the size. 

I also really like their caramelized waffle...so delicious! If you haven't gotten it before you should definitely try it (comes in coffee filter). Lines at the Ferry building on the weekends are long, but they have 2 windows inside the building and one booth outside.
 
They also had cute tote bags with the blue bottle counter and the ferry building art on it last time I went (in December) and are priced reasonably ($12 dollars?) but the coffee filter sold there was very expensive...would not get it from there.
author: Whitney W.

description: Eh. We ended up here twice on our trip. Iced coffee is good but I didn't see anything but 2% milk and sugar to doll up my drink. Cold Brew was just ok. Long line and lots of fuss but not sure what over...
author: Jaime K.

description: BB's espresso drinks are as good as it gets. Drip coffee? I'm a Peets guy. The lines are annoying.
author: Michael S.

description: Line is always looooooooooooooong ~ 15 people, but here you can pick up fresh dripped coffee, new orleans iced coffee( sort of intense like a vietnamese one), waffles, and best of gadgets - made in Japan $100+ vintage coffee makers or pick the ceramic dripper for cheap. There's a small metal counter in front of the espresso machine for just 4 people. I  had a great time chatting with people. Once I saw a lady with the same rare wallet as I do. We passionately chatted for like 10 minutes... i know, girls can talk
author: Dilys S.

description:
SF is making me a coffee addict.

I went to the farmer's market on Saturday morning, stood in line here.  The line took a little while since they only have one register open. I got an affogato and my friend got an iced coffee.  The iced coffee is made New Orleans style, which the cute barista very nicely explained is coffee mixed with chicory and milk, and kept overnight.    

My friend and I decided to share a waffle, because it looked so delicious.  The waffle took a little too long, so we found ourselves a spot to sit, and I asked the Barista to wave for me to come get it once it was ready, which he did.  

Overall, I was really happy with the coffee and the service.
author: Anoo L.

description: My first cup of coffee in SF and haven't met anything close to it yet. I'm lucky I was able to stumble across this place. The cappuccino I had  was almost perfection. The servers were extremely helpful and friendly and it made the experience even better. 5 for blue!
author: Sam S.

description: This was probably the best MOCHA I have ever had.  Not only was the artistic touch made it difficult to drink it because my wife was attempting to take several photos of it, but I had to buy a second because one taste was enough to enact a veto on SHARING the hot beverage.  There is also a little bakery on the side of this place that does not disappoint.
author: Jason H.

description: What a cute little coffee place on Embarcadero! Absolutely didn't know this was here - their cappuccino's are divine and the service is great! Quick and with flair! It was just my first time ordering from here but it looks like it definitely gets busy and the regulars definitely keep coming back. Yup! Picked my new favorite cappucino spot 8)
author: Marevie T.

description: Have to admit: don't like coffee and didn't have any here (okay, that's a lie...I had a sip of my friends, but I don't like coffee, remember?).  Still, my friend wouldn't shut up about her cup, and the line probably speaks for itself.  I talked to the counter worker a bit, trying to finagle an iced chocolate out of her.  They couldn't do it because they said it just freezes into a solid bar since they use real chocolate.  Oh well.  Meanwhile, they had lots of cool things for me to look at in line.  Their foam art is good, people are friendly, and they use good stuff.  It's too bad I don't like coffee...thumbs up anyways.
author: Brian B.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee serves up a simple menu of fresh, delicious espresso drinks, drip coffee, and iced coffee alongside an assortment of baked goods and breakfast items.  

Yes, yes, at Blue Bottle, coffee isn't just coffee -- it's made with certified organic, sustainably farmed, non-child labor, green, solar, non-animal tested, fair trade (and any other over-used PC terms that you like) beans.  And, sure, the coffee is good, but what I don't get is why people are willing to patiently wait 30 minutes or more for it.  

Hey, it's good, but not that good.
author: CJ G.

description: Waited in a long line for average coffee.. Hoping it was something like philz being that the brew each cup for you and all that.. The long line probably made the experience worse coz expectations are built while waiting half hour or so for your coffee..the coffeefoam art is cute tho.. But the whole time drinking their coffee i was dreaming of a jacobs wonderbar from Philz...
author: Richard V.

description: I don't drink coffee, but I did wait in a 20 minute line to devour the MOST MIND BLOWING Caramelized 'Belgian Style' Liege Waffle EVER!! And I walked from our apartment there, which was about 30 minutes.. yes, I would do it all over again.
author: Abigail W.

description:
Starbucks couldn't do it.  Peet's Coffee couldn't either.  Blue Bottle Coffee Co. however, finally accomplished making me crave coffee every morning.  

If there comes a time when I start to make one billion dollars a minute, I would like to put a Blue Bottle Coffee Co. in my apartment.   It would be a great setup.  Bronze cougars on both sides of the coffee stand that would also be fountains pouring fresh brewed Blue Bottle Coffee.  27 people on staff working full time.  Eleven ninjas standing by for security and the occasional "joke of the day" and conversation. So why would I still live in an apartment if I was a bazillionaire? I have no idea.  

Basically the only important information needed in this review is the star rating and the first paragraph.  But I just had a delicious Blue Bottle New Orleans Iced Coffee and I kept typing.
author: John R.

description:
New Orleans Iced Coffee. Perfect refreshment on a hot day. This was pretty bomb. Creamy, but nutty coffee, kind of reminds me a bit of Philz. 

DAMN GOOD! AND WORTH IT!

FYI: For you lactose intolerant kids like myself, soy doesn't cost extra!
author: Constance C.

description: I don't get what the hype is about.  I've been here twice and both times, it's been sub-optimal.  I like to try the coffee black first to give you a real idea of what you're getting.  For me, the coffee was bitter/acidic and generally wasn't good.  Even after adding sugar/cream didn't make it appreciably better than what you would get from Starbucks.  Overall, it was pretty disappointing (especially after waiting in line for a little while).  B2 Coffee in San Jose is much better IMO if you ever get a chance to be in the south bay.
author: Rob Y.

description: I went there just to go there and it was pretty good. I went to the one in the Ferry building which was really crowded, so maybe my only downfall.
author: Scott P.

description:
You already know Blue Bottle is delicious - this review speaks to the sometimes nightmarish experience of actually getting a coffee at this location.

1. While the "secret window line" USED to be faster, as toursits assumed it was cash-only, this is no longer the case. AVOID THE WINDOW LINE unless there are only 2 people in line. It will always look shorter than the mainline, but as there is only one person doing every order and manning the cashier simultaneously, it is unbelievably slow. 

2. Therefore, always rely on the real line. No, it won't be fast, but it will be worth it, and it has one thing going for it: it's faster than the other line. However, BEWARE line cutters. Almost every time I have stood in the line I have witnessed people cutting - some have been completely shameless. I guess it is a testament to how good this coffee is that it turns people into conniving line-cutters, but seriously, watch out. That hippie with a market bag? She's going to cut you.
author: Orla Rose B.

description: Many people say that society runs on oil, I would argue society will collapse if we don't have coffee for more then 48 hours. Blue Bottle coffee is among the top coffee shops in the Bay Area, with the right roasting that will unlock the subtle taste of coffee that many will not noticed if they stick with starbucks or peets coffee. After trying blue bottle, you will be inadvertently on the war path (regardless if you like it or not ) for good coffee with everything that is not higher then blue bottle tasting bitter or just doesn't unlock that stimulus it provides. The price of blue bottle is either similar to their competitors or just a little above it.  However it is will worth the cost as the quality of good coffee can make or break an office day. Especially if you have a TPS report to submit and your boss decided that you should redo it from scratch because "why not and to check for any discrepancy "
author: Gerard F.

description:
Need a caffeine fix? Or even if you don't need one, go to Blue Bottle! You'll thank me later. The lines are extremely long, but worth the wait! My favorite past-time while waiting is people watch- and it so happens that every time there has been quite a few guys worth looking at :). The first few times I was I've always ordered the drip coffee because it made me feel special that they individually made it just for me. But on a hot hot day in SF, I decided to venture out of my comfort zone and try the New Orleans Iced Coffee that everyone raves about and boy am I glad I did! The overnight brewed chicory coffee is HEAVEN IN MY MOUTH! Just thinking about it makes me drool... it's nutty and creamy and OH SO DIVINE. I usually get fat free milk with my drip but don't skimp on this one! WHOLE MILK is the way to go! Trust me, order it and you won't regret it.

Hate to say this, but Blue Bottle's New Orleans Iced Coffee is better than Philz's Mint Mojito Iced Coffee :X (and I love Philz too!)
author: Jessie C.

description:
Located at the Ferry Building, it gets really crowded and the lines are pretty long. Don't get me wrong, the coffee and service are excellent, but the experience of waiting in line kind of ruins the experience. 

Nevertheless, it is worth to try!
author: Mitch W.

description: The coffee is amazing, but plus the way it's served it's becoming a nice treat of the day! Starbucks and Pete's will never have espresso like this!
author: Zara D.

description: I could be a fan but the long long line and waiting  is preventing me from being one.  I don't like wasting time for a cup of coffee.  But then again, waiting in line for this and   waiting in line for coffee at Starbucks ... BBBC wins of course.
author: Cj P.

description: Get. The. Waffle. Please get the waffle. I was only able to eat one while I was in San Francisco and I still think about it almost every day. It was the most perfect, warm, crispy, hand-held, served in a coffee filter treat I have ever had. And the coffee was great, too. But, oh, that waffle!!!
author: Amy E.

description:
Oh wee... It's been about two months since my first visit, and I could still taste their Affogato and New Orleans Style Iced Coffee.

If you've never had an Affogato before, prepare to have every Affogato from anywhere else RUINED. This place definitely did it for me, but I'm glad that it did! Essentially, you get two scoops of Humphrey Slocombe's Honey Ice Cream that gets topped with Blue Bottle's Espresso. It's so strange... as the Espresso meets the cold ice cream, it creates a barrier-like force field of deliciousness that surrounds it with each bite. Humphrey Slocombe's rich & creamy textured ice cream when paired with the Affogato is something out of this world! Don't be shy and scoop more of that Espresso from on the bottom to the top of your ice cream.... This... drink? Nah, BEAUTY... is something that you should try at least once when you come here!

Their New Orleans Iced Coffee has a rich, smooth taste, and shouldn't be taken lightly for an iced coffee. Because it's so strong already, adding any extra sugar would definitely send you flying across the room. The beautiful aroma comes from using chicory, which is a woody plant. Cold-press this bad boy (or girl), and you've got yourself a fantastic drink!

Be prepared to wait in line for a little bit. Talk to your neighbors, or bring someone with you, because it might take a little while.
author: Patrick K.

description: Great coffee, nice staff... I got the basic coffee, nothing fancy and it tasked great, very well balanced... no complaints here. And just a few doors down, you can get some salted pig parts :)
author: Steve S.

description: I love blue bottle coffee co. They make a great regular cup of coffee or iced coffee. However, the mocha is to DIE for. It is almost impossible not to get one if I walk by and there is no line. Unfortunately, this location almost always has a huge line on the weekends. Though I do love that this location is in the ferry building and very convenient if your in the area it is not my favorite blue bottle location as it is smaller and usually has a long line.
author: Samar N.

description: If you love coffee, then you go to blue bottle. What more do I need to say :)
author: Mia S.

description: The soy mocha I had here was perhaps the best I've ever had. The service was fast, the presentation was flawless, and the coffee and chocolate were perfectly balanced.
author: Richard B.

description: Don't be fooled by the line. It moves fairly quickly. I tried the New Orleans Iced Coffee during my very short visit to SF. It lives up to the hype and I miss it so badly right now (as I'm sipping this sad substitute - Starbucks Iced Coffee instead).  And if you're a tourist/newbie to Blue Bottle and can't decide between visiting Blue Bottle or Philz....pick Blue Bottle. :)
author: Kristin C.

description: I've tasted many of the new coffee trends, Blue Bottle Coffee is by far the better tasting coffee that is worth trying.  Their water is silkier in texture and the coffee just tastes better. It can be expensive cup, but I like to treat myself a couple times a week whenever I am around their place in the Ferry Building.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Lord, this is the best coffee I've ever tasted and probably one the reasons I'll stay in San Francisco for the time being.
I've tried the gamut of the coffees the city has to offer and I ALWAYS go back to Blue Bottle. My favorites are the Bella Donovan and Three Africans, which we either make in a French Press or Chemex at home.
I usually grab a bag of the freshly roasted beans (check for the date on the back) and you can skip the line if your'e not buying a beverage. 

We love Blue Bottle so much we ordered pounds of it from their online store and divvied it up into tiny little bags as wedding favors for something a little different and a taste of the Bay area. Everyone loved it. Amen.
author: Lisa K.

description:
This was probably the most amazing latte I've ever had in my life.

When I first stepped foot in the Ferry Market building, I could smell the scent of coffee in the air. Of course, it's because we entered right by the Blue Bottle Coffee Co.  I saw people sitting around and ordering their drinks, and my first thought was "wow those are small cups".  I'd become used to the larger drink sizes offered by most of the chain coffee shops.  Regardless, I wanted to give the place a try because a quick yelp check showed that there were lots of reviews.  

The first clue I got that the baristas here took coffee seriously was the care and effort they took in making just the drip coffee. Instead of asking who was ordering lattes, they asked who was in line to get drip coffee. Each cup is prepared individually with their own filter and grinds.  I got a regular latte, mainly because I wanted the cool latte art.

When I got my drink (made with whole milk unless otherwise told), I was a little disappointed in the small cup. However, one sip and I didn't care. This was an AMAZING cup of coffee. Period. The latte was incredibly smooth; none of that burnt tasting crud you'd get at other coffee places.  The whole milk also made the entire drink extremely filling.  While drinking the latte, I was careful to not mar the design on the top because it was just so cute.  I also had some of the drip coffee which was very robust and rich.  The closest I've had to coffee like that is the French press coffee from Griddle Cafe in LA.

One latte and one drip coffee cost $6.
author: Janet P.

description: I love it here. Their lattes are absolute perfection. They also have friendly baristas and I love watching them meticulously craft each cup with such care.
author: Suzannae L.

description:
The amazing Artists... And yes, I do mean Artists at this paradise.  What fun!  I thought I was just going to grab a cup of
Coffee before boarding the ferry to Napa.  What an experience this was.  Thank you for the delicious coffee and the waffle is a must!
author: Jody W.

description:
Wow. The mocha is really GOOD. I like a mocha where you can actually taste the chocolate. I usually have to fix it up quite a bit to get it right. I don't have to do anything with the mocha here.

Also? The Belgian waffle is totally worth the wait!! Now having said that I wish that they would create a separate line for people who just want to buy food and not coffee because I've been wanting to try this waffle for weeks and the line always made me change my mind. I'm so glad I finally got to try it one early Saturday. Hot off the iron, it's crisp, slightly sweet and just perfect.
author: cyndi L.

description:
I dream of your coffee.

New Orlean's style iced coffee - Doesn't get much better than this. I'll drive an hour and 45 minutes and the first place I want to go when I get to San Francisco is this wonderful little spot.
author: Shelley A.

description: Secret window! Obsessed with the New Orleans iced coffee. Their coffee is not that expensive, it's about the same price as starbucks, and Blue Bottle doesn't have that burnt taste. Hint: you can get the new orleans iced coffee in haight at one of the market/stores, for the same price and it's in a bigger cup!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Amazingggggg coffee. Some mornings I feel like nothing brings me more joy than a hot and frothy freshly pulled Blue Bottle mocha. Since the price is a little splurgy, I've taken it upon myself to perfect this creation in my own home using the Hayes Valley espresso, which is surprisingly forgiving on a stovetop Italian espresso maker, and Tcho chocolate shavings from down the Embarcadero.

Blue Bottle is number one fish in my book for espresso from a sea of Four Barrel, Sightglass, Barefoot, Philz, and Ritual. More flavors of iced coffee and more consistency in drink quality amongst baristas would push them even further over the top.
author: Claire C.

description:
Let me start by saying that I'm not a coffee person. 
(In fact coffee acted as a sleeping pill when I took them in my futile efforts to stay awake during my college years).  Also I'm not big on drinking hot stuff cos I am clumsy enough to burn my tongue every time which basically takes away my joy of eating for half a day at least. 

Since Blue Bottle Coffee was so widely raved about by people, and since I had a guest visiting from out of town, I thought I'd check out this supposedly amazing coffee establishment.

Line was long on a Sunday afternoon.  

I had their New Orleans Iced Coffee...and BOY BOY was it amazing. 

It was strong but not bitter. It was full of flavour and not watered down. 

It also totally kept me alert ..(for a few hours anyway).

Since my blue bottle experience, I have fallen in love with caffeine and iced coffee.  Since I live and work in the peninsula, I had to try other available alternatives.

Peet's iced coffee - they call this iced coffee? NASTY NASTY!
Starbucks Clover Iced Coffee(I've tried Starbucks anniversary blend & Iced Kenya) - they were not drinkable without milk and sugar but with milk and sugar actually comparable to Blue Bottle in its fullness & flavour.  

I haven't tried Starbucks' drip coffee iced coffee so I can't comment. 

If I'm in the city, I'll definitely come grab myself a Blue Bottle. I've been told Philz is also really good.  Wait for my update!
author: Sujan H.

description: Who doesn't like amazing coffee and out of this world affogato?  Blue Bottle Coffee is one of the best coffees I've ever had even the ones I've had in Italy.
author: Erika S.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee has become my obsession.  I've bookmarked every location on my Yelp app, just so I can find the closest one whenever I'm in San Francisco or Oakland.  Now as to why it's obsession, it's the best coffee I've ever had.  I usually go for a Gibraltar here, so I can have more coffee, less milk, than a latte.  I love coffee, but these days I can't drink much, due to the acidic nature upsetting my stomach, but with Blue Bottle I don't have to worry about it, very low acid makes for a very happy tummy.  Add in a delicious flavor and I'm all set.  

There is almost always a line, but this location is set on a corner of a hallway in the Ferry Building, so they have 2 lines, one on each side, to make getting your coffee fix easier. 

Since I live in the South Bay and can't drive up to the city daily to get my fix, I order the beans online so I can make my own delicious cup of coffee at work every day.
author: Crystal B.

description: I'll confess, I'm not much of a coffee drinker. But who am I to refuse free coffee, particularly the kind from Blue Bottle? Made use of my $5 gift card by ordering a caffe latte, which I had ordered at one of their other locations a while back. Love how they make such pretty designs on it. Makes you not want to drink it, almost. Since it's inside of the Ferry Building, there's always a line. However, it does tend to move rather quickly.
author: Rhia R.

description:
Same awesome coffee/lattes as their other locations.

Amazing pastries, too!

But wait! What's that? FRIENDLY service!!

Such a pleasant experience overall that I'd give this Blue Bottle 10 stars if I could.
author: Tiffinie T.

description: Best latte I have ever had.  Amazing high quality biscuits.  At first I was nervous about this waffle everyone talks about due to receiving it super hot and fresh which seem a tad soggy. Once I was able to actually eat it, it cooled down enough to crisp up the outside and kept the inside sweet and soft.  Walking around the Ferry building, looking at all the amazing vendors products during the farmers market, doesn't get much better then that.
author: Erik K.

description:
I love blue bottle. I love this coffee. There is NOTHING better than getting your java fix and then catching a view of the bay or people watching in the Ferry building. 

So amazingly good, worth every penny.
author: Hilda Z.

description: Such a fan of BBC!  The customer service partnered with high quality coffee is hands down the best you can get.  This location in particular, I must give extra kudos to because they are always slammed with customers and tourists.  I've noticed on numerous occasions that they take the time to explain the drinks to newbies, make recommendations, or even keep that smile on their face to keep the positive vibes going.  Well done BBC!
author: Meryl P.

description: The coffee was typical overpriced coffee. I'm not totally sure it was worth the lengthy wait, but I needed a caffeine fix, so what can you do. There are actually 2 lines for this 1 location which was a little confusing. And at least for the farmers market on Saturdays, there's also a mobile stand set up outside. I would go again if I happened to be near a Blue Bottle, but definitely wouldn't make it a destination.
author: Cory U.

description: The line is not so long as in Peet's and Starbucks on California, and the coffee is way better.
author: Nadia C.

description: Some of the best coffee ever. Long lines are common. Prices are high. Worth it once in a while.
author: David P.

description: My SF friend is my coffee place guide in the city. He suggest Blue Bottle Coffee in downtown and I know why people are queuing for so long! Each cup is prepared with a lot of love. No "what size?" "what syrup?" kind of questions. Short but effective coffee list and few nice baked treat on top. And since I am a mocha fan I have tried it too and I am very satisfied with it.
author: Nathalie H.

description: Great coffee! I came on a Friday around 3:45pm and waited maybe 10 minutes max in line (it looked long, but moved quickly). I got the iced coffee with whole milk (what they reco) and it was very smooth!
author: Mary G.

description:
So, you've come for a cup of coffee with a couple friends before/during/after your trip to the Saturday morning farmer's market and you see a long line. A seriously long line. And the first question that pops in to your head is,

"How long is this line REALLY going to take?"

Don't you wish someone had some data on how long the line actually takes, given that you have 18 groups in front of you? Well, you data junkie, you supposedly cool-cat with a secret statistics fetish*, here's your satisfaction.

I made it through the line last Saturday just after 8am. I took out my iPhone. Unlike the other people on their iPhones (if you are in line reading this on your iPhone---ahem---take a look around; you are in good company), I decided to do something useful for everyone. I busted out my stopwatch app.

So, without further ado, the wait time: on average, a group gets through the line every 1 minute and 21 seconds.  

This is the time from when a group arrives at the front of the line to when they walk away with the receipt. I've got 18 data points, and the standard deviation (oh, you nerds are getting excited now, aren't you) is 31.4 seconds.  

So, you want to know about how long it is going to take you to get through the line? Well, count the number of groups. I don't mean individuals; people usually order as a group, you keen observer of human nature. So take a minute (you'll have plenty of time) and see who is socializing, holding hands, making out, etc. These are groups. 

Take the number of groups and multiply it by 1.35. That is your approximate wait time on a Saturday morning, in minutes. If you can't do that in your head, your phone has a calculator---now is the time to use it.

But why not multiply by 1.21? Because that is wrong. Take a deep breath if you made this mistake---you haven't had your coffee yet---1.21 minutes is 1 minute and 13 seconds, not 1 minute and 21 seconds.

A couple caveats.  First, they hadn't opened the secret window yet. I have no idea how this affects the wait time. Second, I've only timed the wait once and (obviously) they could have been particularly fast or slow that day. 

As your financial advisor is fond of saying, past performance does not guarantee future results.

(Oh, and for the record, the coffee is really good, and worth even a 30-minute wait. They lose 1/2 point because it isn't the best cup I've had and 1/2 point because of the ridiculous wait.)

(*) 1 in 7 have it. You like that, don't you.
author: Mike M.

description: Very, Very long line, but,  very, very good coffee.  I had a latte, and will be back in line again soon, for another latte. So should you.
author: Winny S.

description: I've been to Blue Bottle a few times, having had their mocha's and latte's.   The quality of the coffee is good.  However, you'll always find a line.  At the ferry building farmers market, they have a few booths setup to spread the traffic.  The major chains could take a note or two from Blue Bottle's attention to detail.  Prices are reasonable for what you're getting.   Whenever I'm nearby, I won't hesitate to drop by Blue Bottle for my caffeine fix!
author: Albert L.

description:
After waiting for nearly 20 minutes to get my Drip Coffee in the morning, they certainly did not disappoint.  Every time I get coffee from a specialty store, I drink it black to really taste the flavor.  And this one was very good.  

But I wouldn't wait this long to grab a cup of Joe if I was on my way to work in the morning.
author: John C.

description:
Two different lines and both long, but, well worth the wait.
The pour over coffee served was smooth and delicious.
Great Coffee!
author: Alejandro G.

description: Well, I must say their coffee is worth the wait! Why?? Because we got it free! Yes! While standing in line, one of the baristas kindly handed us a mug with a note that said, "LAST CUSTOMERS-FOR REALZ"! Such responsibility, but it was all worth it in the end! The mocha was superb and we even got snicker doodles! 5 very enthusiastic thumbs up!
author: Kevin C.

description:
3.75/5 damn strong.

for those long days, or those frustrating ones when you just need a farther walk away from the desk, i come here. the iced coffee is deep, and seems to be stronger than others out there. i always come back to my desk wired and ready to pound out the rest of the afternoon into the evening.
author: Alvin D.

description:
we came around 830 am on a rainy saturday. the line was about 10 people deep and a 20 minute wait from start to sip. 

if you're reading this, chances are you already know what blue bottle is about. you know about the pour-over individual drip coffee, the cappuccino or latte offerings (one size, no flavoring such as vanilla, there IS soy option, ~$3.75), so i'll just say that while it isn't the strongest espresso i've had by any means, it is good. i don't know if i'd ever wait an hour or go to great amazing lengths to get it, but it's good. 

they have these thick belgian, iron-press waffles that come out buttery and pipping hot ($3). they're quite delicious, though missing the sugar pearls in each bite that make yeasty belgian waffles so oh-la-la. 

and along with the good looking, skinny, slightly detached men they have manning the counter, there are also other yummy offerings such as cookies, muffins, and other pastries of the sort. 

oh, i believe it's cash only..?
author: Melissa N.

description:
I usually get my latte wherever I go. This is how I compare among the different coffee places. My only complaint is the temperature of the coffee when I get it. It's not really hot enough for me and it's just below the drinking temperature. I like the first sip you take when it's full of flavor and silky goodness.

The latte itself was pretty good, pretty smooth.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Awesome Coffee, and average customer service. Although I ordered and tipped, I never got a "Thank You". I still recommend the product and experience.
author: Michael S.

description: hit the secret window and you're golden ;) well somewhat you may have a 15min wait instead of 30min wait :) Great lattes
author: Candace L.

description:
one of a kind coffee atmosphere. there are a bunch of people queuing up in the line for amazing coffee. what I like about this particular place is that it amazes me how they make their coffee under this cool foamy filter where a barista pours around so gracefully with super garnished silver coffee pot, then drips down to a white coffee mug. this part fascinates me because it's so different from just a coffee machine, it's handmade COFFEE! 

great variety of coffee beans if you like to brew them at home. oh, they don't do coffee grinding here as we already asked. awesome beach themed coffee.
author: Jan P.

description:
good coffee, loooooong lines. even at random times on random days there is a significant line in this ferry building location. 

i had the new orleans ice coffee which was really tasty. everyone around me was ordering the waffle and it was so tempting, but i passed. assume it was good though!
author: Christina H.

description: Solid 4. Cafe Mocha was just the right amount of sweetness (meaning more coffee and chocolate than sugar!) The Waffle was scrumdiddliumptous - a must have. Will definitely have to get this again when I am in the area. Suggests BBC open a location in LA - preferably in Fox Hills Mall near my work!
author: Wendy Y.

description:
The Product: One of the best cups of coffee I've ever tasted, though not by much (a cafe in Seattle called Migliore's still has my heart); and yes, I've tried many different kinds of coffee. I take my coffee as it is handed to me (no cream, no sugar, or rarely a little soy). Blue Bottle's coffee has a variety of blends, and at this location you need to go to the side window for the wider coffee selection. I suggest tasting it black before putting in any milk, cream, or sugar.

The Venue: It's next to the ocean, so drinking your cup of coffee there, I think, changes the flavor. Sipping on coffee and breathing in the ocean air makes this coffee more an experience than just your afternoon caffeine. Beware of long lines and lack of "cafe-style" seating.

Overall: Everything is great except there isn't really a place to sit and maybe read the paper. I understand Blue Bottle is a place where you grab your coffee and go on your lunch break, but if that's the philosophy, then why isn't the "grabbing" process expedited? If there were more seating, or if the serving process were faster than 10, 15, 20 minutes, then I'd give it 5 stars. Til then, it's a solid 4/5 stars.
author: Gun-Ik P.

description:
Just tried Blue Bottle Coffee after hearing about the buzz from a few friends. I tried the New Orleans iced coffee and a couple pastries. While I thought the coffee I had was good I didn't think it was anything amazing. I was actually disappointed by the fact that they serve the iced coffee in a hot coffee cup and didn't have any straws. 

It was a little pricey as well, I paid $11 for an iced coffee, lemonade, and 2 mini pastries. 

I saw a couple of cappuccino's being made and they looked amazing, almost like artwork. I will be sure to try one of those on my return visit.
author: Michael C.

description: So I don't drink coffee but man the affogato is amazing!  I think I can start consuming it if it was in affogato form.  Friend ordered it cause she told me it's a must try.  So we ordered that and a waffle.  So of course being the little piggie I am, I decided to put my waffle in the affogato also.  Wow.... this should be a sin to eat... def going to try and do this at home since san fran is a little to far from me haha.
author: Lizzie C.

description:
This is going to be short and simple...

Really good coffee.  The cappuccino and the macchiato are highlights.  When I'm in SF, I make it a point to take some time, visit this location or the kiosk, order a cup, and enjoy my coffee at a leisurely pace.  There is never a need to rush this coffee experience.

The only drawback for me is that the staff can sometimes be a little less than friendly at first, but they warm up to you after a while.  Oh, and the lines.  Just be patient.  :)
author: Danielle P.

description:
Im a coffee snob (i DO come from Seattle).  I love drip and this places drip coffee is amazing.  A-M-A-Z-I-N-G-ly smooth.  The coffee is fresh and they take their time to make sure that it is well made.

The lines get crazy long but totally worth the wait for this craft coffee.
author: Curtis C.

description: It was only a matter of time before I would finally take the plunge and wait in a long line for some Blue Bottle Coffee.  The line wasn't too long today.  I think I must've waited like 10-12 mins before I finally made it to the cashier.  The weather was pretty warm today, so I opted to try their New Orleans Iced Coffee.  So was it worth the long line?  I'd say yes because for one thing, it didn't long for them to make, and the other thing was that it tasted really good!  For me, really good coffee is when you don't have to add anything to it.  Even though the N.O. Iced Coffee had cream in it, it wasn't super sweet and I'm glad that I didn't have to add any sugar to it.  Or maybe I just didn't see them add sweetener to it.  Either way, I really enjoyed drinking it.  I will most likely be drinking another cup from them in the near future!
author: Rodney H.

description: I've been going to this Blue Bottle location about twice a month for over a year. I get a latte and a shortbread. Consistency is important to me. My latte always tastes the same and is always the same temperature. My shortbread is always tasty. The customer service is always perfect and they are super helpful.  They are awesome!
author: 13E ..

description:
THIS IS NOT A REVIEW OF BLUE BOTTLE - I love Blue Bottle

This is a review of the process and experience of getting a cup of coffee at this location. They just don't get it. The coffee is watered down and takes forever to get. 

Blue Bottle drip coffee is a strong rich cup of coffee. That's one reason they only sell one size. The Ferry Building coffee is like drinking Coors Light when you're expecting Guinness. 

Also the service is horribly slow. When the line is 20 people deep, they act like the 1st person in line is the only one standing there. MOVE FASTER!!!

I RECOMMEND GOING TO THE BLUE BOTTLE STATION OUTSIDE ON FARMER'S MARKET DAYS. Such a better product even though they claim the same process.
author: Brian P.

description:
I'm hardcore when it comes to coffee, and there are a few places that make killer coffee that doesn't require all the cream/sugar fixings. Regular drip coffee, it was aromatic and delisch (bitter as fk!) ~ exactly what everybody else says! Now I know what all the rave is about. Hands down the best cuppa black coffee I've ever had!

Downside but not really: wait time for 2 coffees was about 10 min. Worth it, don't care!  
 
And loooove that it's in the Ferry Building!
author: Shiki W.

description:
My friends love their coffee and so do I. I have had good coffee in far away places--Italy and France and Vienna have great stuff-- and this stuff competes, like other bay area gems, oh how proud I am of my home towns, Blue Bottle Earns the right to delight your coffee fixing dream.
-
oh, they did accidentally cancel a huge order for small bags of roasted beans as gifts for our friend's wedding attendees, then had to rush and fill the order at the last second, which they did just in time and the beans were so fresh I smelled the beans all during the dinner as the aroma filled the air.
author: mickey l.

description: Another go to place while in SF. A delicious cup of joe and tasty waffle is worth the wait. The waffles are big, so my husband and I share it.
author: Aquamarine M.

description:
Blue bottle coffee took over an older flower shop at the corner of the inlet mall area in the Ferry's Building.

-The first thing when you enter the right entrance, the aroma or the essence of coffee awaken your life.

I ordered my usual, an americano... simply delicious. Not watery like some chain coffee place or taste of burned coffee... just the right amount of aroma and a slight hint of bitterness from the coffee that was roasted perfectly. 

What's cool too if you order a Drip Coffee, they actually dripped the coffee from a funnel shape drip, in other words you just have to wait a little longer than usual.

The other "Most Try" is .. don't really remember the name of the food/coffee... it starts with "M" i think... anyway it was like a scoop or two of vanilla ice-cream with a shot of coffee over the ice-cream. Great dessert and coffee combo ever... Tasted heavenly...

Must try when you hit to the tourist district of Pier area.
author: Will K.

description:
New Orleans Iced Coffee? Check.

Affogato with Humphry Slocombe ice cream (one of my favorite ice cream spots in SF)? Check.

This is Ferry Building goodness right here. Apparently, though, my iced coffee was not "New Orleans" style. Knocking one star. It was good, but it wasn't much different than an iced coffee I would get anywhere else.

Onto the affogato... this put me directly into a "I shouldn't be eating more at 1:15 on a Thursday and returning to work" coma. I am currently pretending to work as I write Yelp reviews, as I am pretty tired and lethargic from my feast of a lunch in my beloved Ferry Building.

If it weren't for the iced coffee gone wrong (but still so right), I probably wouldn't be able to write these reviews.
author: Kristin F.

description:
Their coffee is good.  
I am coffee obsessed. I love the stuff, it is almost a religion for me.  
My coffee at home (Alterra Coffee Roasters!) is far superior to Blue Bottle. I brew a mean cup and I do it in a fraction of the time it takes them to drip a small and overpriced cup of coffee for me as I stand in an annoying line of Saturday morning SF hipster moms and tourists.  Its not just that the line is long but also that the line  is too slow and the baristas are incredibly inefficient to the point of it seeming almost spiteful to the people waiting for service.  I think they deliberately move slowly to piss you off.  
Again, as with my only complaint about the other blue bottle location, they are slow and unfriendly.  There is no reason why brewing a small cup of drip coffee should take so long.  

If you have the patience of the Dalai Lama, then by all means, enjoy waiting for your cup of coffee.  If you are a mere mortal and need your caffeine within a reasonable timeline after ordering it, then save yourself the anger-inducing 20 minutes and go to Peet's.
author: Nilu r.

description: The best mocha I've ever had!!!  Really cute shop and friendly service. Open one on Arizona!
author: Lindsay M.

description: And I thought I knew a cappuccino. Well these guys have the creamiest cappuccino's I've ever had. Better yet, they are consistent in making them. Milder than Intelligentsia and just a tinge bolder than Urth.  I had a couple on our visit here and boy was I in heaven. They only serve their waffles until 2 pm so make sure to get one.  Seats are definitely limited so watch closely and get them as soon as they open up.
author: Barbara H.

description: Not a true coffee fan so bought this for my sister and Mom to try. I will admit the New Orleans Iced Coffee is pretty good but wish I could be in love with it (if I was in love with coffee)
author: Jamie T.

description: The lattes here are delicious -- don't need to add any sugar/sweetener because it's just already sooo good.  A bit pricy, but you are getting an amazing cup of coffee.
author: Mel G.

description: I got the New Orleans style iced coffee. I like my coffee strong and not too sweet. This was perfect, especially for a sunny day in the city.
author: Jenn F.

description: My oh my the line for this place was long...both of them actually there are two lines for Blue Bottle Coffee at the ferry market! Kind of smart! The lattes and coffee were pretty good, the icecream they had was delicious too! Each latte is made with art and that little touch makes it that much better! Hopefully they can expand and make a sitting area that would be nice! and maybe some fans or air so their guests don't melt in line!
author: Milana K.

description:
This time I opted for their drip coffee and their caramelized Belgian-style waffle! This waffle - let me tell you - is to light, airy and fluffy, you feel like you're floating on clouds after the first bite. The sugar crystals that layered the outside of the waffle were a delicious touch to the already decadent buttery treat. 

However, get there early. Waffles are only served until 2pm and the never ending line may scare you away - but once you remember the endgoal, you'll be happy you stayed in line amongst all those pesky tourists who hold up everyone because they can't decide what they want.
author: Julia K.

description:
I had been hearing people rave about Blue Bottle for some time now, so when I found myself wandering through the Ferry Building in need of a fix, I was excited to hop in line. 

That line, by the way, was a bit long. Not bad, maybe 6 people in front of me, so I figured it wouldn't take long. 20 minutes later I'm finally ordering. They brew each cup of coffee separately when you order it, so it isn't really the wham-bang grab and go type of place. But that coffee is excellent. Very strong, very rich and reasonably priced (that one surprised me). They also had some awesome looking waffles, but I chose to pass. It is my biggest regret to date.

It is excellent coffee, but don't line up if you have anywhere to be in a hurry.
author: Chris N.

description: I stopped drinking coffee a while ago, but every once in a while, I will indulge in a decaf Americano. Had to wait in line for 20 minutes, but I'm glad I had the patience for the wait. They even steamed my milk for me so my drink looked pretty too. Delicious beverage ... Very smooth, perfect temperature. I was beyond happy with my Americano. Oh, and the waffle for $3 was very good too.
author: Mercedes R.

description:
I don't drink coffee, but this place is better than 66 Mint for the waffle.

This is the best waffle (in the flesh sans toppings) I can remember and not overly proportioned for one person.  It's denser than the one at 66 Mint.  I savored every morsel, mm mmm!

The staff here is friendly and knowledgeable.  I went there Friday and Saturday and they actually remembered my order from Friday (ok, this shouldn't be expected, but I was pleasantly surprised that they aren't just zombies)

**** NEWS FLASH:  Blue Bottle sells a different waffle type at the Ferry Building than at 66 Mint.  Ferry Building is only $3 and totally yummy.  The one at 66 Mint is just ok and almost $10!

Don't go to 66 Mint for the 7x7 EATS list.  I know it lists the 66 Mint address, but looking at the reviews between the 2 stores, it looks like they got the address wrong.  http://www.7x7.com/big-eat-2011-100-things-try-san-francisco-you-die ****
author: Cathy U.

description:
4.5

DRINK:
1.) latte - yummy, actually still had the foam design inside the togo cup. haha. 


SERVICE:
hahaha i love sf earthy ppl... so genuinely nice n caring. lol... Order and pickup at counter. 


ATMOSPHERE:
Inside Ferry building ;P Once again, waited in line for a little bit, on a Sunday morning. As expected. It's mostly just order togo, buuuut they dooo have a very tiny 5 stool bar seating along the side... lol..
author: Angela L.

description:
I can't go to the Ferry Building and not go to Blue Bottle.  I can always count on good taste and strong flavor.  Each cup is made to order so you will wait a while.  If you get an espresso based drink, you will get your cup with a leaf drawn in the milk.

I've had the drip coffee, latte, cappuccino, and mocha but will always fall back to the regular drip.  The milk based drinks tend to not be very hot and cool quickly.  Take those drinks outside by the bay and you will have iced coffee in no time.  Priced more than what you might expect, but the quality is not to be missed.
author: Michael M.

description: I think I went on an off day but my drip coffee was very bland and light. I didn't pick up any distinct flavors, as you would at philz or starbucks.. My fiance had the affogato, and that on the other hand was divine. I'll give it another shot next time I'm in town.
author: Kannika L.

description: I went and stood in line for 15 minutes, hoping it would be worth the wait. AND....... it was! I had the drip coffee which they do individually after you order. This is why it takes so long and it is definitely worth the wait. The flavor and smoothness is like nothing I have ever experienced. It definitely has ruined me for all other coffees. Can't wait to go back and relive this special experience.
author: Pamela S.

description:
While on my walk this morning I ventured through the Ferry Building and opted to have my coffee at Blue Bottle.  I was excited but ultimately disappointed.  I expected hot and strong, and it was semi-hot and a moderate strength at best.  Thankfully the line wasn't the usual out the door this time.

Philz is sooooooo much better!!!!
author: Sparkely K.

description:
Blue Bottle, like you need another review...

Anyhow, I'm just going to add another glowing review since you've always satisfied me with your heavenly good coffee.

God... how is it possible that coffee taste just like desserts? Say it hype, say I'm just going with the crowd but I found you long before I knew you're 4+ stars on yelp and I've been sipping your coffee for years now. Love you
author: Cliff T.

description: Amazing latte. I usually add 2% in my coffee or latte but blue bottle is exception. Their latte tastes much better with whole milk. I wish they sold in latte in 20oz. sizes as well. Mocha is ok, but am not a big fan of Mocha anyways.
author: Suyog D.

description:
My SF trip wouldn't have been complete without a trip to this SF staple.  I've heard so many compliments regarding it that I couldn't help but going in with expectations... kinda like when your friends talk about those "really good" movies...

Yea, 3 stars... I know.  WHAT IS WRONG WITH YOU?!  Well, let me say that the hype doesn't match up to what I tasted.  Sure the coffee was good enough to merit 4 stars, but the hype left me somewhat disappointed.  I got a single drip coffee which was made well but like I said, I couldn't overcome the expectations.  It is what 3 stars is on Yelp... A-OK.

I'll come back when I'm in SF again... just don't expect me to be super excited about heading there.
author: Michael K.

description: Definitely great coffee, but one thing I don't particularly like is that the latte/coffee is warm once you get it.  I prefer it hot, especially when I am waiting that long!  I think they should either heat up their milk or coffee a bit more. At that point, I can give them 5 stars.
author: Abra S.

description:
some of the best coffee i've had in the city.  philz is still my favorite as i like a lot of variety.  blue bottle coffee just tastes damn good.  

the line can be long at the ferry building location....lines seem long just about everywhere that serves coffee in the morning.  

i make the stroll here when i am in the city...nice little walk with good coffee as the reward.
author: Dustin S.

description:
I stand in a long line all the time observing the coffee making process and marvelling the attention and the time they took to make each drip coffee and the beauty in which they served the coffee in those neat brown cups with saucers.

Reached the counter and ordered a Machiato, I recieved it in about 2 minutes and I actually smelled the brew and was transported right into my childhood. Having filtered coffee and making filtered coffee in southern parts of india is a refined art and a daily ritual. I remember how the smell of coffee would literally wake me up and add that special zing to my day. How my mother and aunts would at length discuss the different coffee estates and the brews they would come out with and rate them(I have spent many a summer in actual coffee estates and loved the tender care required to create the end product) I wish my mother and aunts were with me when I had this coffee and given me that smile of approval but it's in the authenticity of those fond memories that I wish I could add another star and delight in the happy thought that i finally found coffee that is closest to the filter coffee made in southern india
author: Harsha G.

description:
$2.50 for an expresso, $2.75 for the drip, and $4.75 for the mocha.

Expresso's served in a large shot glass, and as for the coffee, it was pretty good, but it wasn't out-of-this-world like how everyone is raving on here (maybe they're used to drinking rocket fuel at their local gas station?).  I had the drip neat; to me, it had a medium roast and tartness to it, while maintaining a smooth finish.  All the 5 star elitists can get their panties in a wad, but for nearly $5 a pop, the regular-sized cup of regular-tasting mocha was just meh.
author: Sam W.

description: OMG! Blue Bottle Coffee Co. (and a number of others) is actually located inside the Ferry Building at the Embarcadero. During my initial trip to San Francisco I wanted to have a cup of coffee and be well-caffeinated for my visit. But as I toured/walked along the Embarcadero and Fisherman's Wharf, I could only wonder were there was a coffee shop. They are hidden inside the Ferry Building along with a deli, some gift shops, a juicery,etc. I found this out while waiting for my departure trip. I would have definitely had coffee here has I known. Maybe some signage along the Embarcadero would help visitors to find and enjoy coffee here.
author: Blandie M.

description:
Here's what East Coast pansies who "thrive" on Dunkin' Donuts swill don't understand about us Northern Californians. There may be some wise words written about "moving out of Northern California before it makes you soft," but I think East Coasters are just jaded because they are forced to settle for crappy coffee. The Bay Area refuses to settle for shitty coffee. REFUSES. NOT OK. They drink REAL coffee. And the best roasters, imho, are in the Bay Area. Aside from Peets (Peetnik for life over here), we got Ritual and Blue Bottle. I have always been able to get some at my Cafe 504, but I really needed to go to their real coffee shops.

I regularly scoffed at the line for this Blue Bottle for the last year. I always bypassed it and went straight to Peet's instead. But today, I forced myself to stand in the long ass line to have the freshly-brewed BBC that I grew to love at Cafe 504 in Oakland.

The verdict?

New Orleans Iced Coffee FTW!
author: Zulu Q.

description:
Everyone I know is like OHMAHGAH I LUFF BLUE BOTTLE COFFEE.

As a non-coffee-drinker (meaning I don't need it to function in the morning, I don't drink it on a whim, and I don't drink it in the afternoon to perk me up after lunch), going "out for a coffee" has very little sentimental value to me.  I can count on one hand how many cups of coffee I've had in my life (we're not talking about frappucinos or stuff like that).  I failed the Starbucks coffee test (remember the one where they wanted to see if you could distinguish their instant coffee from the regular one?).

Having said that...

+ Their mocha makes my day.
- The line makes me :(
+ The location in the Ferry Building is cute and makes me wish I didn't have to go back to work.
- Their drinks are never hot.  In fact, they're really lukewarm.
+ The people are nice.
- It takes for-ev-er to get my drink.

If I ever have to start drinking coffee, I'll start with Blue Bottle.  Only the best (supposedly), right?
author: Tori S.

description:
A visit to the Ferry Building, or San Francisco, for that matter, would not be complete without getting coffee at Blue Bottle.

There is a reason why there is always a long line. Tip: Don't let the lines deter you, there is a side window whose line is not as long as the main register but nonetheless, be prepared to wait. And it is worth it.

I LOVE their Affogato. The coffee is so perfectly strong and bold. The flavor is more complimented when combined with the ice-cream from Honey-Slocombe. I can't explain how good it is. Puns aside, it definitely is a party in your mouth. Their coffee of the day is just as good and strong too. Sister got the New Orleans iced coffee and says that it was pretty good and she highly recommends it. It's so good she doesn't know how to describe it when I asked her so that I could put it on here haha. They do have a unique way of brewing their coffee, and I like it =)

I still have yet to try the other independent coffee shops of San Francisco but for now, Blue Bottle is definitely my go-to coffee place. Starbucks does not exist whenever I'm in SF. 

And because I love it so much, I always come back to SD with a bag of fresh coffee beans so that I can brew my own cup of Blue Bottle Coffee in my own home and be reminded of how much I love San Francisco. 


P.S. don't forget to try their "buckles," it doesn't disappoint!
author: Bernicemina M.

description: Always a good idea to start here before you start queuing for the awesome fruits and vegetables outside.  My favorite is always an iced New Orleans coffee with chicory and a brioche waffle.  I don't mind getting elbowed as much when I have superb caffeine and sugar in hand.
author: Jenn N.

description:
It makes me angry when people say that they had to wait too long in line for this place.  Wahhh, babies!  You're getting a custom, handmade cup of coffee!  If you want fast coffee, then go to Starbucks and get a Venti half-pump vanilla with three inches of foam, or whatever the hell you order. If you want amazing, smooth, liquid gold coffee, go to Blue Bottle and stop yer bitchin'.

Tip: Walk though Mint Plaza rather than coming in the back door down Piss Alley.  It's a much nicer walk. :)
author: Melissa M.

description: Best coffee I've had in San Francisco. I am willing brave the ridiculously long lines, wait for the individual cup of perfection to drip, and pay more than a "Venti" for the small uniform size they serve- it's that good. One star deduction for the lid on the cup, I cannot manage to walk with without having it leak out multiple sides on my way to work.
author: Kerry K.

description:
Despite the (rare) scorching weather in San Francisco today, I knew I couldn't get through my afternoon meetings without a hot cup of Blue Bottle drip coffee. 

It would have tasted even better if I hadn't begun sweating into my cup, though.
author: Henry F.

description: They should give you a complimentary cup of coffee to help you stay awake while you wait till these pretentious coffee snobs prepare the slowest lukewarm latte in the world.
author: Frank L.

description:
Disclaimer: I am NOT a coffee drinker.  This review is NOT (really) about Blue Bottle's coffee (although I've had their iced coffee and regular Gibraltar and stuff-- all of which are good, but I'm not really one to judge).  No, this review is mainly about affogato, one of the items on the Blue Bottle menu that isn't strictly coffee.

Why am I not a coffee drinker?  Let's see if this story explains:  I had (stupidly) a latte at 4pm last week.  NOT a good idea.  I was wired until 3 am.  And because I'm used to waking at 7:30 am on a regular basis, my body woke me up after four hours of sleep, and I was a zombie the rest of the day.  In other words: I have zero caffeine tolerance.  

So what is this review about?  Because if not coffee, then what?

AFFOGATO!

Two scoops of Humphrey Slocombe ice cream (Maple Sugar Pecan or something decadent like that) plus an espresso poured over it.  Can you say HEAVEN?  My old roommate from college was in town visiting, and I took her and our other high school friend (who lives in the area now) to have Blue Bottle.  Affogato-- do it.  If you don't drink coffee (like me), do it.  If you drink coffee.  Do it.  If you drink tea.  Do it.  Do it do it!  It's coffee ice cream, but . . . not.

It's really sweet, and the portion isn't huge, but because it's so sweet,  it's actually perfect as an after-meal dessert.
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
I do love me some blue bottle :) I order the Bella Donovan beans to be delivered to me in NY, so when I am in SF I of course have to go get some blue bottle :)

The drip and soy cappuccinos put me in coffee heaven!!
author: Helen B.

description:
Normally I am not a regular coffee drinker, but I just love love love your soy late. 

At rush hour the lines are super long and it takes them forever to catch up. But I can't resist...
author: Claudia K.

description: Man, what a place! One of my favorite things to do in San Francisco is to attend the Saturday farmers market. Problem is I hate waking up early for it, and when I do I need caffeine to keep me going. This is the tastiest solution ive found. Fresh roasted coffee with perfectly frothed milk makes the blue bottle latte very hard to beat. I love this spot
author: Mina M.

description:
if you're looking to grab a quick caffeinated pick-me-up, you probably want to run across the street to the embarcadero center . . . to quote from their own PR blurb:

"Blue Bottle takes a hands-on approach to every step . . . . no matter how inconvenient or time-consuming . . ."

it is nice that they're upfront about it! piggies give bonus points for honesty (^(oo)^)v

all the drinks are really quite good and worth the wait if you do have some time to spare . . . they even make a perfect little leaf pattern in the foam on top! c'est trop cool, said the little piggy!

would be 4 stars if they didn't have a disappointing habit of running out of menu items rather more frequently than the average cafe
author: Vicki Y.

description: Fantastic coffee once again. This place is addictive. What more can I say that hasn't been said already :) Just wish parking was a little easier here.
author: John H.

description: Amazing coffee. I had a skinny cappuccino. Strong and creamy with no burnt aftertaste. Will be coming back
author: Michelle P.

description:
I was really excited to try Blue Bottle after seeing the great reviews on Yelp and from hearing great things about it from my friends. Last week, it was a beautiful day in SF and I got off work early, so I thought it was a perfect time to try it out. 

It took me ~35 minutes to get my coffee, and 20-25 minutes of that time was waiting for them to make it after I ordered and paid. I waited so long because since it was my first time here I was thinking that it just might take longer here than other coffee places. I was in no rush to go anywhere so waiting didn't bother me. However, it was getting to be a really long wait and I noticed that it was me and another girl waiting about the same time, but multiple people that got there after us were getting their coffee. Eventually we decided to ask the barista about it in case our orders had been overlooked. When we asked we got a short response - "Well that wasn't on my list" um... Ok. And then he says "Well I"m suuure you have been waiting 25 minutes but it wasn't on my list. But I'll make your coffee anyways". He made it feel like it was our fault for not having the coffee... how dare I ask for the coffee that I paid for and that I've been waiting for right? (by the way, I am not exaggerating the waiting time... I checked to see what time I checked in on foursquare, and the other girl checked what time she had made a call when we first started waiting...). I'm sure he deals with rude people all day long but that is not an excuse to be rude to us when they made a mistake...

The girl working the cash register was extremely nice the entire time and gave us a refund. If I only dealt with her, my review would be higher... I understand mistakes happen, and she dealt with it perfectly. Oh yeah, the coffee was good I guess.... honestly I was still kind of shocked at that point about how rude that guy was to us, so it didn't taste as good as it could have.... definitely was not worth the wait and experience.

I would try Blue Bottle again, but I don't think I'll be going back to this location.
author: Alison B.

description:
People were telling me this place has the best coffee around and I'm a big fan of philz so I was skeptical.. But this coffee is pretty damn good. First sip I was like ehh.. But then after taking a couple sips I was starting to understand the hype. The taste is unique and very enjoyable.  The aftertaste of the coffee is flavorful and lasting on your tongue. 

It is a one cup brewing at a time like philz but you gotta do ur own sugar and cream.  Ionno if It will replace my philz as my fave but it sure is damn good. 

Their waffle is something to get too while you're there.
author: Patrick L.

description:
I've recently become a convert to Blue Bottle's coffee after Happy Girl Kitchen back at home in Pacific Grove started serving their drip coffee about six months ago now. I was thrilled to try Blue Bottle straight from the source when I was up in the city a couple weekends ago. 

As I'd feared, there was quite a line to get coffee at this location--even with Blue Bottle's Saturday farmers market stand open outside, there was still a considerable wait for coffee. Between the farmers market crowds and the line of coffee-craving hipsters, Blue Bottle gets a little cramped. But it was definitely worth the crowds and the wait for a good, strong cup of coffee to keep me going through the afternoon.

It was a nice day, so I decided to get an iced coffee, choosing the New Orleans-style iced coffee to mix things up. The roasted chicories gave a subtle twist to a classic iced coffee. Sure, the iced coffee was a little pricey at $3.75 for a small cup, but it was worth every penny! It was a great pick-me-up for the afternoon ahead shopping the Ferry Building, then heading over to the Legion of Honor to check out their new Pulp Fashion exhibition. (Great exhibition, by the way!) I was tempted to order one of their Belgian waffles too, but considering we'd just had lunch a couple doors down at Sidekick, I simply didn't have room for anymore food.

Yes, some of the other Blue Bottle locations in the city are probably more conducive to grabbing a cup of coffee to go, especially considering the traffic on the waterfront on the weekends. But if you're already in the Ferry Building for lunch or farmers market, this Blue Bottle shop is mighty convenient for a great cup of coffee.
author: Raul N.

description: .....if you are 20 years old and want to feel like your doing the in thing, this place is a must do....wait on line, the long line....this place has struck gold...$20 for a pound of coffee, but to go easy on your maxed out credit card they package it in half pound bags for $10....have you noticed, young folks in San Francisco enjoy waiting in lines, how very docile...coffee is coffee
author: jim b.

description:
My favorite coffee place in the city (and if you're my friend you know that's saying something given what a caffeine junkie I can be).

Drip coffee -- pretty great and strong... a bit pricier than I usually pay for my daily starbucks closer to my current occupation in the south bay, but worth it.

My fave tho? probably the recchiuti mocha.... hefty price tag but perfect flavoring. I tend to find that many coffee places skew too sweet or too chocolatey in their mochas... this one is the perfect blend for me.
author: Rachel M.

description: I came here during my lunch hour around 1:15pm and there was a line which took maybe 15 minutes to get through, luckily I was taking my time.  I got the New Orleans Iced Coffee, and it was only "OK."  I never had blue bottle coffee before but I heard the hype and I'm not impressed.  I'm not a coffee person so that might be it.  It also had an after-taste that really stuck in bad way.  It was also rather pricey for what would be considered a "small" coffee on standard terms.
author: Laurice G.

description:
So I'm not a coffee fan but I have it on good authority that their coffee is awesome. It definitely looks the part! We hit the Ferry building almost every time we're in San Francisco and this is a must-go place. I can attest to the fact that their hot chocolate is to die for. So good...

Only bad thing is the horrible lines this place gets. I get it, I get it. Got to spend time to craft these delicious drinks. Still a pain in the butt to wait around for 30 minutes to get that amazing cup, so i had to dock them one star. But if you're in no rush, it won't disappoint.
author: JoeNLauren P.

description:
I totally have a hard time to make it a 4-star rating.

I had a cafe au lait and it was solid and smooth. I think it was overly smooth because of too much milk and not enough of coffee. Though, I appreciated the effort and care the staff spent on the coffee when I see the leaf or heart foam pattern on top.

Service was not friendly and dudes working behind counter was sorta rude. My friend was looking for creamer for his coffee and grabbed the carton box next to the espresso machine, and next the guy  didn't say anything and grabbed the box away from my friend.  Then, he mentioned the creamer was on the counter. I was there observing the whole interaction and in my opinion, it was unnecessary for him to do that to my friend.

Taking away the not-so-pleasant experience with their service, I do think it's a good place for a cup of joe.
author: Edmund L.

description:
Call me crazy, but I was totally underwhelmed (especially after reading all the 4 and 5 star reviews)... Philz Coffee kicks this place in the butt (not even close in my mind), and I'm not even sure the coffee here was at Starbucks level.
I had the mocha and I could barely taste the coffee.. and the Nawlins iced coffee was meh...
Also had the waffle. Wasn't bad, but wasn't great either...
Definitely not worth the crazy lineup for... nor the expensive price!
author: D T.

description:
The coffee here is AMAZING!  I'm not huge on coffee (I know, blasphemy!), but I can tell you that I walked here 2 days in a row, and spent 30 minutes in line each time for one of their concoctions.  

The cappuccino? Great!  The Baristas here are wonderfully skilled and aside from the coffee, it's really a great experience. 

If there was a Blue Bottle in socal, I could see myself becoming one of those $4/day coffee fanatics.  Good my wallet, I suppose, but I definitely have a hankering for a cup now.
author: Angela T.

description: The coffee here is to die for, but don't miss the waffle!!! Seriously, don't miss the waffle.
author: Katherine D.

description:
was in the area around lunch time one day and decided to check out their store. the line was pretty crazy. the cashier line moved quickly but the wait for the coffee was long. 
i got a latte and the coffee was good and fragrant. 
i'm not too sure if it's worth the wait though. there are a lot of coffee place around.... 
so i will still appreciate when people bring me a cup of bluebottle but eh.. prob won't go to the store myself again...
author: Ai L.

description:
Get the Drip Coffee. It's so smooth and rich. 

They have a nice selection of pastries and breakfast items. Baristas are truly passionate and knowledgeable about coffee they create.

Watch out during the mornings and afternoons... it gets extremely busy! but well worth a great cup of coffee.
author: Raleigh S.

description: Good coffee deserves at least 4 stars  however I am more of a fan of Kauai and Kona coffee.
author: Darin C.

description:
Is it the organic milk? Is it the espresso? Is it both? YES.

GET THE Coffee Cake!  Omg.  It wasn't too sweet and not too crumbly.  Not dry.  It had a hint of rose.  AWESOME. 

Very legit.  Very good.  Very worth it.  Can't wait to try their coffee in Bklyn!
author: Liz M.

description:
When
I
just
want
a
drip ...

I'll go with Blue Bottle.  It's like the Goldilocks cup: not too bitter nor too dilute.  Won't scald my tongue; hot enough to wake and warm me up.  At $2.50 it isn't cheap, neither is it overpriced for the quality of the roast you get.  

And you know it's a good roast when you can drink it black and the last sip tastes as great as the first.

I like their waffles.  Big, crunchy hearty warm serving makes the perfect mate for the drip coffee.  If you haven't tried one yet, you should.
author: Eileen P.

description: Always a long wait, but they soooo bring it when it comes to a cup of joe.... Drip is the way to go, especially if you like it black.
author: Ladybird G.

description:
Best cappuccino I've ever had.
I drink about 5 cups of coffee a day- I don't consider myself a coffee snob as I'll drink Starbucks and peets just as well as blue bottle. 
My drink of choice is an americano which they do great also- very strong. But my
Coworkers told me to try the cappuccino n so I did, and it's just amazing- like sex for your mouth. It's like a guilty pleasure in a cup. Really really the best coffee drink you can get in my opinion. And 3$.. Sure it's small- but mmmmm sooo good !
author: Adam O.

description:
Gawd! I love Blue Bottle Coffee. Every time I visit SF, i MUST have Gibraltar at Blue Bottle or Cappuccino! Gibraltar is not on the menu - my friend recommended i order it. A gibraltar is a super-short latte, or maybe a cross between a latte and a cappuccino.
Last time i was at Blue Bottle, I had a shot of Gibraltar and a cup of cappuccino - i was on Cloud 9 and i felt as if i grew wings!!! I was wired for HOURS.... lol 
*sigh*
author: Julia C.

description:
Love their New Orleans Ice Coffee....soooo good.  And if that's too cold for the winter days, give their drip coffee a try... stronger than the New Orleans Ice Coffee and pretty good.

We've been to both the Mint Plaza and the Ferry Building locations and prefer the Ferry Building location. The Ferry Building location has more space and two lines/ordering areas that makes the experience a little less daunting.
author: Christine C.

description:
It's cold as hell outside in SF, and I've walked a couple of miles to the Ferry Building to get some good bread for dinner (and work off some my holiday gustatory sins). Chilly and caffeine-deprived,  I look into Peet's: no line, but eh, not feeling it.

Then I see the big line at Blue Bottle inside the Ferry Building. And walk around the corner to the shorter line at the other Blue Bottle counter. Which moves like molasses because the one guy is doing everything--taking orders, making coffee, taking the money. And doing it SLOWLY. But, as I move closer, and see the perfect coffee drinks he's creating, I get a burst of patience, even with the New York-sounding guy who keeps trying to cut me in line while chatting on his cell. Finally, it's my turn...and my coffee is gorgeous, and the world is good again. And I immediately forget how long this took.
author: Chiquita y.

description:
Always had long lines at Blue Bottle coffee at the Ferry Building.

Once I tried their drip coffee, I knew why people waited in line for so long.
One of the best coffees I've ever had (including the ones I had in Europe).
Very fresh, not acidic, smooth drinking coffee at a reasonable price.

I will revisit when we are back in SF
author: J B.

description:
No go here.  It is too good.  You will want the New Orleans Iced Coffee  every second of every day until leap year ends.  

There are very few marsupials here however.
author: Darren H.

description: Stopped by this place for a latte, and that was the smoothest latte I've had on the west coast. Double ristretto shots plus some organic milk steamed by the cup at a perfect temperature yields a happy Jeff. If you've been to 9th St. Espresso in NYC, it reminds me of the coffee  there. If you're a coffee lover, Blue Bottle is definitely a place you have to go to.
author: Jeff Y.

description:
I had the hot mocha. It was strong and not too sweet. No chocolate after taste, which is a plus!

I would come back and try the drip, even though I don't like drip coffee. I was almost tempted to buy a drip coffee cup machine thingamabob because it looked so cool.
author: Melody W.

description: I've been waiting many many months to finally visit SF to try this Blue Bottle. As I walked into Ferry Market, I couldn't help but stand and wait in the long line at the Blue Bottle Coffee stand...in the rain. I ordered drip coffee so that I could just try their beans in the most raw way, without too much added sugar/milk. It was good, a little too acidic for my taste, but carefully prepared / dripped. Maybe I'll try a different roast next time that I may like better. Or maybe this place is just too hyped up?
author: Jennifer M.

description:
This coffee is absolutely delicious... I had their espresso and it was AMAZEBALLS!!! 

As I was sipping on that cup it reminded me of the old times in Italy when I used to sip on espresso at a BAR (cafe) and smoke my luscious cigarette.. So yummy!

They also have a great selection of other coffees I am sure must be delicious I am yet to try. I work at a hotel across the street and send several guests over and they all come back to offer nothing but great feedback...


CONS: the line is ALWAYS no matter the time or day absolutely insane... They should really staff it more because that is the number 1 remark I hear from all my guests and as a result if they are in a hurry I am forced to send them to Peet's Coffee or Starbucks!
author: NC B.

description:
Does love always have to hurt?

I mean, sure, the coffee's good, but the service is so inexcusably poor that this abusive relationship may need to end (esp. in light of Frog Hollow Farm's introduction of Verve Coffee on 1/16/10!). Interestingly, nearly every 4- and 5-star reviewer here mentions the long lines and slow service - but still 4 or 5 stars? People, there's a better way! Or do we somehow stay attached to something because it is hard?

My girlfriend - a hospitality professional and emerging operations guru - diagnosed this swiftly yesterday. I quote: 

"The place to order is too close to the place to pick up the coffee. Consequently, confused customers all gather in the same (too small) place. This is one thing they could (and should) learn from Starbucks (or Disney, for that matter).  

The other problem is that the "barristas" are too slow  - partly since
they often start running around to do other things, and partly since there is no truly efficient way to sequence the coffee orders: the manual order slips may be cute and retro, but they lack sequence numbers or times. 

All of the above can easily be fixed if they use a straight counter and move people from order to pick-up, just like their neighbor ACME bread does. Instead, they're wasting space displaying retail items (which nobody buys because they are overpriced) in a dead corner."

In short, good operations support good service and a good customer experience. Frankly it's just inhumane to make someone who's paying $3 to get a potent cup of drip to wait ten minutes for it.

Or am I just unhip?
author: Diane B.

description: Experienced my first cup of java from Blue Bottle yesterday and wow, it was wonderful. I ordered a latte and am looking forward to exploring more of the menu in the future. The taste was reminiscent of European espresso: bold and flavorful but not too strong.
author: Candice D.

description: Poseur coffee made by fake hipsters from suburbia served to sheeple willing to wait an hour for inferior coffee.  It's the iPhone of coffee.  Weak, pretentious and extremely popular among the socially challenged.
author: Otto D.

description: Really, really good cappuccino is what you can expect. They are consistent in their quality, their service and in the lines waiting for the building to open. Decent sandwiches too.
author: Robert P.

description:
