It's not that the coffee is bad - it's delicious - not bitter at all, and I'm a serious coffee wuss. I don't even mind the long line or the time taken with each cup. 
I just like my lattes hot. Not scalding but not tepid and sad like it had been sitting forgotten for a little too long. I know that's just how they do things.' So instead of going against the current - I'll just continue to get my lattes from Peet's.  Thank you Peet's, you are still my favorite.
author: Julia A.

description: I love Blue Bottle. We went again last weekend, and even with the line it is hands down my favorite latte. I would have given it 5 stars but for the line .... All they need to add is a GF version of their waffles.
author: George L.

description:
3.5 stars - it's good but not enough to be a fan.

Going to the Ferry Building on a Sunday has its perks.  We got there around 11am and we were able to hit all the hot spots w/ barely any lines.  Like here, it was only 3-5 people in front of us so it's a short line considering.  We got the drip coffee so we can really taste the coffee.  It's strong and pretty good but not very hot.  The petite brioche for $4.50 was not very good.  The bacon one was ok, it was cute with a slice of bacon rolled as topper with bits inside.  The sesame absinthe cigar is $1, not sweet with a nice hint of licorice flavor and dense.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Went into San Francisco yesterday from the North Bay on the Ferry.  As usual, when I make this trip I stop at the Ferry Building for coffee (a latte).  For the first time, I want to the Blue  Bottle shop instead of Peet's.
I got a non-fat latte which is my usual drink.  I was extremely disappointed.  The latte was not nearly hot enough, very small, the espresso weak and the drink was very expensive for what I got.  
I'll go back to Peet's in the future.  IMHO Blue Bottle is over priced and over rated.
author: Richard B.

description: Once in a while I'll go to the farmer's market on Saturday and drop by blue bottle to get the New Orleans Iced coffee. It's a nice treat every time I come here. The coffee is very strong and has a nice kick to it. The espresso OMG will wake you up. You'll be bouncing off the walls all day.
author: Thu L.

description:
this is wifey's review cause well, i gave up coffee quite a few years ago.  she ordered the affogato which was served with humphrey slocombe ice cream.  

wifey said, "no complaints"  haha. 

espresso was done just right!
author: Jen W.

description:
Admittedly not a coffee snob or an expert.

I had the drip coffee - yes it was good. Was it worth $2.50? No.
Is it worth standing in a long line for? Hell no!

I am curious though to try the iced coffee and the waffles they have.
author: Chili B.

description:
The Staff Makes it Special!

So we know that the coffee, tea, tisane, and pastries are all superb.  What really rocks is the staff.  Bryan, Charlie, and Vanessa make the experience what it is.  Charlie, well, she makes a great latte.  Bryan, he knows exactly how to make the Americano that I crave.  And Vanessa, her smile and overall attitude make the trip over worth it.  I try to walk to Blue Bottle Ferry Building on Saturdays during the Famers Market, and don't mind the line.  I know what I'm getting once I make it up to the front.
author: Eric S.

description: new orleans iced coffee my all time farovite!!!
author: Peter N.

description: i'm not a caffeine addict and i don't drink coffee regularly, but my friend loves this place and will gladly wait in that ridiculous line to get a cup of black stuff. i got the new orleans iced coffee and it was still bitter... which i guess is good? I like my coffee tasting like candy, so i'm not a very good critic for this place.
author: Jenn C.

description: Latte is my favorite, have not tried their drip coffee as of yet. Waffle is amazing and love the way the Sugar is baked in. it's sure worth waiting in line for a great cup of coffee/
author: Shadi K.

description: Got the New Orleans Coffee with Soy milk! The coffee was not too strong and not too weak, it was a great balance and a great way to start the day!
author: Esther S.

description: WOW !  Now I know why there is a constant line at this place ! Coffee is amazing, each one is brewed and made to order. Everything is of the highest quality.
author: Alissa W.

description:
Best coffee I've had in the city...
Please don't add milk/cream/sugar/cocoa/sweetener/sugar or whatever else you are craving to add to dilute the quality of this coffee...If it was Starbuck's, I'd understand, but this stuff is no joke, serious quality, strong ass coffee, and you should at least have one sip before deciding to add all that crap to it...

With that said, the line is extremely long here, but on a nice day, who cares? If you're in a hurry, you shouldn't be at the Farmer's Market anyways...
author: Farbod D.

description:
Over rated. Maybe it was all the hype built up beforehand, maybe it was the long line on Saturday morning filled with small children in strollers and their overtired parents, or maybe it was waiting 15 minutes after i ordered a cup of coffee and a latte that annoyed me, either way- over rated. 
You know what was good though, the beef noodle soup at the back sliding door and the chicken bow was yummy.
author: Mackey J.

description:
I would love to give them 5 stars since BB made my first cappuccino in SF. The reason I can only rate them a 4 is due to Frog Hollow. Don't get me wrong, the cappuccino was awesome, the coffee brewing process was unique and very exciting, the issue was FH was a bit better and how do you rate 2 companies a 5.

By the way I was impressed by the wave of loyal patrons. What I found by mistake was an outside outlet at the Pier during lunch without a line.
author: David B.

description: I tried the New Orleans style iced coffee and loved it.
author: Guillermo M.

description: Meh. I feel like I would be stoned if I gave this place three stars, so I'm going to bump it up to four. I like Blue Bottle, don't get me wrong, but I don't fully get the hype. I have a hard time waiting in like for 25 minutes at the Ferry Building when the line at Peet's around the corner is clearly only two people deep. Perhaps the problem is that I always just get regular coffee -- no New Orleans Iced Coffee (whatever that even is) or any other fancy offerings... perhaps that's the root of the problem. If the line isn't insane, I say go for it so you can see what every San Franciscan is raving about; but if it's trailing out into the main thoroughfare, skip it. It's good, but it's not THAT good. (Pretty sure that last statement is going to incite hate mail).
author: Shannon E.

description:
As usual, a Saturday is always busy with tourists and locals strolling around. I came by to pick up some great coffee drink while doing some nice bay water view.

The shelves, as usual, are almost always all empty from people who will buy several bags of beans at a time. They really should limit how many bags people can buy because truly, we should all have a chance to have some. But I am glad that still only limited batches are available at the stores.

Having a coffee should not be just a caffeine kick, it's an enjoyment, a pause of a day/evening to reflect and to know what life has to offer. It brings you back in reality, yet keep you linger in heaven, surreal.

And this day I had the mocha that is made with Recchiuti, which is sublime. And that's what I called unique.
author: T L.

description: You shall wait until you don't want coffee anymore. And even then, it is ALMOST worth the wait.
author: Yan L.

description: The line to the actualy place is super long, but it is always worth the wait!
author: Sheena P.

description: Worth the wait!! the waffles are absolutely amazing!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Short and simple. 

Their drip coffee goes down so unbelievably smooth. Thick and bold. I had heard so much and HAD to try it, so I broke my no coffee after 3 pm rule and had a full cup at 6:30pm. Then I was cracked out the rest of the night, tremor and all. Chicago fav: Intelligentsia. SF fav: Blue Bottle!
author: Annie W.

description:
I do miss my days working in the City since I started my latest assignment in Silicon Valley (SBC baby!).  Well, OK, maybe not the working part but definitely the part where I'm walking there and get to stop for coffee on the way.

So Blue Bottle is another place that has sprung up, been bantered about on Yelp and caught my eye for places to try (poet and don't know it).  One morning meeting was going to take me by the Ferry Building so knowing there was a Blue Bottle cafe in there, I mapped out my morning to give it a shot.

The FB is pleasantly quiet in the early morning, a welcome contrast from the daily lunchtime mayhem.  I saw the bottle and knew where I was going.  There was a decent sized line and a positive buzz around this corner of the otherwise still sleeping building.  I opted for the basic cup o' Joe, feeling this is a good benchmark for measuring against other places.

Great staff at this cafe, obviously benefiting from their product at this early stage in the day.  My cup took the amount of time to prepare I like it to (i.e., significantly longer than pouring from a spigot) and then they called my name.

Plenty of time before my meeting so I took a load off and had a seat to enjoy my first ever cup of Blue Bottle.  Now I must point out that I tried Philz for the first time only a few days earlier, and I thought that was heaven sent.  But I already wrote a review for them!  Blue Bottle was also delicious and clearly a top notch cup of coffee.   A level above the Peet's and Starbucks of the world, to be sure.

I look forward to going back and trying their espresso drinks as people have raved about those.  All in all, an absolutely terrific start to that day.  I need to get back "working" in the City...
author: John K.

description: Best latte ever!!  There's always a huge line but it's worth the wait.
author: Cathy L.

description:
So, I knew about them for a long time. For some reasons, I never had a chance to try their coffee until the other day.

I'm a huge coffee lover. I travel miles for good coffee. I also do not mind standing in a long line for good coffee as long as I have enough time. Besides, the line wasn't really that bad on that day. I normally don't drink latte or anything that has lots of milk because I believe it kills the taste of good coffee. But what can I say? I'm a girl that likes cute stuff... I wanted to see a cute foamy heart floating in my coffee cup. So I ordered latte.

Big mistake.

First, the guy who was at the espresso machine forgot my order. I had enough time so I waited, waited, and waited. Nothing was happening. Meanwhile, everybody else was served and drinking their coffee. Uh.. hello?

So, I told him I'm still waiting for my latte. No apology. And he did a lousy job making it. How do I know that? It's because he was talking with his friend entire time and was not paying attention to my drink at all.

And then, my latte finally came out. Sure, it did have the cute foamy heart I wanted. So I was thinking, "well, at least it looks good, and if this tastes good, I could easily forget about the fact he forgot my order".

I knew they don't serve their beverages super hot. I knew it. But this latte was not even close to be considered as a "hot beverage". And hello? where is the espresso? I couldn't even taste it. It simply tasted like a coffee flavored lukewarm milk. It was too bland to taste anything distinguishable. 

With all the expectation I had, what a disappointment it turned out to be. At least the guy who took my order, who was also running around to take care of the cashier and the drip coffee was very nice. I should have just ordered the drip coffee and I'm sure it would have tasted way better.

I figure being a tourist spot, people who work at Ferry Building location probably have less expectation to meet their customers' satisfaction. I will try their MInt location next time as I still have a hope that their drip coffees and waffles are worth their repuptations.
author: Cupie M.

description:
You know, although this coffee is some of the best I've ever drank (why? - ultra smooth with no bitter aftertaste)...I've gotten so used to including syrups and sweeteners to my coffee, it's a bit of a disappointment that they don't have that option here. There is a sugar shaker and Clover brand milk and soy milk, so it's okay...I'm just a creature of habit.

Currently when I go to the Ferry Building Farmer's Market, I always stop by for a cup of drip coffee or a latte. I plan on trying everything on their menu here eventually. I love their breakfast breads and pastries too especially the belgian waffle which is made fresh within 4 minutes - warm and slightly crunchy on the outside with a fluffy middle. Delicious.
author: Elaine W.

description: Delicious delicious delicious. They put effort into every drink they make, no matter what you order, I will definitely be back.
author: Claudia F.

description:
Disclaimer: I am a hot chocolate connoisseur and despite knowing Blue Bottle is notorious for their coffee, I decided to try their hot chocolate just for kicks. 

First sip reaction was that it was not that super sweet chocolately taste you might find elsewhere, which was nice. However, from my second sip on I was quite unimpressed. I paid $3.50 for a very small cup and it was not very hot at all and it felt taste-less after a while. Definitely not worth the price in my opinion.

However, I loved the ambiance and the employees were super chill and conversational, but for the place being in the middle of the Ferry Building, ambinance wasn't really the most important factor. Maybe next time I'll have a better experience with the coffee...
author: Jasmine S.

description:
I don't know what it is, but their coffee is the BEST!
Latte is so rich and smooth or a regular cup of Joe...mmmmm.....heaven in a recyclable cup!
Don't forget a Snickerdoodle....but expect a wait....remember you are in the Ferry Building.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Soy latte -- beautiful and yummy.

Service -- the main attraction, for me. Real, honest-to-goodness human beings who are passionate about quality food and coffee and making sure that the business' visitors have a great cup of coffee. 

Gorgeous cookies.

Initially, I was thrown by their menu, which only had a single size option for a latte or whatnot...  but then I realized that by streamlining the options, they are better able to focus on the quality.  Bingo!  

You gotta try their crafts.
author: Jen S.

description:
Definitely recommended. I go almost exclusively for the soy lattes and cappuccinos, but haven't been back as often nowadays because I'm too bushed after work and the lever machines are usually shut down by the time I drag my butt downtown. Consistency is BB's high point; drinks are never lacking in flavor and the milk/foam is always butter smooth (my favorite part).  I think I've had just one mediocre cup since patronizing them. I don't bother with the snacks or pastries as they're predictably overpriced and nothing out of the ordinary.

I'm definitely in the minority in that I don't mind the long lines at all, but only because I'm a budding coffee geek myself and I spend that time observing the baristas' techniques from the extraction to the pour (I'm pretty decent at latte art but I don't hold a candle to these guys) as they unflappingly crank out drink after drink for the endless barrage of tourists. 

The baristas aren't the friendliest sometimes, but that's probably from having to be endless workhorses that in turn doesn't allow them to interact with customers that much. I know the feeling; I used to work mornings at a Peet's and it was like an assembly line and not being able to really interact with guests sucked. Best to go in the evening when it's much slower and they're more relaxed if you're feeling particularly talkative. 

The downside: They've since stopped using Sunrich soymilk - the best I've ever tasted - and switched over to the more "meh" Pacific (which Peet's uses). 

Grab a cap for yourself and then wander around the Ferry Building looking at all the wares that you can't afford.
author: Jon A.

description:
Yes, the taste is great. Standing in line for 15 minutes, worth it. Spending over $3 on a coffee? Well I did spend the same amount at Philz before...
The lattes and cappuccinos come with a pretty foam design, so your girly heart will be happy.
Go try for yourself and see who wins your heart Philz or Blue Bottle.
author: Sonja S.

description: I love the drip coffee & waffle at the Ferry Bldg location.  The line can be dreadful though especially on Saturdays' Farmers' Market. The baristas are really cool/friendly especially once you become a regular patriot.  The kiosk (Thu/Sat) outside sometimes serves lukewarm drip coffee so I tend to avoid it now.  The waffle is the best - pippin hot. lightly sweetened, slightly crisp outside, soft inside & scrumptiously cheap at $3. However, there mocha or hot chocolate is not much to write home about so to speak.  But this is definitely a coffee place that rip-off Starbucks can't hold a candle to for sure- it's like comparing burned turpentine coffee to how real fresh coffee should be.
author: MiniTess D.

description: I bet it's faster to fly to Italy for a great espresso, than dealing with these pretentious Blue Bottle coffee con artists.
author: Michiel D.

description:
Cash Only.

Price is fair, coffee is quite good, but not perfect. My cappuccino was yummy but it didn't knock me over. Perhaps I'm a victim of my own overinflated expectations, but it just didn't kick my ass the way I wanted.

Amazing coffee leaves you speechless, but I was still able to carry on conversation without remarking the blend, therefore I have to assume I came on an off day.

I plan on sampling this again and writing a follow-up review but my first foray into the blue bottle wasn't lights-out-knock'em-down delicious, yet it was pretty darn good. I think next time around I'll order the drip instead.

TL;DR: I like coffee, and Blue Bottle makes a damn good cup, but it wasn't the best cup I've ever had, as I'd been expecting due to the hype.

Originally posted to the wrong Blue Bottle shop. Moved to Ferry Building to more accurately represent my experience.
author: Joshua G.

description: New Orleans iced coffee smooth and cool just like me...just playing, no but seriously yeah I'm cool.  I like the drip coffee idea and i like being able to taste the coffee.  I do believe hot coffee should be black and iced coffee should be sweet, but this coffee was good to go as is.
author: Theo B.

description:
oh
my
goodness

inducted into BBottle world by Kara's cupcakes in the Marina a while back, but the drip coffee was perfect. So, so perfect, especially when I added just a spot of milk to my cup of drip in the Ferry Bldg, and, not wanting it to be lonely, grabbed something uber sugary @ Miette.

spendy, yes. bean with super roasted flavor, and inimitable aroma. yes

Must cross Bay again soon for more methylxanthine magic...
author: Jana C.

description:
This place just beat out Brooklyn's Gorilla Coffee as the best coffee on the planet. I spent 30 minutes of a Saturday morning waiting in line at the Ferry Building after hearing everybody rave about this place. 

Worth. Every. Single. Second.
author: Casey K.

description:
lol at their "secret window" that doesn't really seem much like a secret.  It's just around the corner from the store front, before the restrooms.  A good idea in theory.  

I must have waited 10 minutes for my turn to order despite there only being three people ahead of me in line.  I guess good customer service is a good excuse for a long wait.  The barista really did channel all of his energy into making me a perfect soy latte.  Love that they don't charge extra for soy.  Love the foam art.  The taste was exceptional, even when it became lukewarm.  I liked this cup better than the one I got at the Mint St. location.  Thumbs up for good coffee!
author: Lydia W.

description:
AHHHH I love this place. I used to work at Starbucks and that crap just killed me inside. So going to a great coffee shop like Blue Bottle really means a lot to me. I love the way they brew their drip coffee in those little manual drip cone-shaped things. The espresso is so smooth and delicious. They only use organic milk (although I've recently gone vegan; I'm pretty sure they offer soy... I haven't been able to go recently). Their menu is short and simple. No BS. 
This location is always busy whenever I show up, but I like to order my latte and take it outside to the back of the ferry building, sit on a bench and enjoy with a beautiful view of the bay. :)
author: Jennie M.

description: For my money, Blue Bottle is as good as it gets. Whether it's the whole beans, the individual drip coffees, the well-manicured capps and espressos, or the sublime Gibraltor, Blue Bottle "brings it" on every drink.  This location in the Ferry Building is obviously fantastic for locals and tourists alike, and is perfect for sitting and people watching (if you can find a seat) or grabbing a drink on the go.  Be prepared for longish lines on weekends!
author: Ethan R.

description: The staff here are always so friendly and welcoming! I typically grab coffee around 7:00am, and even for the early morning they are perky and delightful! I'm just breaking into the craft brew scene and they are more than willing to answer my questions and teach me about the coffees and brewing. The kitchen is currently under construction, but they still have a decent selection of pastries and breakfast items. I can't wait for it to reopen so I can try their infamous waffles!!
author: Ashley S.

description:
Blue Bottle is a treat each and every single time I go. 

1. The servers are SO NICE even though it's always busy. 

2. Best drip coffee I've had in the city (and they do such beautiful things with the foam that it almost feels like a shame to drink it) 

3. PASTRIES ARE DELICIOUS and pair so well with coffee. I once had a savory shortbread biscuit (I forgot what it was exactly, I believe fennel seeds and maybe pumpkin seeds were involved) which was not like anything I've ever found at a coffee shop. Buttery, salty, perfect texture. I highly recommend the Gruyere sandwich, 4 slices of cheese with butter inside a soft yet kind of rustic bread. It doesn't sound like much but it'll do a lot for your taste buds. 

4. I also really like the portions of everything. The drip coffee only comes in 1 size so I don't end up ordering a large because I can, then OD-ing on caffeine. Many pastries are also smaller than what you'd find at a Starbucks or Pete's and priced accordingly. (Sometimes I don't want a scone the size of my face!) For example the previously mentioned savory shortbread I had, which was maybe $1 or $1.50 for a piece the size of a fat Madeleine cookie, is the perfect size to nibble with coffee. 

Only downside is that Blue Bottle is usually busy, they take great care to deliver an awesome cup of coffee so it does take a few minutes. The wait is worth it if you have the time, but if you expect to order and be handed a cup within the minute I'd hit up Pete's instead.
author: Vivian Q.

description:
Before I headed back to SFO I wanted to stop by the Ferry Building so I could get some gluten-free baked goods at the Mariposa Bakery kiosk for my roommate. I bought a cinnamon roll for myself and since I couldn't have a roll without a nice latte or cup of coffee, I walked down to the Blue Bottle Coffee Co. and got a soy latte. It was absolutely delicious, especially with the gluten-free cinnamon roll. I nearly cried, it was so good. 

The menu looked a bit limited but one doesn't always need the Starbucks experience in which you're inundated with choices. I'll definitely go back...and yes, I'll be getting another cinnamon roll first. How could I not?
author: Corinne L.

description: I made the trek to the Ferry Building from Nob Hill twice in my three day trip to SF. My New Orleans iced was freaking delicious. I almost never have iced coffee, but I wanted it to carry with me wandering and was just in the mood. Sometimes iced coffee seems really weak, but the coffee was full-bodied and frankly, awesome. Lines moved fast, which was also a huge plus.
author: Renee E.

description:
New Orleans Iced Coffee at BB is sorely overpriced at $3.50 each.

And, yet, I had two of them in one morning.
author: Patty W.

description:
Always a long line but moves fairly quickly.  I like the New Orleans iced coffee or the drip.  I've seen a lot of people get the affogato which I will need to try one day.  High quality coffee in the beautiful Ferry Building with a scenic view of the SF bay right outside.  It's pricey coffee made with love.  What more could you ask for?

Note:  If you really can't wait, then Peet's is a great, quick alternative.
author: Justine L.

description:
Review of the hot chocolate only:

They have regular hot chocolate that they mix with milk, and they also have a vegan hot chocolate that they will mix with soymilk. I had the latter. I had just asked for soymilk, and the cashier volunteered the info about the hot chocolate mixes. That was nice. Considering it was rush-hour, they had pretty fast service. The vegan hot chocolate was very sugary, medium thickness, and served hot. It satisfied my chocolate craving of the afternoon, but I don't think I would order it again.

The one thing that worried me is that the clean spoons container and the dirty spoons container are next to each other and can be mistaken for the each other by people rushing. And one misplaced dirty spoon contaminates the whole clean container.
author: Corinthia C.

description:
Please don't confuse my 3-star rating for this location as a knock against Blue Bottle coffees. I LOVE their espressos and the coffees they make, but this location in the Ferry Building sucks. 

Sure it's right there in the middle of everything, but that's not the best location for a traditional coffee shop like place. You know, where they make each latte one cup at a time and brew each cup of coffee one at a time. If I wanted that I'd hit up another Blue Bottle location. But when people are in the Ferry Building, they are shopping or catching a ferry back home or doing something in a hurry - either way I can't imagine anyone wanting to wait around 10 minutes to get a cup of coffee.

If you can get lucky enough to go there where there isn't a line, you'll enjoy their coffees. If more then 5 or 6 people are there forget it, you'll be waiting 20 minutes.

I really think this was a poor place for a shop this like. I hate to say it, but something like a Starbucks or a quicker type coffee shop would be so much more convient.
author: Erik B.

description: Tried Blue Bottle after getting off the ferry, the line was 10 people deep at 9:30 in the morning.  The service was really friendly.  I tried the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee, best Iced Coffee I've had in a while.  It was very bold, not bitter and had a smooth buttery finish.  All the drinks are hand made, even a straight cup of coffee.  Be prepared to wait 10 minutes in line if you go at  a busy time.  The Ferry building didn't have much in the way of seating, more of a grab and go set up.  At nearly $5 a cup it's on the expensive side but hey you're in San Francisco and the coffee is really good.
author: Daniel W.

description: not sure what the hype is about this place. i was by the piers on Saturday morning and thought i should try a non-starbucks/peets place. yelped and decided to try this. stand in line for 45 minutes?! got the mocha for $4.75. i have to say that their baristas have very consistent latte art skills. however, the mocha itself was no that special. i would assume the $4.75 is because of the rent for being in the ferry building, but the line was just ridiculously long (b/c of farmer's market). anyway, i won't go back at my own will.
author: Diana C.

description: Just ok.  I judge a coffee shop on the quality of their coffee.  Go figure.  In this case, they have the right approach with the cup drip, but the coffee has way too much cocoa flavor for me, and a really sour finish.  Gross.  I do like the rich bodied texture before the sour takes over.  Intelligentsia and Caffe Vita have a similar body, but are far better balanced and blow this place out of the water.  Too much hype surrounding this place.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I waited in a heinously long line to purchase coffee beans here. I can't say how the espresso drinks are, but if you're having a terrible time enjoying life, you should buy a bag of Zemoch beans. They will awaken your senses like no other. The smoothest, sweetest brew, without a hint of bitterness. Not over-roasted at all. I think it is sourced from Guatemala, one of my fave coffee locations. 

I am most definitely returning to try more kinds of coffee. I also noticed they serve freshly made Belgian waffles...it's a shame I can't eat them.
author: Helen I.

description:
It's depressing to admit that very few things excite me in life. Sure, I'm lucky, healthy, happy, even content... but excited? REALLY excited? Meh.

It's even more depressing to admit that food is one of few things that provide excitement. My mind everyday: God, I'm bored- day full of stress- pay that parking ticket- hold mail for old apartment- worry about dog- don't forget to workout- muse about direction of life- fear I'm making the wrong choices at 24- contemplate running away to a foreign country- oh, wait, no, my dog couldn't come with me... what's for lunch?

Lunch?! Such a welcome and delightful thought! 

It's along these lines that I love Blue Bottle. It may be absolutely NO different than any other cup of coffee; I'm happy to admit that. It's definitely too expensive. The pastries are okay, but $4.50 for brioche? Is it gold-filled? In general, Blue Bottle may absolutely be 98% hype.

But in a boring day full of rumination on the many worries of my life, Blue Bottle gives me something to look forward to. I can pretend it's special. When I start off my morning with Blue Bottle's New Orleans Iced Coffee or Drip, I can feel like maybe today IS special. Maybe there is something to be excited about, afterall. 

If I'm paying $3-10 for an illusion- bring it on. 


BTW, the yogurt parfait is terrific, albeit expensive. There's a $1 deposit since it's served in a glass jar, so it's something like $6, but what else do you expect at BB?
author: Amanda C.

description:
I'm generally an espresso drinker, but at Blue Bottle I usually go for the drip coffee - it's that good! Strong and tasty, you can enjoy a big cup and still get the flavor of a short espresso.

The location at the Ferry Building is not ideal, since it's always crowded. Having a second window for orders is good, but unfortunately don't alleviate the problem entirely. Hence 4 stars.
author: Kris M.

description: best latte I've ever had.  That simple syrup stuff they put out only adds to it's deliciousness. I honestly can't believe they only sell those 2 tiny sizes they do... I could drink this stuff all day. Lines are crazy, but we went to the shop in the Ferry Bldg one night and there was no line (think it was right before closing) and went back the next day to the stand where there was a line... took ab out 15 minutes, but was totally worth it. Now that I'm back home in Boston, where there is not a Blue Bottle Coffee Co., I feel a little sad inside.
author: Ali K.

description: How is it that I've missed this place? Well the important thing is that now I know and will be back to continue to support their superior coffee. I will note that while they do brew the most perfect espresso I've encountered in SF, they do use vanilla soy milk (tisk tisk) so I docked a star for that. Usually the vanilla soy drops a review down to Starbucks level but the espresso is that good.
author: Stacey C.

description:
I finally tried Blue Bottle Coffee on my last day in SF and it was so delicious. I wish I went sooner!

The line was long but the service was quick. I ordered a New Orleans Iced Coffee and my mouth is watering just thinking about it. The coffee is strong but not bitter, aromatic & smooth. It is served with milk and has a hint of natural sweetness; no sugar needed.

Please be kind and try, it is so good!
author: Terry C.

description:
Yet another place that we stopped by at the Ferry Building.  First things first, expect a line, as there were at least 10 people in line every single time that we stopped to get our morning coffee.  They make all kinds of fancy coffees and expresso type drinks here including "drip coffee" and my personal favorite the New Orleans style ice coffee, which they told us takes 18 hours to make by some fancy method.  Typically the NO ice coffee comes with milk blended in since it apparently has a bold even harsh taste.  I usually drink my coffee black, and so I requested no milk in my ice coffee. This is where a 5 star review becomes a 4 star review.  I understand the warning about the milk recommendation, as it does have a strong, non conventional taste, but I like it that way.  If I tell you that I like it that way, have had it before and somehow survived, please stop fussing at me at the counter about my order.  Despite the minor customer service hiccup, this place does have awesome coffee and will be  staple of any trip to SF.

My wife tried the original version with milk and while it was still very good, it lacked the experience of the black or no milk version that I love.
author: Andre B.

description:
This place is GOOD! 

There aren't that many places in SF that I found had a coffee prepared so well. The baristas know their stuff, the coffee they use is nice and not overly bitter, and their latte is pretty much a flat white if that's what you're looking for. 

If it's your thing, they also do drip coffee here.
author: J S.

description: The only thing special about this location of Blue Bottle is the extra-extra-long lines at all times of day.  I recommend going during the Farmer's Market and grabbing your coffee at one of the outside stands to cut your wait in half.  Coffee is good (just like they tell you over and over) and usually worth the wait.  They only use organic milks which pleases my Monsanto hating guts.  My favorite: New Orleans Iced Coffee.
author: Sally L.

description:
Great Coffee!!!  A friend recommended that I try this place since I was visiting the Ferry Building.  I'm glad I did because they have wonderful coffee!  I'm from Seattle and I am really impressed with Blue Bottle.  I had a soy latte and it was one of the best lattes I've ever had. 

The next time I visit I would like to try their signature drip coffee that's prepared by filter individually.  It's supposed to be good and worth the wait.
author: Rowena D.

description:
Something I know I'm supposed to like more than I do.  On a very conscious level I know this is good coffee & I know I'm meant to love it, but I just can't.  I'm a Boston native & I want my DD light & sweet.  I just want it how I want it.  Ordered an iced coffee here & it made me afraid to go to New Orleans.  Will they not let me have cream??

Staff was upbeat, friendly & I liked the atmosphere - felt good to see a huge crowd of people all standing around like they were waiting for free gold, but rather for coffee.  

Going with 3 stars because that's what I would give Blue Bottle if I was able to actually appreciate a good cup of joe.
author: Talia R.

description:
My cousin was always perplexed by Blue Bottle: "Who are all these people standing in line for that long for coffee?"

So one day I took him.  After one sip, by the look on his face, I knew I won.  Sometimes, hipsters aren't completely full of it.  

Perfectly, perfectly, perfectly pulled espresso every time.  Seriously, one cup and you'll forget about every cup of coffee you've had up until that moment.
author: Courtney N.

description:
Blue Bottle = My choice rocket fuel.

Blue Bottle used to be my token treat at the Ferry Plaza's Farmer's Market, but ever since I armed myself w/ a French Press, Grinder & 1/2 lb. of Three Africans Blue Bottle beans... it has become my daily pick-me-up. Long gone are the days when I would purchase lattes @ Peet's & Starbucks. Having a straightforward cup o' joe that isn't chock full of sugary richness is what I much rather prefer, and BB's stuff does the job beautifully.

I came here yesterday to stock up on new beans and got myself their delicious New Orleans Style Iced Coffee. Last time I had one, I slurped it down so fast, I had to go back for another fix! I'll have to buy one of their ice coffee kits so that I can satisfy my addiction more often! I also picked up one of their waffles dusted w/ powdered sugar, which definitely beats a hard-as-rock biscotti to go w/ the coffee. YUM! Their breakfast sandwich selection had me in envy of those that work in the Fi-Di, where they can easily stop by here to get themselves a decent morning meal on the go! They put Starbucks & Peet's to SHAME.


Thank goodness Blue Bottle ships to NYC. I don't know how I'll be able to survive w/out it!
author: Tiffany M.

description: Really great coffee, be prepared to wait in a really (really) long line. The people who work there are fabulous and helpful- I didn't (and still don't) know much about coffee when I came here the first time but they weren't rude or demeaning about it. They also helped me pick out a bag of coffee. Had a capuccino both times and it's one of the only coffees I did not feel any need to put sugar in. DELISH! Plus they use organic milk :)
author: Amanda W.

description: This place is continuously bombarded by impatient tourists with bad midwestern fashion and the baristas are still gracious every time.  In addition, the coffee is spectacular and the waffles are just right - not too sweet.  Five stars.
author: Dan S.

description:
Grab a Gibraltar. A mini latte that is named after the glass it's served in.
It's not a menu item, just ask for it.
author: Geordie E.

description:
OH MY GOT.

This is probably the most memorable little cup of cappucino that I have ever had in my life.

I fell in love after my first taste. The 20 minute wait was well worth it. I added a teensy bit of sugar,  but that wasn't necessary.
author: Beverly T.

description:
Looking for lunch at the Ferry Building, I was pleasantly surprised to see that Blue Bottle had opened inside the Ferry Building!

Awesome. I didn't have to walk all the way down to SOMA to pick up some great coffee. But, I was in for a surprise... this location serves bag lunches. WOAH. Kill two birds with one stone. 

The bag lunches includes a salad, a salty snack, choice of sandwich, seasonal fruit and a dessert. That plus a cup of their delicious drip coffee brings your total to $14. Sure, it's a more pricey lunch but I thought it was completely worth it. 

The salad of the day was a Lebanese cous-cous salad and I chose the Duck Pate sandwich. The salad was fresh and light. The sandwich was aight, a little heavy on the red cabbage slaw. 

There is some bar space to enjoy your lunch, but not too much... but who wouldn't want to take your bag lunch out to the dock area and eat your lunch and sip your coffee while taking in the beautiful SF bay.

Come for the coffee, stay for lunch, and come again to get a refill on that coffee.
author: Danvin R.

description: I haven't been a regular coffee drinker for many years now, but if I was, the New Orleans style iced coffee would be what I would drink. Damn is it good...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
I visited SF this past weekend and wanted to try a coffee house specific to the area. Luckily, I found Blue Bottle Coffee Co. in the Ferry Building!

They actually brew individual cups of coffees. Fresh coffee?? Wow. Coffee cups are lined up, filters (w/grounds) placed on each cup and hot water is poured in and voila! Water drips through and delivers the most freakin delicious coffee ever! 

I tried the New Orleans iced coffee, which was perfect! I originally thought it might be too sweet, but it had the right balance of coffee, whole milk and sweetener.

I wish Blue Bottle was in OC. I'd be a frequent visitor!!
author: Tanya S.

description:
Stood in line for five minutes to give my order. Worth the wait. I had the machiatto in a espresso cup, while mixing in a half pack of sugar.

I've been to many Roman bars sipping the best cappuccini, Blue Bottle is in a class of their own. One of the best machiato's I've had,
author: Jolene R.

description:
Well BBCC you have done it again.   You really know how to roast good coffee but you also know how to hire pretentious (yes pretentious) hipsters.

So mr. hipster barista (i'd provide a description of said hipster but they all look alike - http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=hipster) maybe try to get off you fake depression trip and provide some good service.

the coffee is good but i'd rather drink an ok coffee that does not come with the a side of attitude.   

just a suggestion BBCC but you should send your staff to Ritual for a day to show them how to provide good friendly service in a busy environment.
author: Aus B.

description:
YESSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS FINALLY A PLACE THAT FEELS LIKE HOME!!

when you grew up on coffee, and can drink it all day everyday, and enjoy a nice cup of espresso after dinner; coffee is really important!!!!! I am from seattle, and I have been searching far and wide for some damn good coffee in the bay area. No go in the east bay, south bay, or sf so wtf!!!! so I did what most people do when they are new in town. Go on yelp and let yelp guide me to greatness!!!! and greatness is where blue bottle has it!!!

Crack in a cup- yes indeed and I love it. Too bad I have to f'n drive to get :( and the hours suck but we'll see how many times a week I can drive there to get a cup of coffee.. Sorry starbucks but since my last encounter of stalkerish guys in the marina I'd perfer the hipsters at blue bottle
author: Nina M.

description: OK, I have been drinking machiattos, espressos and lattes for 20+ years at some of the recognized landmarks for excellent coffee in Portland, Seattle, Vancouver, Chicago, Paris, Vienna, Amsterdam, etc.  I'm not a coffee snob or extremist, but I appreciate a well drawn shot, a brilliant roast, perfect temperature steamed milk, etc.  I am pretty sure that the Latte I had yesterday morning at the outside stall of the Ferry Building was the most delicious Latte I have ever come across.  It was like nectar.   I can't get over how perfectly balanced it was.   Bravo, Blue Bottle!
author: Bob T.

description:
Inserts 'First To Review' button next to avatar, since Blue Bottle opened today, 4/2/09, which makes me a winner. 

The Blue Bottle in the Ferry Building is fiiiinally open and I am so excited I knew this day would come kind of like when I used to unwrap my presents before Christmas and hide them back under the tree. *Switches to Decaf* 

The puzzle piece counters are cool to look at and there's coffee to buy if you're a smart cookie and know how to brew it at home. 

Plus, the staff is so top notch and friendly that I almost feel bad they'll have to see my grumpy face each morning. But in the afternoons, after the caffeine has kicked in, I'll return for another cup and hope that they choose to serve me. 

The windows on the side allow you to see what's going on in the back, which makes my stomach queasy-free. It's kind of like when you Google prospective suitors or follow them around in a trench coat and hat... maybe not completely necessary, but a good way to know what you're getting into.
author: Janney B.

description: I have been to New Orleans and know what the real cafe au lait aka New Orleans' iced coffee tastes like...and this place disappointed me greatly. The iced coffee was strong but lacked flavor and the chicory taste that true NOLA coffee has. Blue bottle should not claim to serve New Orleans iced coffee because it certainly isn't! It comes from a huge iced jug and they add ice and milk. At Starbucks its called iced coffee and it is about 3 bucks cheaper, yet the taste is the same.
author: Karina A.

description:
Just as our society has evolved from Turning Leaf White Zin to five Napa-Sonoma reds by-the-glass, so is coffee evolving from Dunkin Donuts to Starbucks to Peet's and beyond.  Blue Bottle is the Chez Panisse of local, sustainable, high-quality coffee. Check out Cafe 504 sometime.

But damn, great service here. I lined up, expected a long wait as each drip cup was brewed to order, but the lineup of filters and a quick, efficient staff kept the line moving. I got to the front, ordered my take-out cup, and watched the filter cones get their fresh slugs full of ground goodness and the metered dose of hot-yet-not-boiling water.

A few minutes later, the servers realized someone hadn't claimed their cup. It was abandoned. I'd watched it being made, and saw it set out on the counter. It was hot, fresh, and unsullied. It was about to be rejected and discarded. So, I claimed it, thinking that to waste a fine cup over a mere minute's delay was foolish and wasteful. The coffee professionals saw this as a sacrifice and offered me the cup for free. My money, in hand, went into the tip jar.

And it was still great coffee.
author: Matt R.

description:
I don't even like coffee!

Yet, I willingly walk 6+ blocks every weekday and stand in line to get the New Orleans style Iced Coffee.

It's that friggin' good!  

Do give it a try!
author: Tushar V.

description: Great coffee! I'm not a very big coffee person, but I tried their New Orleans Iced Coffee ... and it was really good, even without any sugar! Not bitter at all and really smooth! And it offers an extreme energy blast!  It was cool watching them drip their coffee in individual filters too!  Little pricy, but it was yummy!  ;D
author: Tramy V.

description:
I may get hate emails for a while for giving less than 5 stars.

But when I have to wait 15 minutes for a drink when there was barely a line (ie. 3 people ahead of me) and it's because the employees are chatting about what bar they went to, well that irks me.

Imagine if I had been in a supreme coffee emergency and was in need asap.  What if I was going through coffee withdrawals?  I would get it if there was a wait due to a long line, but when I'm waiting because you are talking about the hottie at the bar last night that ignored you, well that irks me.

Oh, but once we get our drinks, all is well again.

So maybe worth the little wait and annoyance.
author: Denise B.

description: Stood in line, wondered what to order.... decided to order a drip coffee. Looked at the to go cup and said to myself.. "the cup is so small, ill finish my coffee in no time" boy I was wrong! The coffee is soo strong! Very good flavor and by the end of my cup.. i felt cracked out and I drink coffee everyday.
author: A L.

description:
I am not so sure it was "life changing" as my friend Ray exclaimed. However, it was pretty damn tasty. I waited in a very long line chatting it up with these ladies from Concord who threatened to take RAY down if it wasn't as good as he made it out to be. He was still standing at the end of the day so apparently they were not unhappy with the wait. 

Iced New Orleans style coffee was my choice and to quote another Ray "YUMMO" (as in Rachael Ray)
author: Scott P.

description:
Basically on par quality wise with (as far as my taste buds can tell) the good espresso places in New York, maybe a bit less, but still pretty good. My espresso shot was satisfying and my brother's cappuccino was good too (even though he isn't a coffee drinker, he liked it).

Not much else to say..
author: Amar P.

description:
I was buying groceries and two girls had a very animated and excited conversation over Blue Bottle. At first I thought they were talking about seltzer water because I had know idea about this place but after a few minutes in line I had to turn around and ask them about it.  Because they were annoyingly funny dropping "like" and "totally" every other word and were soooo in love. I remember a friend telling me about it too but forgot all about their coffee.

I have come to realize that coffee in SF is not merely just coffee but it is just like anything served in a delicatessan. Which is great because for a coffee lover it gives variety. I ordered an Americano and the very nice barista brewed the shots up and poured the drink into a small cup. The coffee could wake the dead, it was quite tasty and did not taste burnt whatsoever. I am happy to say that I finally tried this place out to see what the hype was but I am more of a Philz kind of girl.
author: Morgan M.

description: Oh delicious, delicious macchiato. Worth standing in line, worth the wait. You can't get their espresso to go, as they only serve it in the ceramic cups so you have to stand right there and drink it. As you should. Espresso out of a paper cup? Lame. Blue Bottle Coffee Co.? Awesome.
author: Davida G.

description: Great coffee and latte is best latte I ever had in SF so far
author: Unyo N.

description: Excellent coffee.  They know how to make a Latte.  The down side is that I'm not the only person to think that.  The line is often crazy there.  But in the end, it's worth the wait.  Sweets were yummy, too.
author: Greg B.

description: Ultimate luxury in a cup,  or bag if you pick up their beans.
author: Elle C.

description:
FINALLY! The much anticipated Blue Bottle coffee bar opened it's ferry building doors this spring and has been a hot spot for designer espresso shots ever since. 

So whats all the fuss about? Why are San Franciscan's willing to patiently wait 30 minutes or more? 

At Blue Bottle, coffee isn't just caffeine in a cup - it's a carefully crafted creation of the best brew in the business. Here they use only the best certified organic coffees, fresh from the farm and full of flavor. They take great pride in the process of producing the perfect cup for each customer.

Blue Bottle's bar in the ferry building serves up a simple menu of espresso drinks, drip coffee, and their New Orleans iced coffee. They also offer an assortment of baked goods and breakfast items.  The shop also carries Blue Bottle's line of artisan coffee beans - if you are crafty enough to attempt creating a cup at home.  

Fresh . Rich . Delicious . Coffee like this shouldn't be missed!
author: Caroline J.

description:
Gasp. Not a good time to try their coffee. The weekend crowd line was 10 bodies deep waiting to purchase a cup.  I bought into the hype after reading a newspaper article about how great the coffee is and that their baristers decorate the foam, and that they do and beautifully at that.  

However, oh, so NOT worth the $4.50 extravagance I spent for a mocha coffee even if he decorated a lovely heart in my foam.  Hey, it's Mother's Day, my treat to myself after sharing another expensive treat, a Miette cupcake, with hubby.  And, Happy Mother's Day to you Yelper moms out there.   They advertise that they use their neighbor, M. Recchiuti chocolate in the mocha, I saw him pour some into the bottom of the cup but for the life of me, there was only a hint of chocolate and I had to strain to taste it.  At that rate, give me Starbucks, give me Peets!  At least I can taste their chocolate, even if it's only syrup.  Worse yet, I love my coffee hot, and this cup was lukewarm.

Hubby agreed that he couldn't taste the chocolate flavor either and the coffee had a bitter finish.  Thumbs down from the both of us, and he said he'll take Folger's instant coffee anyday over this cup o' Joe.  I did buy a bag of beans, Chapada Diamantina.  (I brewed this on another day and found the flavor of the coffee to be oaky tasting but not great.)

The cashier tried to look for 2 other beans for me and when she opened 2 cabinets, the shelves were completely empty.  Old Mother Hubbard, the shelves were empty and bare.  At $15/lb, this coffee bean had better be good.  As far as organic coffee goes, the best cup I've had was in Healdsburg, The Flying Goat, which clearly doesn't cost so much even if they don't draw milk pictures on top of your cup of java.
author: Ry T.

description:
The good: Coffee was smooth. The flavor was not bitter at all. 

The bad: Wait time. Wait time in proportion to price. Wait time in proportion to price and very rude service. The guy who made my coffee was nice; it's his coworker who is very curt and needs to find a new job.
author: Ruiqiu K.

description:
Fantastic.  The mocha, made with Rechutti chocolate is heaven in a cup and beautiful, with the leaf-like design in the foam.  It tastes like the most amazing dark chocolate bar, though it is served at bit cooler than most coffee drinks I have had.

The lines are usually on the longer side, but worth it--and since I am unemployed, what better things do I have to do but wait in line?

The drip is amazing as well.
author: Gretchen J.

description:
The brown bag lunch was the best lunch I've ever had, period.    Coffee is delicious and worth short wait

The Brown Bag Lunch wasn't the sad PB&J from Grammar School with a few chips and carrot chunks.   It was an amazing gourmet sandwich roll with Cowgirl Creamery cheese, natural turkey, shaved celery.

Combined with parmesan crackers, strawberries and cream , Couscous salad with fresh tomatoes and cucumbers in lemon and good chocolate cookie it was delicious
author: William G.

description:
Preface: I don't drink coffee.
Reason for going: Dad likes strong coffee.
Mood upon getting in line: Wary. Long line.
Mood after being in line 20 minutes: ...
Service: Good when I finally got to talk to them. There seemed to be a problem with one of the machines, but even with three people I don't think it should have taken that long.

There are some tasty lookin' pastries. They also have a few non-coffee drinks. I bought some beans roasted the previous day and they smelled excellent all the way home on BART. Pricey, but a good gift for coffee-lovers. The help really knows their stuff so if you have something you like, ask for a recommendation. If you're coffee enthusiast you can buy different coffee-making contraptions here, too.
author: Amy N.

description: I feel lucky. We arrived on a Wednesday, around 10am and the line was very short. I ordered a cafe au lait, and took a picture of the cute "heart" that seems to be their "schtick".  Nice touch.  I bought a bag of coffee to take home, which is a bit pricey. However, it's worth it.  The coffee isn't acidic at all.   Very friendly service, and a nice treat to enjoy their coffee  while strolling along the shops.  My credit card and I had a great time.
author: Debby F.

description: After planning on ordering a mocha, I was persuaded to try the New Orleans style iced coffee. While the coffee itself was very good quality, I didn't like the drink and I was concerned about not being given a lid.
author: Katie O.

description: The coffee was quite unforgettable, it's gentle, soft and smooth. I was easily addicted but it's a happy accident. The desserts were great. It would make a perfect afternoon sitting here with a cup of refined coffee at hand.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
I think the only thing not to like about Blue Bottle Coffee Co. is the line.  Other than that, it's a definite winner.  Blue Bottle serves of the best lattes I've ever had, hands down.  I've got an espresso machine at home, and I can only wish I had the equipment or the skills to create an espresso drink so frothy and rich.

I've also been to the kiosk and the siphon station on Mint.  I've reviewed both, and while I thought they were alright, I think I like this location the most.  There are just a ton of other things to do while you're at the ferry building, and a blue bottle drink is the perfect compliment for a casual bay-side stroll.  What pushes Blue Bottle over the top is the fact that the espresso drinks here are virtually the same price you'd pay at Starbucks or Peets, only the quality is helluvalot better.

As my girlfriend and I made our way back to the parking lot after a fine morning at the ferry building, I found myself savoring every last frothy sip of our Blue Bottle latte.  I think when you enjoy something this much, it's definitely earned its stars.
author: Tony L.

description: The Ferry Building is one of my favorite eating destinations in SF. And that includes coffee. Blue Bottle makes a great drip coffee and although the price may be steep for a cup ($3), it is worth the price. Each cup is individually dripped taking about 3-5 minutes to brew but the coffee is strong and flavorful. No artificial sweeters here so don't go looking for any Splenda on the counter. The baristas and friendly and helpful with suggestions and recommendations. Grab a seat at the coffee bar or table around the corner and enjoy all the people watching you can muster.
author: Calvin G.

description: So good and smooth. Drip and cafe au lait were super yummy.
author: Carla T.

description:
Love this place.
On that note, does anyone know what blend they use in their lattes?
author: caramel c.

description: I gave up coffee but occasionally slip up when I smell a delicious cup of coffee.  We came here and luckily there was a line of 2 people ahead of us.  When he finished ordering our mocha drink, there was a line of 8 behind us! I could not believe how many fans this place has!!! But after trying the coffee, I can see why people line up for this stuff. It was really cool how the barrista made the foam in our cup of coffee look like  a leaf!! The coffee was smooth and delicious!
author: Janet E.

description: OK OK... I found a Crazy Great Coffee Place!! So Happy Love Love Love this coffee! Its Rich, Inviting has a Robust Aroma Wonderful Taste. I found a coffee that's close to New York Coffee,  GREAT Cup of Joe STRONG LIKE CRACK LOL it gives you a kick in the butt !  Another Plus Is they drip the coffee fresh right in front of you. I'm In Love
author: Sera O.

description:
I'm a big time coffee drinker (no sweetener or cream, thank-you-very-much) and am always looking to try different stores, brands, kiosks, where ever I am; Blue Bottle is the best coffee I've ever had. It may take a little longer to get your coffee, but like waiting for a draught Guinness to settle, the anticipation and then finally getting the first sip is well worth it.

It was full-bodied, rich, and oh so very smooth. Actually it's a good thing there aren't any locations where I live as it would become a serious addiction!
author: Jason C.

description: Second time getting coffee at Blue Bottle Coffee. I'm no expert at coffee but from what I've had here, I really like it!  This particular visit was to try to gibraltar (the 2010 big eats SF) Beautiful foam art ontop and with some added sugar (I cant drink coffee straight) it was really good! I didn't see the gibraltar on the menu so it must be one of those special drinks where you have to know about it or hear about it.
author: Katherine C.

description: Blue Bottle Coffee is the BEST coffee, EVER, hands down!! Give it a try...I promise you will not regret it!! I wish/hope they become the next Starbucks, since Starbucks reallyyyyyyy sucks!!!
author: Mandi C.

description: their New Orleans Style Iced Coffee makes me soooooooooo happy! Best iced coffee ever! So smooth & perfectly sweetened (not too sweet :) I really want to try their Belgian waffle sometime, too!
author: C K.

description:
Disappointment & Dissatisfaction 


If you are going to go for the custom single drip coffee, why not use enough grind to make a decent cup?   Outside of the fact the coffee was about as strong as tea colored Folgers; the flavor was off- overly acidic ground leather boot flavor to be exact.  

This spot if off and I won't be back, go to Peets in Embarcadero and hook up a decent cup of coffee and free wifi as the icing on the cake.
author: todd b.

description: Get in and get out. Located in the Embarcadero station, this place is simple and efficient. Since I don't drink coffee I opted for the hot chocolate. Really, it's hot cocoa with just the right amount of bitterness from real cocoa powder (not that artificial syrup n' stuff). It's a far cry from the remorseless machine that is Starbucks. They actually take pride in each cup of joe they brew. If you are a TRUE coffee aficionado and actually enjoy the TASTE of coffee, then check out this little gem. I hear the line gets SUPER long on weekend, so visit during the week and skip the crowds.
author: L2 L.

description: I'm a coffee and latte person, so tried a cafe latte and drip coffee at this place. Both were good, but the dripped coffee was a bit too strong for me. However, love the latte here (with soy). Tip: They have two lines, but both are usually long. Expect at least waiting 15-20 mins during peak hours.
author: Samantha C.

description: Best coffee in San Francisco, but it does vary from good to great depending on which barista is working. The lines are always long, long, long so you have to be willing to wait. Get the Gibralter - it's my favourite!
author: C H.

description:
Yum!

I very much enjoyed my cafe mocha. It's a very simple drink but also made well. It wasn't too strong and it wasn't overly sweet with sweeteners and syrup. It even tasted healthier. I also did not have a drag or crash after having my coffee. 

Would come here again if I lived there...
author: Kat T.

description:
The drip coffee was acceptable, but not up to Philz standards of perfection. However the Affogato with Humphry Slocombe Maple Walnut ice cream was delightful. Dessert and coffee all in the same bowl. What could be better?

My companion had the cappuccino, which he rated as very good.
author: Richard P.

description:
A little over-the-top when it comes to coffee snobbery (for example you can get a macchiato but you can't get it "to go" but you can get a dry cap "to go"), but I keep coming back because it is the best macchiato in downtown SF and they make pretty hearts with the foam.  Their beans are roasted fresh and definitely worth buying if you make espresso at home.  The cold brew is delish in the summer and I have never found another one as good.  

Don't let a short line fool you though, they will serve you whenever they feel like it and they are often faster when they are busy.
author: Tracy M.

description:
I've been eagerly waiting for this Blue Bottfle cafe to open since the wallpaper / sign has been put up at the Ferry Plaza.  Hopefully having this permanent cafe will divert a bit of the traffic from the other 2 kiosks on Saturday.  The location is beautiful and centrally located, it'll be great for the ferry riding guest and saturday rush crowds.  

Get the SG-120 if you want heaven in a glass, or the Gibraltar if you're daring.
author: matt c.

description:
Seems that this is the hippest new spot in SF.

I'm just here to concur with most people:  the coffee is good, the packaging is cute, the servers are awkward, smart-looking hipsters that I want to be friends with.

However, if you don't like it, that helps the rest of us out, because those lines ain't short, that's for sure.
author: Chelsee H.

description: Yes there is a line. We went in the middle of the afternoon and the line stretched 10 people deep. Patience is a virtue. Service is slow, but it's a hand crafted drink. We ordered a Caffé Latte, Caffé Mocha and the New Orleans style iced coffee. All the drinks were good. The New Orleans Style iced coffee was a perfect concoction of caffeine in a cup.
author: A D.

description:
Long wait, but you have to wait for quality right?  Rich, flavorful coffee.  Each cup is individually dripped and you can taste the difference.

It's a little pricey, not something you can get everyday.  But if you need an afternoon treat, grab a drink from here and enjoy the great view from the Ferry Building.
author: Brent T.

description: This has to be the best coffee in San Fran...I'm an Aussie from Melbourne and we love our coffee! Definitely worth the wait in line. 4 stars and not 5?  If I had the option of drinking it from a cup it would be perfect.
author: Suzanne H.

description:
For a second, I thought I was back in Italy. There was no where to sit, but then, ah! a stool at the bar opened up. I expected them to add a euro for me to sit, but then I remembered I was actually in friendly San Francisco.
Amazing espresso, prepared by hot coffee aficionados with attitude, with just the right amount of crema on top. Oh and the view is nice: so many pretty people with their farmer's market baskets, cameras and flowers. I will return for many a cuppa joe.
author: Kyla L.

description: Service was a little slow but only because they take care of their customers. Coffee was good and O would come here again.
author: Mike K.

description:
Honestly, I don't know what all the fuss is about. (Full disclosure: I might have more research to do).

I'd been hearing and reading about Blue Bottle Coffee since I set foot in San Francisco, so while showing my gf around the Saturday morning farmer's market at the Ferry Building, I stood in line for about 20 minutes or more just to try a New Orleans style iced coffee.

The verdict? Well, t's certainly not bad coffee, but it's not spectacular either. And for $3.50 I got a medium cup full to the brim with ice, which didn't leave much room for liquid. I drank as slowly as possible, trying to savor the moment, but still finished the drink in less time that it had taken me to stand in line.

I have to say that I was at Farm:Table earlier in the week and had THEIR iced coffee and was blown away. Talk about perfect bitter to sweet ratio. It was bomb.

Now as a coffee fanatic I certainly haven't given up on Blue Bottle. I'll be back to try their other offerings besides the N'Orleans iced. I haven't even tried any of their coffee blends, hot and black. And I will. 

But I don't think you'll catch me waiting in a long line again for cup.



,
author: Ben B.

description: A stop-over at Blue Bottle always brightens my day. The line is always long but the service is polite and speedy :)
author: Nicole M.

description:
This coffee is the tops, the primo, the best, the shiiiizzzzznit! I love love love this coffee, would give them 10 stars!! They have a lil' kiosk that has opened in the Ferry Building which is the best news ever!

My best girlfriend Mac, gave me a 1/2 pound of their beans for my birthday and I have been hoarding it from my husband (NO, you can't have ANY! Mine mine mine!)

Try some of their delicious coffee now!
author: Ingrid K.

description: Solid place to get coffee.  I had a cup of their drip, which they serve as pourover individually.  While 2.75 is not cheap for a cup of black coffee, pourover is definitely worth it.  Good coffee, can't wait to try out their beans at home.
author: Josh W.

description:
The employees are smart and not pretentious. A guy asked whether the container had cream, and the worker said no it was half and half, but he wasn't smarmy about it at all!

They make patterns with the foam if you get a drink that has it.

They play the best music. They were playing Holly Golightly this morning. I never thought I would hear that in a coffee place.

They sell granola that's super neat0. They also sell beans in eight-ounce bags, which is nice because by the time you get through a pound bag the beans are old anyway.
author: Joel E.

description: In love with the New Orleans Style Ice Coffee! Went there a couple times on our trip to SF. The brew was just so smooth and perfectly, lightly sweetened. But be prepared for really long lines! Really wish they had a location in Chicago...
author: Judy H.

description: I'm not a huge coffee person, but I really wanted to like this place since the single drip coffee making process looks so cool! I got the iced coffee, and it was okay - kind of bitter for me.
author: Melody L.

description: I just spent $5 with tip for a latte that I waited 15 mins for - and NO - it was not crazy busy like it usually is - anyway, the guy used the wrong milk and when I asked him about he just looked at me as if I was from another planet.  Sorry Blue Bottle  - not so happy with your service - or complete lack it. And I would have preferred if the barista would have quickly offered to make my latte the way I ordered it.
author: Tina P.

description:
Disclaimer: this place has good coffee and I would have given BBCC more stars, except I just tried their "brown bag lunch" and am left rather displeased.  For $12, the lunch included a very small (and we're talking VERY SMALL) turkey roll that didn't impress--more cheese and fennel than tomato and turkey.  Also, after having walked back to my office and opening the lunch bag, realized that one of the 5 lunch components was mistakenly excluded.  (!!!)  So, in addition to overpaying for a small lunch, I was jipped of an item.  
I can at least say that i've tried BBCC for lunch--but I sure won't recommend it, nor return.
author: Valerie F.

description: their mochas are good from what my friend tells me but for me, i go for the simple coffee. Well their ice coffee that is..i dunno what they put..prob the chicory they use but man that is delicious! i dont need to add anything when i get it. sooo GOOD! my favorite!!!! i wish it came in bigger size cuz i could drink that all day! love theres two sides but ppl seem to line up only on one side...i go onto the other side since its faster! but i like to take my drink then sit on the pier and people watch..gorgeous on a warm day! :D thats the life!
author: Angela C.

description:
I don't care how much I am ridiculed for saying so, but Intelligentsia (LA) is better. Especially the Angeleno vs. the New Orleans Iced. However, it is still great coffee and bonus for having ah-mazing Strauss family creamery yogurt parfaits in little jelly jars with strawberry compote and pistachios. *perfect breakfast*

The baristas are much friendlier than their LA counterparts, however.
author: Gina Q.

description:
The coffee is so smooth. The best coffee I've tasted really. I'm not really sure why all coffee can't be this way. 

The menu is limited in comparison to Starbucks, but I think they take pride in that. There's one size of latte, etc. I really like the lattes and the New Orleans Iced Coffee, which is made without heat. There's also fancy snacks you can buy. The hot chocolate is also really tasty, very rich and not overly sweet.

There will be a line when you go, but it usually moves pretty quickly. I'm willing to wait 10 minutes for this coffee.
author: Grace Y.

description:
I loooooove Blue Bottle Coffee. Their lattes are amazing and the affogato is TO DIE FOR! Blue Bottle Coffee is a local coffee shop that vows to serve coffee only 48 hours out of the roaster. You can't get any better than that!

The scene:

This location of BBC is a storefront in the Ferry Building. It's across from Ciao Bella Gelato and both stores have insane lines. At times, it can be nearly impossible to pass through to the other end of the Ferry Building.

Behind the counter, you can see how they make their own drip coffee. Instead of an ole coffee maker, they use their own filtering system in which hot water is poured over a rack filled with filters and coffee grinds. The coffee then drips out of the filter and into a cup. Check out my photo below and you'll see what I mean.

The food:

Drinks aren't that cheap in Blue Bottle. You still have to pay anywhere between $3-5 for a cup of coffee/espresso.

Latte - The lattes are so beautiful. The barista creates a fancy heart or flower shaped design in your cup using the coffee and milk. I have to knock off a point just because the latte is never hot when I get it.

Affogato - Mmmm.... I seriously need to stop myself from getting this as a midday snack during work. BBC uses the Breakfast Secret (bourbon ice cream with cornflakes) ice cream from SF's Humphrey Slocombe and pours a shot of espresso right on top. The espresso melts and mixes in with the ice cream and makes the coffee both sweet and creamy. Downside is that it costs $5.50.
author: Sam L.

description: This is by far the best coffee I have ever had anywhere. My favorite is the iced coffee which has a splash of organic milk and I never take dairy in my coffee!
author: Raymond L V.

description:
Stopped by here while at the Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market, because I just had to. So glad I did.

I ordered the drop coffee, which is made individually with precision. You can tell in the taste -- so good! Best coffee I've had in the city yet. I bought a bag of fresh-roasted beans which smelled delicious all the way home.

Someone else ordered the Gibraltar, which isn't on the menu but looked beautiful. I'd forgotten to order this, but will order next time.
author: Leo B.

description: The first time I tried Blue Bottle was a few weeks ago at the Ferry Building Farmer's Market on the weekend.  There was a very long line and after getting my latte and waffle, I realized there was another side to the cafe with yet another line and ANOTHER cart set up outside with all the vendors.  I wish I could contain enough caffeine to try the other drinks that day but I stopped at one drink.  I tried my friend's iced coffee called the New Orleans and it was pretty refreshing on such a hot day in the city.  I wish they had some more chains down in the Peninsula.  It would do well in Palo Alto... I can only wish because I would probably get this on my way into work.  Definitely going back to bring my friends!
author: K. C.

description: Hands down the best latte I've ever had!!!!! AMAZING!!!!!! My latte was so velvety and smooth. I just hope one day there will be a Blue Bottle in San Jose.
author: Selina S.

description:
i prefer visiting the alley in hayes valley any day.  the deliciousness of their soy latte is best in the embarcadero.  the waiting 15-20 minutes for something i'll drink in less than five minutes is the downfall at this location.  at their hayes valley location, especially on a weekend, the line is just as deep and 1/4 of the wait.  and this location services TWO lines.  

on every occasion, since starting to work downtown the past month, I have witnessed the kitchen help just waiting for a waffle order and 1-2 other employees just lounging around.  this seems to be the biggest complaint to the low ratings of this place; its slow service.  i'm not expecting a drip coffee or my latte upon ordering a la other "fast coffee" joints.  it's become the norm in SF that good food comes to those who wait; but the wait is a bit ridiculous here.  since most complaints on slow service are dating back as 2010 for this location, obviously this corporate coffee joint seems not to care.  yes, by SF planning law they would be considered corporate.  they've just become "smart" to mask their namesake by serving their coffee at locations under different business names.  even the planning department knows this trick.  

on a final not to you fair ferry building baristas: you only work in a shop.  you can drop the attitude.  you just steam milk and pour hot water.
author: Boho H.

description: Hands down the best coffee in the Bay Area. It is excellent! I love their Mocha made with the TCHO chocolate.
author: Megan B.

description: The coffee is the best and people are pretty good too.  The only exception is the line is always a 15 minutes or more wait.  If you walk down the street to Plant Organics Restaurant or go to TCHO Chocolate, they have Blue Bottle Coffee with no real wait.
author: Michael N.

description:
Boss and I ordered 2 regular cups of coffee.  She's been raving about this place and when she found out there was one at the Ferry building we decided to go during lunch.   

All in all, we were fairly disappointed.  Maybe it's because the place was so busy, the cups we got were so watered down that it felt like they reused the grinds for a previous cup.  

Dark and full body it was not.  I'll give it a second shot tomorrow and will change the review if necessary.  I'll try to head there during off peak hours, but since this place is in a tourist attraction that'll be difficult to achieve. 

Dirt Cowboy in Hanover is still the best I've had and they raised the bar pretty high.  Same concept but they have 15-20 different types of beans you can choose from ranging from light - dark roast, regional as well as organic.
author: J T.

description: very nice cafe au lait. brought my friend there and she had the best mocha ever too.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
The combination of the "I'm too sexy for you" Hipster staff, and the "Oh look, a cool coffee place" Tourist crowd create the perfect storm for a long wait.

Would you wait  40 minutes for a coffee drink? By the time I ordered and received my drink I may have been eligible for medicare benefits and perhaps a senior citizen discount.

Their coffee tastes great, though their cappuccino with the high concentration of milk tastes more like a LATTE.
author: M E.

description: Oh blue bottle why are you so irresistible? I'm such a coffee lightweight and know that if I have any after 3 pm I would be up all night. But there you were, smelling so good on a sunny Sunday evening that I just had to have you. Now it is 2 a.m. and I'm awake writing yelp reviews in bed, unable to fall asleep. I can still smell your aroma, taste your richness and feel the buzz you generate. Mmm if I promise to dream of you tonight, would you let me get some sleep next time? :P
author: Sarah L.

description: Oh-my-gooness! Just had my first made drink here (opposed to drip) and it was Heaven! I had a regular latte with non-fat milk and I don't think I have ever had anything like it. I am the type of person who likes a little coffee with my creamer, meaning I like it sweet. Considering I am not typically a sweets person, coffee, lattes, and cappuccinos are my form of diet kryptonite. My latte was perfect and did not even need one drip of sugar or sweetness and it was sooo creamy that if I had not seen her put the organic nonfat in my drink, I might have accidentally spit it out on the barrista (*kidding). Non-fat latte that tastes like it was made with cream? This must be what Heaven tastes like!
author: Brandy B.

description:
The best coffee I've ever had.

Not only is it organic, its also locally roasted right here in the bay (Oakland to be exact)

The staff is nice and knowledgeable especially when you are not sure on what kind of beans you want to get.  Its a coffee-junkie's green heaven.

The coffee comes in half pound bags that are about $8/piece and come in paper bags that are compostable after use.  The best is just picking up the bag and you can smell the awesome coffee aroma just waft out of the bag.

I highly support Blue bottle's mission and its excellent coffee.  I'd have to say the coffee made right there always tastes better than the blue bottle I make at home, so defintely take a cup home with you.
author: Kameron K.

description: The first time I heard of Blue Bottle was at Humphry Slocombe; I particularly enjoyed the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee flavor. I came across the actual coffee shop while walking through the Ferry Building and ordered the New Orleans style iced coffee. The coffee tasted a hint sour to me. I was slightly disappointed, but my friend who had the Cafe au Lait did not seem to have the same problem. At any  rate, I'll probably give this place another shot when I'm back in the area.
author: C K.

description:
