Um, hi: BEST ICED COFFEE I'VE EVER HAD.

That is all.
author: John S.

description: These arrogant pricks don't deserve to be in business. I wish they would leave and free the space for another coffee shop. Yes, the coffee is great, but every time I have to deal with them, I'm treated with a disheartening level of pompousness. I've refrained from writing about it, but today was the last straw. I went to the booth at the Tue Ferry Building Market and I asked for a Gibraltar. Then, I told him I'd be right back, as I'd run to get cash b/c I was in a hurry to get to a meeting. He refused to make the Gibraltar and told me I'd have to wait in line and start again. After I got the cash, I waited in line again. He saw me there. He ignored me the whole time. I waited for 20 minutes, and then, all my free time was finished, and I had to leave to get to a meeting. No coffee.
author: Eater S.

description:
The soy lattes are the best I've ever had. It's like drinking art.

It must be good for a cranky wretch like me to voluntarily brave the packs of asshole tourists, the tacky craft merchants, the pretentious Ferry Building shoppers, and the constantly long lines. Blue Bottle lives up the hype.
author: Stumbalina b.

description:
It's all about the beans.  These beans do not make you toot.  The more you drink though the more you will totally be off the wall and quite possibly get arrest because the POPO will think you are on crack.

I don't drink coffee, but this is a dam good cup of caffe mocha.
author: Po L.

description: OH YES! Hands DOWN the BEST coffee in the Bay area! My husband got me a Jura coffee maker for Christmas and we found that the Bella Donovan is the best coffee to use in that machine. DELICIOUS and SOOO smooth and no bitterness at all!!
author: Maryellen O.

description: The Affogato with Humphry Slocombe is a must have. Flavorful coffee on of the rich and creamy Slocombe.
author: Arun V.

description: The coffee is good, but not goodbye-30-minutes-of-my-life-waiting-in-line good.  I'll give it another go once the waffle maker is working. I don't believe I've ever had a waffle that wasn't worth a little wait, especially if there's a decent cup of coffee coming along with it.
author: Lynn M.

description: Tried the Mexico Chiapas, Three Africans, and Bella Donna blends. All were excellent. Best coffee ever.
author: Mara B.

description:
I have an excellent taste for a superior coffee and I can say that Blue Bottle makes the best cappuccino I have ever had outside of Rome. 

The espresso shot and the brewing temperature is precisely to the bean they are using, the milk is the best cream ever - this is so special because a cup of milk is made for each cappuccino. The barista designs that dress the top of the cappuccino it's different for each customer, making it unbelievable!

The line for the coffee was long but it was worth it. Needles to say the service was great. We believe the Blue Bottle is over the top a complete overblown cappuccino experience.
author: Gigi W.

description: Chump city!  The coffee is under-roasted swill.  The 'baristas' are d-bag, hipsters with crap attitudes and there's always a line of tools.  Even their gear is way over-priced.  They certainly know how to draw out those tools, though.
author: Lester B.

description:
I took a 4 month hiatus from coffee but have found myself back in its clutches.   It's not an all out obsession, but some mornings (read: afternoons) when I've crawled into bed only 4 hours before, the coffee helps gets things going lest I stay indoors all day sprawled out on the floor of my apartment in perpetual exhaustion.

Coffee seems to also help after yoga when all I want to do is lie down in Savasana for another hour or so.

Tuesday Farmers Market has me in the Ferry Building after yoga and this week I noticed Blue Bottle.  I had heard they had built one here but had never seen it.  Amidst the crowds with their biobags bursting with peaches, blueberries and apricots I decided to brave the longish line.  I've braved the line at the BBC in Linden Alley on many occasion, so why not?

It only took about 15 minutes to get to the front and I made the mistake of ordering an ice coffee which had surprise dairy in it (is this what makes it New Orleans Style?  There was no trace of chicory in it at all, which is what I thought gave NOLA style coffee their distinctive taste).

With the mob of people behind me, I decided to pick and choose my battles wisely and accepted my cup o' cold coffee and milk and went on my way.  I'm just glad there were no residual after effects from the beverage.  I haven't had milk in anything since the beginning of this year. Yay for avoiding dairy fallout!

With the reappearance of coffee back into my life i am realizing I can no longer go el cheapo on the stuff.  I will admit it.  I would rather go without if it's not BBC, Ritual or 4Barrell. I'm definitely not hip nor bougie enough to fit the coffee snob stereotype, but my taste buds are.

Oh, and Emma's, the coffee shop a block from my house. But only for soy lattes.  

Ugh.  I sound like people I usually hate.  But oh well.
author: Jen I.

description:
What's the big deal?

I was visiting SF, and my friends pointed out that Blue Bottle coffee had just opened.  Usually, a long line is indicative of something great.  This time, it was just a long line due to slow servers.  I've bumped it up to two stars, only because I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt that it is a new store, still working out the kinks.

And the coffee?  It's coffee.  No big deal.
author: Tom W.

description:
Blue Bottle turned me into a regular coffee drinker. This stuff is the smoothest, richest, most legal form of crack you'll ever have. Once you go Blue, you never go back.

The lines are bad and bound to remain that way as more and more people catch on to this new Ferry Building location BUT it's more than worth it for one of their lattes.

Also, try any of the baked goods they offer. The chocolate cookie pairs perfectly with espresso drinks.
author: Claire G.

description:
I am Sooooooooooo disappointed in the new blue bottle cafe in the ferry building. I was really really hoping for a good experience as I have had int eh past at the farmers markets or at their linden street location.

The Saturday market guys were always great and I really looked forward to the new space, but after my experience today, blue bottle lost my business and I will not go back.

I ordered a latte and a single cappuccino with my wife and when they came up the drinks were luke warm...and my cappuccino was more of a latte, barely any foam on top and again very much luke warm.  I tried to deal with it, but after two sips I had to go back and ask for them to please remake it as it was just not enjoyable.

Here is where they started to lose me as a customer:  

As I was standing there waiting to ask for a new coffee a woman was standing next to me waiting for her drink and she asked me what I wanted to ask them.  I told her that my cappuccino was more of a latte and more importantly it was cold.  She told me that this has happened with her drinks 3 times so far and she is also disappointed in the new blue bottle.  NOT A GOOD START.

Here is where they lost me as a customer, the guy who was there making the coffee, i did not get his name, if I did I would post it here, but he was kind of stand-offish.

I pointed out that it was luke warm and that for a cappuccino there was very little foam and I would like a cappuccino and not a latte.  I asked him if he could remake it and his response to me was and I am not making this up.
"yeah, we make our coffees not hot and only luke warm here, I only steam the milk to 135, that way customers can drink it right down."

well, I personally like a hot cup of coffee, and so did the woman next to me.

anyhow, he made me a new one, which was hot enough...but still NO FOAM...again just a latte.  if you want a latte, blue bottle Embarcadero may be a good bet for you, but be sure to ask for it hot.

if I want a cappuccino I will go to Peet's instead from now on if I am in the Ferry Building.

Sorry Blue bottle.
author: Greg F.

description:
I know that Blue Bottle is supposed to be the best cup of coffee around, but is it really worth the wait?  I don't think that it's good enough to regularly wait 45 minutes to get a cup of coffee.  That being said, it's a really great cup of coffee and definitely worth trying that one time.  I'm pretty much over the line though now, especially on Saturday morning's at the Farmer's Market.  

I like the Gibraltar in a glass if you have time to hang out for a bit (after the wait).  I always get my espresso drinks extra hot because I think that they are a little tepid for my taste.  The drip coffee is excellent but strong, so be prepared.  

I swung by earlier today ( much better on weekdays at odd times as far as the line is concerned ) and just found out that they serve food for lunch now.  The menu changes each week and features other Ferry Building shops like ACME and Cowgirl Creamery.  Will definitely need to try that for lunch one of these days (but at 11:00 before the line gets too crazy).
author: Brian L.

description:
I happen to be in the city on an early Sunday morning and stopped by a local cafe in the Inner Sunset region and had a cup of their drip coffee. It was ok. Nothing spectacular. Nothing WOW! Thinking it was just the way the cafe prepared it, about 1.5 hr later, I ended up at the Ferry Building and decided to give it another chance. I braved the long line and this time, I ordered their New Orleans Iced Coffee. 

My first impression as I saw them grab a paper cup, fill it to the brim with ice, and pour pre-brewed coffee from a plastic unmarked container, was "DAMMIT!! I just paid $3.75 for day-old iced coffee." But immediately after my first sip, each unrelenting sip that followed melted away my initial impression and while the $3.75 price point is a bit much for an approx 8oz iced coffee (or any coffee at that), it's definitely a treat whenever I'm in town.
author: J C.

description: Always 5 stars for Blue Bottle.  Great service and worth the wait in line.  Every cup is perfection!
author: April M.

description:
This is not a reflection on the quality and tastiness of Blue Bottle coffee. 

Stopped by this location today to pick up some coffee for my coffee maker at home. I usually buy my beans elsewhere, but I thought this is on the way to BART why not?!? 

I approach the counter and ask if they take credit cards because I'd like to buy some coffee for my machine at home. The guy says sure and then follows it up with, but we don't have what you are looking for (most unpleasantly). 

Now my response should have been, you're right you don't. But I replied, "well actually you do." 

"Oh you drink decaf?" he asks slightly annoyed. 

"No, espresso please. Also would you grind the beans for espresso," I say. 

This clearly offended him as he first slightly mocked me and questioned," You make espresso at home? Well then you should know that you shouldn't grind the beans before you make the espresso. Furthermore it's against our policy to grind beans." 

W-O-W! The first statement wasn't enough? I also am the lucky recipient of a tutorial on coffee making from the baritsa with an attitude problem? Must be my lucky day! 

I thank him for his "assistance" and walk away thinking... what's the store policy on turning customers off of the brand or store location?
author: Lindsay W.

description: Blue Bottle has the best espresso in SF.  Their New Orleans-style iced coffee is equally awesome.  The Ferry Building location is great for its proximity to other eateries (Acme, Cowgirl, Prather Ranch) but can get ridiculously crowded midday on weekends and weekday mornings.
author: Steve K.

description:
Soooo, based on their coffee and the art of making it, these guys get 5 stars.

Based on the blonde woman behind the counter who was 1) rude 2) sloooooowwwwwwww as hell and 3) couldn't understand a "double mocha" order, they get 1 star.

It averages out to 3.
author: Michael D.

description: We made the mistake of heading to blue bottle on Saturday morning... I think we waited in line for about 20 minutes. The line around the corner was already just as long as the main one. That being said, I would totally wait again. Everyone there was super friendly (is it just me or is that the way everyone in SF is?) and the coffee was awesome. It packs a lot of punch but you would have no idea because of how smooth it is. I ordered the Gibraltar (not on menu) which came in an oversized shot glass and was the best espresso-like drink I have come by. No sweetness here. Just creamy coffee goodness.
author: Kerry C.

description:
Just like their location on the SF MoMA rooftop, Blue Bottle @ the ferry building does not disappoint. 

This locale was jumpin' with java jones-ers. Line moved a little slowly, but one employee came out to remind everyone that just around the corner was another order counter. That helped a bit. 

My cafe au lait was the perfect hot temp and had a lovely design in the steamed milk foam. 

Sure, it's a bit expensive for a basically Starbucks tall-sized cup, but the flavor/quality is worth it to me. 

This location also has a nice selection of retail products, including their signature ceramic dripper. May have to get me one of those.
author: Liz K.

description:
As my wife and I wandered through the Ferry Building one day during our recent trip to San Francisco, we noticed a long line waiting to get coffee at Blue Bottle.  That piqued my interest.  I figured that if people were waiting so long for a drink, it must be pretty good.  We had lunch from another vendor in the building, then walked around the farmer's market outside.  

Before moving on to our next stop, we decided to go back and get some caffeine from Blue Bottle.  By this time, the line was much shorter, and it was just a short wait before we got our cappuccinos.

The thing I noticed immediately was that the cappuccinos were immediately drinkable.  Oftentimes coffee drinks are served way too hot (I'm looking at you, Starbucks), and you have to wait several minutes for them to cool down enough to not burn your mouth. 

We both agreed the drinks were very good.  This is the place I would go to get coffee if I was a local.  I wish there was a location in DC!
author: Brian H.

description: Nothing short of extraordinary, and situated in an extraordinary place. I sit in my tropical outpost here in Palm Beach and X the days off my calendar until I get to come back and have another sip of blue bottle on the Embarcadero!
author: Brian P.

description:
long lines...
loud crowd and crying children...
paying $3 for a drip coffee...

drinking the drip coffee - makes me forget about the long lines, loud crowd and the price of it immediately.  

freaking good coffee period.
author: Mike P.

description:
love the location and their délicieuxly made coffee and treats. ..

+ :  solid cup of coffee. .. ginger molasses cookie - just delish and perfectly made - even with a few ginger fibers. .. beautiful coffee art. .. nice little shop within shop for uniquely interesting coffee-related products. ..

- :  can get quite busy therefore long wrapping line and not too many seats to have treats there. ..

wish they were closer to home. ..

for FüN. .. had a Bar Gelato by Naia, specifically their * Blue Bottle Coffee * gelato bar, with a cup of warm Blue Bottle latte. .. man~oh~man, heavenly. .. :))
author: Y I L I W.

description:
The new full storefront Ferry Bulling location is open. The coworkers and I checked it out yesterday because it's possible that it's a tad closer than the Mint Plaza location.

Rest assured it's business as usual at Blue Bottle. New Orleans Iced Coffee is still doin' its thing and the rest of your BB favorites can be payed for and enjoyed as well. 

What's missing? No cool chemistry sets, I mean, coffee makers and for some reason the little brioche pastries are $2 more expensive than the same brioche pastries at the Mint Plaze location ("why would I pay $6 for a piece of brioche?" so sayeth a wise coworker). Guess the Ferry Building has some steep rent that needs to be covered. 

Linden is still my favorite, but I like that the Ferry Building location has 2 separate counters at which to order one's crazy expensive, albeit tasty, coffee beverage.
author: Alexis W.

description: Tried New Orleans Iced Coffee... Very smooth with just a hint of chicory.
author: Irina N.

description:
Coffee is great. Service is terrible. 

I'll take my cappuccino please, hold the attitude!! 

And what's with the 25 minute wait??!! If the service was good I would go back, the coffee really is good. But methinks not.....Sorry blue bottle
author: Nicole L.

description: The coffee WAS amazing, both the drip and the espresso were very pleasing! The line moved quickly and the staff was super friendly- sweet spot in the ferry building--- now serving waffles?! I'll have to try one next time... yum.
author: Coco J.

description: My favorites at Blue Bottle are the New Orleans iced coffee and the Belgian waffle. The coffee is not too sweet, and just tastes good! The "sticky" waffle kind of reminds me of those at Northstar - sticky, sweet, soft and just delicious! Since SF is a bit out of my way, I'm able to get blue bottle coffee at Friache in Palo Alto :)
author: Cindy T.

description: Its a shame that I dont have this store closer to home in Concord.  Excellent espresso, excellent froth.  Only thing I would wish for was that they would give us the ability to add shots to a drink.  Id like 3-4 shots in my Latte.
author: Ivan D.

description:
I'm jolted by the caffeine high and I haven't even finished my cup....New Orleans iced has done the trick today :) 

Friendly service and the server was well informed to explain their "obnoxious process" for their iced coffee. 

Layers of flavor are lingering on my palate. yummmm
author: Charlene A.

description: I just don't get it. I love coffee but I only drink it black, maybe it's only special as a mocha or with steamed milk? Certainly not worth the wait.
author: Mar R.

description: Clearly, this is a company that operates for the benefit of its own executives and employees from the top on down. They serve lukewarm coffee and refuse to grind beans because they use "sustainable" packaging that wouldn't keep the ground coffee fresh. I say that if the customer still wants the beans to be ground in spite of the packaging, you grind the beans to please the customer. There is a reason why Blue Bottle can't make it outside of SF and NY -- and why its previous investors dumped it in October 2012.
author: Sherri W.

description:
The gibraltar here is amazing. The espresso shots are pulled perfectly and I enjoy it every time.

What I do not enjoy is the layout of this place! I was so surprised that they placed the shop out this way, as it makes absolutely ZERO sense. Not only is it unclear where the line begins and where it ends, the payment process was a bit absurd. You pay one person, the next person asks for your order, you tell them you already paid, then the barista pulling shots asks what you want and if you've paid. Also unclear why they made two windows with the tables in the middle...if you want them for your customers, it's hard to discourage any and all to sit and eat there from other shops when it's placed in the middle of the floor.

HOWEVER all that being said, their coffee still rocks and I'm sure in time they will readjust this layout and make it flow a bit better.
author: Abby Z.

description: Quality coffee.  Traditional menu.  They only downside is the long wait line, no-to little seating, and hipster barista's with 'I'm cooler than you' attitude--although I find them amusing. The only other coffee shops I would give a 5 star rating to are Ost (Intelligentsia Coffee), and Intelligentsia in Venice Beach, CA.
author: Wing C.

description: I keep hearing about Blue Bottle from my foodie friends...then Anthony Bourdain mentions it on the SF Layover.  Now I just HAVE to try it.  I don't go to the city often, so I went on-line and ordered a bag to be sent to my house.  I like using a French Press and i've tried Starbucks, Peet's, Allegro (Whole Foods), Verve, Acme, Ritual, and now Blue Bottle.  I'm sold!  I love it!!!  Its fresh roasted, organic, and never goes bitter.  I got a bag of the Three Africans Blend.  Its so good...I'll be ordering more!!!
author: Carolyn P.

description: The coffee is great but the place is a zoo on weekends. Long wait and too many people.  Very limited seating to rest your bones after a trek across SF.  Lots of great little businesses for foodies and a farmers market here in the Ferry Building.
author: Steve E.

description: Hype is always not a good thing. I had to wait in line for close to 10 minutes, not including the time after i paid. Coffee was good and strong. Pricey, but so is everything else in the Ferry Building.
author: Ray C.

description:
I really liked the smooth consistency and the floral flavor of the espresso here. The milk in my latte was super frothy and richly steamed to perfection, but hey it's Clover organic milk, which makes all the difference in any capacity. I bought some beans to take home with me and I have to say, they were good but not amazing. I don't recall the exact variety but the flavor was intensely herbal where I prefer more nutty, rich notes in my coffee. The way they roast their beans looked like they were decaf, but I'm used to my whole bean coffee being shiny from natural oils, which gave off the impression that they seemed a little dehydrated or dare I say past their prime. I probably sound like a douche for being so persnickety, but I'm just describing what I've come to like and have learned from the old days working as a barista. 
Word to the wise, there will be a wait. It took about 30 minutes for me to get a latte because the nice solo gentleman behind the bar was also the ringer, expediter, and bean guru running the fort. For a perfected latte, it's worth the wait, but if you're in a hurry, I wouldn't bother.
author: Danielle D.

description:
The Gibraltar

I love the walk to the Ferry Building. It's quick and quiet. The residents of North Beach are burning fires to warm their hearths and the smell of wood smoke wafts around the pedestrians beckoning them to remember that it's fall.  I thought of the leaves changing back home in the South. All the reds, yellows, browns and pinks splattered across the mountain I grew up on. I thought of the pumpkin patches, plastic spiderwebs and the cool nights. The smell of rotting leaves mixed with fire is a scent I wish I could bottle and wear around my neck for the rest of my life. 

The golden light and echoing sounds of the Ferry Building greeted me as I stepped through the doors. Blue Bottle Coffee Company's simple stall beckoned to me. I was so close to relief from the brisk outside breeze and the fix I desperately needed. Caffeine. Caffeine. Caffeine. I was vulnerable and willing like an alcoholic standing outside of the door to their favorite bar. 

I strolled up to the front of the line to a kind-faced employee. "Do you have something called a Gibraltar?" I asked. She nodded, "Is that what you want?" "Yes." The counter girl scrawled my name on a small notebook with "Gilly" next to it. Even coffee cannot escape endearments.

I listened to the violent sounds of the baristas as I waited for my undiscovered beverage. They hit the espresso handles against the rubber discard bin. They clinked together the coffee cups. They unapologetically cranked the screaming steam. They slammed the metal milk carafes on the hard granite.  The most succulent espresso drinks are born out of violence. 

A tall boy with dirty blonde hair called my name as he held a shot glass with the most beautiful, caramel-colored concoction. So this was Gilly. I watched as the liquid morphed down the sides of the cup leaving a layer of shiny foam on the top. It was almost too entrancing to drink. Almost.

The first hit of warm, bitter coffee hit the back of my tongue with an intoxicating punch. I'm not a black coffee person. I like sugar and cream. However, this luscious little drink could very well turn me to the dark side. It felt dangerous. Rich. Wrong. It was all the best parts of an affair in a glass.

I felt a sense of longing for my second dose before the first was even finished. The last and most bitter sip slipped down my throat. It was good. It was gone. The coffee-stained  container looked betrayed, defiled and guilty. 

As I walked away from the amber-lit interior of the Ferry Building, the dark delight lingered in my mouth and the pungent flavor of coffee rested contently on the back of my tongue. The Gibraltar's sinewy strength snaked its way into my bloodstream warming my body from the inside out. I felt Gilly as she gingerly coaxed my eyelids into opening and I thanked her for the gesture. My brief and dirty encounter with her had renewed me. At least, for a few fleeting moments.
author: Erin S.

description: Such good coffee. I tried the new Orleans style iced coffee. The coffee had beautiful undertones to it and the drink really didn't need any sugar to enhance it. I wish they offered larger sizes, as I could easily have drank double of what I had.
author: Chelsea M.

description:
Humphry Slocombe Secret Breakfast affogato, the new Breakfast of Champions.  (It used to be Jolt 'n' 151 with a chocolate PopTart.)

And, Bella Donovan beans back in the house.
author: Mutant O.

description: blue bottle coffee is a fetish-style coffee establishment, where they focus on slow, deliberate, and carefully executed preparation of coffee drinks. The coffee is amazing, but the wait can be excruciatingly long.Nevertheless, I highly recommend it and tend to get one of their copies at least once every other day.
author: Brian M.

description: Serious coffee lovers may dispute this review, but I found this to be a rather long line for seemingly normal coffee.   Perhaps that's because I prefer my coffee iced, and maybe that's not Blue Bottle's forte.  The coffee gear offered for sale were of interest, but otherwise perhaps not worth the stop.
author: WaitingIs F.

description:
This place is amazing... tucked away in a hidden spot they offer a destination with special coffee and special treats. They also have a small breakfast/brunch offering with a few slightly higher priced items. 

On my visit, I ordered the southern coffee. It was served iced, with milk, and contained a chicory flavor. It was rich, delicious, and enjoyable. I had a baked good (something involving liquor) that was so dense the moisture seeped though the to-go bag and onto my hand. 

We did not stay, but I really had wanted to. The inside gives the vibe of being a white atmosphere that is modern traditional. Very inviting for reading, a slight brunch talk, or retreating to a modern setting for a few moment.
author: Natalie W.

description:
Before the start of a nighttime photo opt on The Embarcadero, I was craving some coffee and wanted to go to a coffee house I have not yet visited so I decided to give this place a chance. Plus it had a unique name, which I forgot to ask what it meant.

Not knowing what to expect, the shop and the stores around it seemed to be getting ready to close up. Even though they seemed to be rather busy with cleaning, they still took my order. Not quite the most friendliest service but its nothing I should complain about. Their menu was very simple and and didn't carry a variety of drinks but their Mocha sound rather unique. I always love it when coffee shops make neat designs on top of the lattes and the one they gave me made me smile =]. The mocha was SOOO delicious and smooth. It was not extremely hot either so I was able to drink it right away.

If I ever come back to The Embarcadero, I will definitely stop by the Blue Bottle Coffee again. I only gave it a 4 star because they did not seem to be the most friendliest and charming baristas from what I am use to. Maybe the next time I come back I will get a better experience =].
author: Daniel L.

description: Blue bottle is definitely my favorite go to coffee place.  Their new orleans iced coffee is so amazing.  It taste so good the way it is that I don't even have to add any sugar in it.  I wish I had a blue bottle near my house.  I would rather come here then go to starbucks or peets.
author: Joyce L.

description: I was told that this has one of the best coffee in San Fran. I ordered a mocha. It was certainly of a better quality than Starbucks and some random cafe in your neighborhood. But perhaps because I had such a high expectation, I thought it is fairly overrated.
author: Vivien S.

description: I recently went downtown on a chilly morning and forgot my jacket. This gave me a good excuse to try the hot chocolate at Blue Bottle (I'm not a coffee drinker). The customer service was friendly and I loved the care they took in the product (my hot chocolate had a cute heart swirled on top, like many of the pics posted here). I don't know if this is common, but my cup was the perfect temperature - I could drink it right away.  It tasted like good quality, very dark chocolate.  It wasn't very creamy or rich (fyi, in case that is your thing), but had a great flavor.  The line was uncharacteristically short, so I didn't have to wait long; I'm not sure if I would wait in a long line, but I will definitely return.
author: T _.

description:
I feel like Blue Bottle is a band wagon phenomenon. I love coffee, but if you've ever read my other reviews, you'll know that the overall picture is very important to me. 

I've been to several Blue Bottle locations and as an amateur connoisseur (with a little bit of coffee industry study under her belt), I do not see how the flavor of their coffee merits the wait time or price. Even their espresso drinks - which should be quick to make by nature - take forever to get. To be fair, I've had their drip, specialty iced, and cappuccinos. I will never have an espresso drink here again because it is ridiculous to do so when they hang their hat on drip coffee and when there is so much better to be had elsewhere. Their specialty iced coffee is inconsistent between locations and not worth the price. I've had their drip coffee, but it was ok. I do not think their method of brewing does anything for the flavor. It's a lot of show that promises a big finale but is very disappointing.

I have not had the much commented about waffles, but I have had their pastries in different locations. Once again, very over priced for the quality and flavor. It makes me wonder if my fellow San Franciscans are just suckers for a high price tag and hot-spots. I'm not saying the coffee is bad, mind you. Just that it is not worth the ridiculous wait. 

For those of you who drink espresso drinks, I would recommend Bao Necci in North Beach. They are masters of their craft and have a properly maintained machine - as evidenced by what you see in the bottom of your cup afterwards... few, if any grounds! In addition, their coffee is outstanding and is the closest to Italian coffee as any other place I've found. You don't have to wait 20 minutes, there are places to sit and the price is appropriate.
author: Maria Y.

description:
For starters, the coffee drinks are excellent.  I come here with co workers for morning coffee and I've tried their lattes, drip coffee, cappuccino and mocha.  All of them are nicely strong and flavorful with nice creamy milk froth on top.  On product alone, this is a must taste.

The drawback is the wait.  The staff are very friendly but the service is sloooow.  Even when there are only 3 or 4 people in line, it can take 25 minutes to get your drinks.  The drinks are also often not very hot when served. 

So the flavor is excellent, but BB loses one star for slow service and one for often serving lukewarm espresso.
author: Bryce M.

description: Location is great,  blue bottle coffee's serve coffee in real glasses request the cups. Coffee is strong!!  Really good I love that each cup is made to perfection! very little seating tho, and not your coffee house feel since it is a stand. convenient location
author: Diane S.

description: The coffee is unbelievably good as usual.  It might be the best coffee I have ever had, although there was this one cup in NYC, but that's another story.  The 2 star, possibly 1 star comes from the service at the Ferry building outpost.  Someone at Blue Bottle has to secret shop this store.  No eye contact from start to finish?  It just seems like I am inconveniencing them every time I order a cup of coffee.  I will temper this with the fact that I have in fact received stellar service here before, probably 50% of the time.  It really just depends on who it is at the register.  Unfortunately 50% does not cut it in a competitive service orientated business. That said, I will still be going here to get coffee.
author: Jeff C.

description: I don't know what the big deal is.  I tried the New Orleans style iced coffee.  It was good, with a nice subtle flavor that I couldn't quite put my finger on.  But it wasn't worth standing in a long line for.  That being said, even though I'm from Seattle, I'm not exactly a coffee connoisseur.
author: Jimmy W.

description:
the best coffee in sfo.

i don't know what makes it so tasty but their drip coffee da best.  i thought pete's were the best, but was wrong.  sorry pete's.  

i like to start a day with great acme pastry and blue bottle coffee!
author: Little D.

description: Went to the Blue bottle in the Ferry Building. It was really hot that day and I needed an ice coffee. I remember not liking the ice coffee at the Blue Bottle at Japantown so I asked for a ice latte, they said sorry NO. I said uhh ok then give me a ice mocha, sorry Uh NO! Fuck! what is iced here besides the yucky ice coffee? NOTHING! And again no artificial sweetners. Ok I get the whole organic natural thing you are trying to do but common! What about diabetic customers? You know there are Organic artificial sweetners now
author: Karen T.

description: If I could I would have an IV run through my vein with blue bottle coffee, however, I would be missing the amazing taste of this individually hand made coffee. I bought all the stuff to make it at home. The friendly staff thought me exactly how to make it, which is an art form in itself. I am able to replicate the experience at home.
author: Magda V.

description: My fave in SF! I always get my fix when i go to the Ferry bldg. Want to try the waffles nxt time.
author: Toni T.

description: I stopped at Blue Bottle after my feast at Hog Island and waited in fairly long line. I am a big coffee drinker and I wanted to see how Blue Bottle compared. I ordered the New Orleans Iced Coffee which I had read about in The Chronicle. It was good, but not wait in line and spend $3.75 good. I was expecting a much more robust flavor out of a so-called New Orleans coffee. Next time I would try one of their regular coffees or an espresso. In the meantime, I will stick with Weaver's Coffee, which is on a completely different level from any other coffee company that I've found.
author: Christian D.

description:
I had a cappucino at Blue Bottle the other day after lunch. The flavor was excellent. They clearly do not over-roast there beans, the coffee was complex - rich, thick, a hint of chocolate flavor, fruit flavors of the bean, excellent foam. There coffee stands out, like no other!
I now see why there are lines during peak hours.
author: Eat See Be E.

description: The secret window is the way to go. Shhhhh, don't tell anyone else!
author: Tracy A.

description: I'm all about regular coffee, but when I saw the pretty drinks my friends got I had major coffee envy! I came here after lunch at Pier 23 which included a few midday beers = nap time! I had a few hours left at work so went straight to Blue Bottle to get my caffeine on. Their regular coffee is delish! But next time I want to get one of their fancy drinks!
author: Casi C.

description:
Once upon a time, in another time and another place, I loved the Blue Bottle Coffee at the Farmer's Market. 

Now, I would rather sip Folgers from a styrofoam cup than buy coffee at this Blue Bottle location.  Don't get me wrong, I adore Blue Bottle, but NEVER, EVER at the Ferry Building again. 

There is this thing called customer service.  I recall Blue Bottle knew what wonderful customer service looked like once.  I always got my coffee with a smile from either of the coffee carts in the past.  

These days, I watch you guys get worse and worse with each visit.  However, my experience two weeks ago is making this the end.  I was at your side window, in line behind a family.  You looked at me, continued making coffee, and then looked at me again, saying nothing.  I waited as you made coffee for another for five minutes.  You looked at me again, and you went on to another cup.  And when I finally got directly in front of your window, you said you were closed.  Um...  There was nobody in line after me; you really could have made an exception.  Or at the very lest, a "I'm sorry I didn't tell you ten minutes ago when I first saw you in line that I am closed already."  Instead, you were very short with me, and I was extremely surprised by your curtness.  When I went into the store's line for coffee, I mentioned to the cashier that you guys should get a specific sign for the window.  And this was the response, "Well that's why we have a store line."  Um...  I don't think so.
author: Wendy L.

description: There is always a line, they have a bad attitude and the coffee is bitter and burned. Not good.
author: Luca R.

description:
Great lattes and mochas. Surprisingly they don't charge extra for soy milk which I give major kudos to Blue Bottle for!! I'm willing to pay the steep price for a nice tasty soy latte that Blue Bottle serves up and the fact they don't double fist you with the added charge for soy milk will keep me coming back. 

Have a soy latte from Blue Bottle and get centered.
author: Steven P.

description: I don't understand why more people don't figure out the secret window at Blue Bottle Ferry Building.  It usually shaves off at least several minutes from your wait and the whole menu is available there (although they do use a different roast for espresso and coffee drinks - inquire as to what they're using daily). We come to the Bay Area a few times a month for work and always make it a point to stop by BB Ferry Building - their beans are always incredibly fresh - usually roasted within a few days and their espresso drinks are made w/ the impeccable care we've grown accustomed to.  Highly recommend the homemade granola, it's one of the best I've ever had...
author: Mishel F.

description:
Hello Cappuccino is part milk part foam not all milk.

Long line, disinterested staff, if you want a good cappuccino this is not the place to go. Try Cafe Trieste in North Beach for the real deal.

Pricy too
author: Another U.

description: I have mixed feelings about the coffee.  Like most 3rd wave places in SF, it favors bright, acidic coffee, which isn't my first choice.  Similar places in NY tend to have heavier, smoother coffees.  I do like the fact that they take coffee seriously, but the service is also super-snobby, so you need to be in the right mood to deal with it.  However, the thing that really keeps me coming back is the affogato.  This is perhaps the perfect affogato.  The combination of the slightly bitter, somewhat acidic espresso and the smooth, sweet ice cream is beyond description.  Perfection.
author: John D.

description: I know everyone raves about blue bottle coffee but I honestly don't think it's that great.  I ordered the drip coffee and it was extremely bitter.  I'd definitely go to philz coffee over blue bottle any day!  I may actually prefer starbucks over blue bottle as well.
author: Vicky C.

description: Long lines, all the time. But it is the same price as Starbucks and so much more rich and flavorful. Try it, especially if you're not from here! It is the best locally brewed coffee in the area.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Five minutes before close. 6:55  pm. Wouldn't serve me a simple latte. Said they were already closed. Mini line of people cut off mid line.. Attitude off the charts.  Love their coffee but sour ass baristas never win. Get a life. Told me to go to peets!
author: Jp M.

description: I tried their Affogato which is vanilla ice cream with a shot of espresso poured over on top. For someone who isn't a big fan of the taste of coffee, the Affogato was really good! The espresso is strong by itself so make sure to get a decent amount of ice cream on your spoon with the espresso. The serving is a pretty fair amount--they give you two scoops. Apparently, this Affogato is from Humphry Slocombe too? My friend and I wanted to check out that place but thankfully Blue Bottle Coffee had this! Their service at this coffee joint is really fast too. Even though the line seemed long, I got my order within 3 minutes of ordering it.
author: Mary D.

description:
The coffee is great, so four stars, but the lay out of this location is horrible. The line snakes awkwardly through the store space leaving no where to really stand and wait for your drink (unless the ferry building isn't crowded, which isn't too often). Further more, the tables and seating are so outside of the store front that they are completely rendered useless with non-customers sitting eating ice cream from the nearby Cia Bella Gelato.

But its the coffee that counts, and its dam good.
author: Alex D.

description:
I really don't see what the big deal is about this place.  I just had my first Blue Bottle coffee today, and was eager with anticipation.  Now that I've had it, I can honestly say that what we brew here in the office (Peet's beans) is way better.  And FREE.  Maybe I got it on a bad day?  The dude didn't look particularly rushed or anything, though.

Overrated.
author: Eric H.

description: What could be better than individually made drip coffee and a waffle to go on a gorg saturday morning by the bay!!! Had to wait awhile but you know what they say... Good things come to those who wait! Enjoyed the atmosphere and hustle and bustle of the farmers market. Nice way to start my vacay!!
author: Steph N.

description: I'm originally from San Diego and made the move up to the Bay Area.  My family used to own a coffee shop, so I learned to drink my coffee black.  Now, I don't dare to put anything in my coffee.  I've had some top notch, upscale coffees in my life including 100% Kona Peaberry, and the prized Blue Mountain Jamaica, and I have to admit... Blue Bottle Coffee Co can roast some quality beans.  I am going to rank them in my top 5 coffees.  I like that they also support free trade.  Try a Blue Bottle Coffee if you're ever at the Ferry Building or in the Bay Area in general.  You can purchase a half pound for a reasonable price.  EXCELLENT!!!
author: Richie C.

description: It was good, but not so amazing that I'd do it again. The coffee was strong, a bit bitter, but with no aftertaste. I didn't even finish mine. Then while we were sitting at the bar, this woman told us we'd need to leave because they were having a business meeting for their company there. It was neat to see the drip coffee and the service before we were at the bar was great!
author: Kristin P.

description:
The drip coffee was very good.  They do a separate drip for each customer, which was sort of cool and interesting, however, this also means that it takes a couple of minutes for them to serve your coffee.  It's a little pricey, $2.75, for what would be a small coffee.  But it was very good coffee.  Quite strong, the way I like it.

Also, I tried the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee.  I asked the cashier what it was and as she was explaining it to me, a customer butt in and said, "Oh you gotta try it, it's the best!" So I didn't hear what it contains, other than chicory and milk.  Anyway, based on this customers enthusiasm over the drink, I bought that along with my drip coffee.  It was also very good.  Pretty weak though, especially compared to the drip.  I would say this drink was very expensive.  It cost $3.75 for a small cup.  Although it was good, I'd probably never order it again because I don't think it's worth the price.

The line at the counter was very long and moves very slowly.  I didn't really like that, but all of the employees seemed to be very nice to the customers.

Although I liked this place and I would definitely get coffee from here again, I wouldn't go out of my way to get here.
author: S. M.

description:
This place is simply not the bee's-knees, in terms of espresso. Both times I've given this place a try, I've received courteous service and a poor quality drink. I've had a double espresso and a cappuccino. Both were average and I could probably do better on my home machine. It's not a bad place to go, but when you have access to Ritual (in the Mission), which consistently serves excellent espresso drinks, it's no contest. Sorry, Blue Bottle.

As an addendum, I did purchase their Hayes Valley Espresso and made it at home, and it was amazing. Perhaps I just don't like the Retrofit blend they use at their store, but I doubt it.
author: Karl N.

description: my love of coffee....truly LOVE their coffee and the TLC they put into making each cup of brew! smells delicious. tastes phenomenal! drip coffee is the best!
author: Esther K.

description: the line was crazy long, which really got me wonder if this place lived up to the hype. and guess what? i was blown away by the affogato. the expresso shot was rich and it complemented the ice cream perfectly! my only complaint is that the line is kind of slow and it is pricy. BUT DEFINITELY WORTH A TRY!
author: Louis O.

description: Must try the New Orleans Iced Coffee...cant miss!
author: Ruben L.

description: Review for Belgium waffle only: The waffle was good. Not sweet at all, but not enough sweetness. It was lacking flavor. It was also kind of oily. Too much oil on the waffle machine? I'd rather get the coffee drinks.
author: Vera W.

description: great individual drip coffee.  the afogato is really good as well.  long wait times during lunch, but well worth the wait!
author: Scott L.

description:
Just had my inaugural BBCC experience with the standard drip coffee.  Excellent coffee - rich and strong, with a little smoky aftertaste.  This is a great mid-afternoon break as it will take at least 10 minutes for you to order and receive your coffee.  Not good if you're in a rush, though.  On a warmer day, I may try the iced coffee.  That is truly the test of good coffee.

I think I prefer Philz - they accommodate more milk/artificial sweeteners and I enjoy having a wide variety of beans to choose from there.  But, this is also quite good and I understand, the quinessential San Francisco experience.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Coffee: I must admit I'm not a super coffee freak (starbucks is usually good enough but not that great) but I was very impressed by my latte. It was delicious and delightful and I wish I could get one every morning.

Service: Excellent. Everyone was friendly and warm without being too chatty. Lack of chattiness is my own personal preference in the morning, by the way, I did not get the impression that anyone working there didn't want you to talk to them. In fact, a few people had questions and they were very helpful and engaging. 

Atmosphere/Wait: I got there early. A few minutes before they opened actually. By the time they officially opened, there were about 8 people waiting. The staff had already started some coffees, however, so I doubt any of the other people had to wait very long. So get there early!
author: K B.

description:
The coffee is great.  It is one of the few things I am willing to wait in  a long line for.  I recommend this coffee all the time.  My only complaint is the service is getting sloppy.  Just at the cart they have outside the Ferry Building.  They keep forgetting to give my drink order to the person making the drinks.   This has happened the last three times I went to them.  On my last visit.  the girl got distracted and then looked in her hand and asked  "Who just gave me this money?"   Me. I'm standing right in front of you.  I am waiting for my change.   Of course the person behind me ordered the same thing I did.  When the drink order came up I went to grab it.  Only to have another employee say  "This isn't yours" and give it the the guy that was behind me.   

I still go to them.  Just not to the cart anymore.  So five stars for the coffee.  minus two stars for the service.

I will still go to them.
author: Jay B.

description: Consistently awesome coffee from very friendly staff who know their stuff.
author: Jean T.

description: Since last year, at least that's when I first heard of it, there have been raves about drip coffee. My friend told me about this place and so she took me here to try it out. Seriously and honestly, it was okay. Yeah, she made such a big deal about how wonderful filtered-drip coffee (or however you say it) was here that I gave-in to try it out. Eh! I still love my espresso drink from Peet's at Opera Plaza, my home-brewed French Press coffee at home, or a cup or two or three at Lucky Penny's on Geary & Masonic. I seriously don't have time for coffee to drip through a filter. The coffee didn't live up to all of the hype that this place has received.
author: Neni E.

description: Went there to check out the "famed" drip coffee & Belgian waffle from the EAT list. Loved that the waffle was hot off the iron & slightly carmelized. I could see the steam rising out of the waffle when they handed it to me in the drip coffee filter (love that! What an inventive use of on-hand inventory & sustainable!). The coffee was good too - no need to add sugar or cream in my opinion. I think I'm still a fan of Philz the most (Fire Alarm or something along those caffeinated lines). A little pricey but worth it - $6.04 for a waffle ($3) & drip coffee.
author: Marissa H.

description: Awesome drip coffee and pastries! There's always a line out the door, but i still have to make a stop here anyway. i really love coffee and this place has good coffee with friendly service to boot. it's definitely worth the wait and a nice souvenir to take home as well (it's whole beans, not ground). try it out!
author: sherrie n.

description: I usually base a coffee shop's tastiness by their drip coffee and blue bottle hasn't failed me. It's always flavorful and delicious. I have waited in line for more than 30 minutes just to get a cup, but that's also the reason why I didn't give it a full 5 stars (I'd give it a 4.75 if I could). Try not to go during the lunch rush because I guarantee you will spend your entire lunch waiting.
author: Gabrielle R.

description: Okay so I was passing by around closing time and a guy that works there was giving out free desserts. I'm guessing they were leftovers but my oh my were they amazing. Especially the rosemary olive oil shortbread omg! I Also had this crumble with fruits kinda cake and it was amazing. I did not get to try their coffee but would definitely go back for desserts :D
author: Amanda Z.

description: Decent espresso but it has a distinctive sour taste, as of my visit a couple of weeks ago.
author: Duncan T.

description:
I happened to be in the Financial District today running some errands with my parents. Having been thoroughly impressed by Blue Bottle's Mint Plaza location, I decided to drag my parents along for a Blue Bottle Coffee fix at the nearest location, which happened to be at the Ferry Building. The line wasn't long at all (less than five minutes in line), but the place was really popular. I ordered the drink that started it all for me: the New Orleans style iced coffee (I actually wanted to try the Kyoto style iced coffee, but it's not available at this location). It came out fast and was just as smooth and wonderful as it was the first time. Even without sugar, the coffee was surprisingly not bitter. I've tried ordering New Orleans style iced coffee at places that serve Blue Bottle Coffee (like Fraîche in Palo Alto), but they don't  turn out even half as good. My parents both went with a caffe latte and they kept praising the smoothness of the coffee. One concern they had, however, was the fact that their coffees were lukewarm at most. The barista said the milk steamer wasn't working. If hot beverages are a must for you, make sure you check that the milk steamer is working when you get your beverage! Otherwise, you may be slightly disappointed.

This location seems to be centered around to-go orders. It's in the Ferry Building, so the setting isn't as relaxed and laid-back as the Mint Plaza location. There isn't as much seating either (just a few seats by the bar). Macchiatos can't be taken to-go, so keep that in mind as well.
author: Josh W.

description: I don't fancy myself as much of a coffee drinker, but I always try to go to Blue Bottle when I'm near the ferry building.  The coffee is rich, and since it's always properly roasted--the natural sweetness of coffee jumps out (no need for sugar with this stuff).  The macchiato is excellent, and on a warm day the New Orleans iced coffee is unbeatable.
author: Don N.

description:
Random crazy woman in line at Blue Bottle day 1 

"Oh my god you have to try their New Orleans Iced Coffee. It is the best damn coffee I have ever had in my life. 
I heard they make the coffee the night before and let it soak overnight with all the special ingredients and that's why it tastes so amazing. Trust me man when I say you have to order one, it will change your life!" 

So I ordered one and although it was good it did not change my life. 
I'm not the biggest coffee drinker so maybe an avid coffee drinker would like it a little more then I did. It was a little strong for my taste but when I added some raw sugar to it I thought it was good. It was about $3 dollars or so and I thought that was not too bad. 

Random sane woman in line at Blue Bottle day 2 

"I love their mocha made with Rechutti chocolate, it is my drink of all time." 

So I went back to BB the next day because I really wanted to love this place because of all the great reviews I read and because so many people told me I had to check it out. I decided to go with this sane woman's recommendation, and I'm so pleased I did. This mocha was phenomenal. It tasted like a melted down piece of dark chocolate. This was by far the best mocha I have ever had in my life. I also thought it was really cool how they make designs on the top of the drink, it was almost to pretty to drink. The mocha is not served as hot as other ones I have had but that didn't bother me at all. This drink was a little high priced ($4.50) but since it was so good, and because I won't get the chance to have one again any time soon I did not mind paying that price. If I lived in SF (which I hope will happen some day) I would probably only get one of these delicious high priced drinks once a week.
author: Craig R.

description: The best coffee in The City, and my personal favorite. Regular drip and New Orleans Iced were amazing. Took some beans home as well.
author: Gabriel P.

description: Don't dare request a bag of ground coffee beans. After carefully handpicking two bags and waiting in line a good 10-15 minutes, I was met with a look of horror and the curt reply: "we never grind our beans" (never? really??). Coffee is good, but good can be found elsewhere, minus the snobbery.
author: Laura S.

description: Just got the drip.  It's better than normal coffee since it was dripped to order.  So its fresh.  Better quality so you get what you pay for.
author: Daniel T.

description: I like my coffee black, strong, bitter and a bit nutty. I ordered the drip it sounded like it would be right up my alley. And while it was leaps above what you'd find in a drive-thru, I expected more. It was not worth the wait.
author: Kellee K.

description: There were some seriously classy people holding down the fort at Blue Bottle today, in the Ferry Building.  It was a gorgeous Sunday in San Francisco, sunny and breezy and cool after the pounding rainstorm yesterday.  Everybody was out and about...and in the line at Blue Bottle around 3:00 p.m.  After waiting for 30 minutes in line, feet aching, my friend and I were finally in sight of an affogato...she had never had one and I raved about how it was the best treat on earth so she was craving it too.  Well, it was April Fool's Day, and the joke was on us, because the person ahead of us in line got the very last one.  They'd run out of Humphry Slocombe Secret Breakfast.  The gentleman making the coffee took pity on us -- I can only imagine the looks of horror, chagrin and disappointment on our faces -- and comped us each a delicious mocha with a beautiful little foam design traced on top.  And he threw in a piece of shortbread.  They have just turned a fan into a loyal and grateful repeat customer.
author: Lira K.

description: Fantastic Coffee in a wonderful location. In my mind, this is an ideal place to come on special occasions or to impress visiting friends/family, etc. I could easily get hooked on this stuff, but I'd rather indulge every once in a while so I can remind myself what a terrific latte or cup of coffee tastes like.
author: Adam W.

description: Over the last 365 days I have had just about 1200 cups of black coffee.  Most at independents with locally roasted coffeee.  My coffee last Tuesday morning at BBCC in the Ferry Bldg was the best.
author: Dan W.

description: The latte is always so rich and smooth, and the ice coffee brings me to Brazil (even though it's supposed to be New Orlean style). Ugh, why do you have to be 'a good 15-min walk from my work', Blue Bottle??
author: Mary L.

description:
This is just a little marketplace outpost in the Ferry Building, so the line to order coffee was winding through the main walkway of the marketplace, causing a bottleneck in the flow of Ferry Building shoppers at peak-coffee-hours (which, unfortunately, also seem to be peak-shopping hours in this building).  Needless to say, the line is completely mismanaged, and with slow (read: customized) service, perhaps the layout of this Blue Bottle was hastily thrown together?  Or perhaps when they built the coffee bar, they had no idea how popular they'd become.  I suppose it's a good problem to have if the latter is true.

To their merit:
The baristas make impressive little pictures in the foam, and the mint tea is actually made from muddled mint....yes, I saw them pick the leaves off a plant growing out of a terra cotta pot produced from under the counter.

The product is obviously of the highest-quality, but the little outpost is so tiny and the line moves so slowly, that you may want to avoid during most busy-hours, or find another location for your inaugural Blue Bottle experience.
author: Heather G.

description: Needed a pick me up and after reading the menu... I saw Humphrey Slocumbe!! Ok... done deal. So the gf (also a fellow yelper) and I were standing in line for what seemed like forever until we stopped yapping our mouths in between eating macaroons, we realized we were standing behind the people waiting for their orders. Not feeling defeated at all, just quite embarassed, we made our way to the front and ordered the drink with two scoops of ice cream and a shot of espresso. The gf ordered the slow drip coffee. Both came out delicious. My ice cream concoction was perfect on this rainy day. Thanks to my love Joy Hallili Millare forcing me to come to SF on a Sunday morning. Happy belly. :)
author: Anne T.

description:
love blue bottle coffee!
delicious latte :)
thank you!
and i've been lucky... no long lines/waits
they individually drip each cup of coffee - very nice
author: charlotte s.

description: I rarely get to enjoy a saturday afternoon at the farmers market so today was a special one, especially since it was sunny out. I've always heard that blue bottle coffee was pretty great but somehow even after living in this city for over 5 years i've never had the pleasure. So today we waited in the crazy line and watched them work their magic for a good ten minutes. I had the gibraltar which isn't on the menu but was listed in the 7x7 things to eat before you die so I ordered it. It's espresso w/ a tad bit of milk. I am normally a late or cafe con leche type a gal so I liked the milk in it. It was very savory, rich and hit the spot. The hubs got a basic drip and like all the other reviews state, it was a great cup o coffee. We bought some to take home but didn't splurge do it yourself cups and filters. Good service and great quality.
author: Audrey V.

description: Good but not great very much sums this up. Was visiting for a long weekend and staying very close to the ferry building so this was a very close walk each day. Kept going back so by all means the place was fine just had better. Staff was very friendly and quick.
author: Tom B.

description: Pricing for black coffee wasn't bad. Quality and aroma of the dripped-coffee was very tasty. Lives up to the rave and long line that the cafe gets.
author: Jessry H.

description: The best Latte I've ever had. Absolute perfection from the flavor to temperature! My sister suggested the mocha for a sinful perk to your day! Blue Bottle coffee is also served at Mission Beach Cafe! Yipeee!
author: Miles G.

description: I had a delicious New Orleans style iced coffee hear. Small sizes, though.
author: Joshua S.

description: Long long queues on Saturday or Sunday morning even on the bar around the corner.  MOSTLY worth it.
author: Dave B.

description: The coffee here is great.  If you haven't been, do yourself a favor and go at least once so you can say you've been. Cash only. Expect to wait in line. Try a drip coffee (or if it's hot the New Orleans Iced Coffee or an Affogato). At this location there's no seating inside, but there are plenty of benches out back near the ferries.
author: Emily C.

description: I was looking for some good coffee when i visited San Francisco and the Blue Bottle was the best.  I love the individual drip...strong but smooth.  The walk-a-way waffle was good, too!
author: Linda K.

description:
I used to work a few blocks away from the first blue bottle coffee about 5 or so years ago and back then everything was great.  Yesterday I ordered a dry cappuccino and ended up with a lukewarm latte that was flat (no foam), the exact opposite of what I ordered.    How does that make sense?

Thanks for ruining my experience, never again will I buy from you.
author: jimmy z.

description:
Best. mocha. ever.

I have to confess. I'm not a big coffee drinker.  I can't drink my coffee black. And I love caramel macchiato from Starbucks.
Before I had my mocha here, I never understood mocha.   At most coffee shops, coffee overpowers the chocolate flavor, and it was a latte with a hint of chocolate.  So at coffee shops, I get a cup of hot chocolate when I felt like I needed a chocolaty drink and a cup of latte when I felt like drinking coffee. But not mocha.

Blue Bottle's mocha? The chocolate flavor is just as intense as the coffee flavor, and the drink is oh so smooth.  Frothy all the way down to the last sip.
author: Mary T.

description: After waiting for 20+ minutes in line and 10+ more after placing my simple order of drip coffee, I'd had enough and left!  If I want Blue Bottle Coffee, I'll go to Mint Plaza or Spin City in my 'hood.  I'll leave this amount of waiting to the tourists!
author: Vicente G.

description: Wait for the back window - the lattes there are even better!
author: Jonathan F.

description: I'm not really a coffee/espresso drinker, but 7x7's list recommended the GIbraltar ($2.75), so I had to give it a try. Let me tell you, this small espresso with milk in a small glass cup was delicious and strong. Came in the morning for the Sat. Ferry Building Farmers Market. Picked up my Gilbraltar before doing shopping with the fam, so there was no line.
author: Marcus L.

description: I quietly hated the hipster boy behind the counter as he painstakingly completed each task in front of him.  The line was incredibly long but that did not inspire the cashier to move at any pace faster than the speed of molasses.  I have never seen anyone take so long to write down an order, turn to the barista to discuss the order and walk over (in almost slow motion) to the drip coffee station to laboriously pour water into a coffee filter.  As I stood there in line I began to wonder if the cashier existed in another world where he must work through matter more viscous than air his movements were so dilatory.  I understand that each cup is made with care, but the baristas were kicking ass, making delicious espresso drinks quickly, but with care.  After FINALLY getting my caffeine inside me my opinion of the mustached-beanie-hat-wearing-cashier improved but not enough for me to forget a few weeks later when I'm writing this review.  All that being said, I'll be back, I really like their mochas.
author: Madeline W.

description: be prepared to wait FOREVER for a latte. Came a few times and i've always had a super long wait. As i stood waiting...and waiting...they had me asking if they had left the counter to fly down to south america themselves to purvey the coffee. Serving size small for the price. It's good but I've had better. Also no artificial sweetners are anywhere to be found so I had to go over to Peet's to get some.
author: Rebecca S.

description: coffee. americano. it was good, but i think CA people just get hive mind and start thinking places are awesome (sorry, i'll say the same about in & out). its good coffee, no doubt, and i'll take it over starbucks to support the indie shopkeeper, but its just a barista doing his/her job -- nothing phenonemal.  people don't do props for "not screwing up".
author: Eric L.

description: Yay! I'm a fan.  I had heard this was "the best coffee ever!"  It was good... really good... but not the best coffee ever.  I did like it, though!  :)
author: Lindsay C.

description:
This place would be 5 stars if they weren't so fucking pretentious.  Yeah, your espresso is fantastic, and your beans are awesome.  But I have a bone to pick with you.  You've got industrial quality coffee grinders.  You only sell unground beans.  I happen to have a rather fancy-pancy grinder in my kitchen.  So the story would probably end there... 

Except that on that particular day, I was trying to get my friend into brewing her own coffee.  You sell great little ceramic one-cup drippers from japan, and german filters.  So I buy her a bag of beans and filters, order an espresso, and then ask that you grind the beans.  "We don't grind our beans."  

ARE YOU SHITTING ME?!  I know you grind them to make the coffee, friend, because this coffee-making process is not a black box to me.  I've seen behind the curtain (or in this case, behind your over-inked shoulder) so I know that you've got a grinder sitting idle waiting to turn your beans into something my coffee novice friend can enjoy without spending $100 on a burr grinder.

"pretty please?"
"in order to ensure the best flavor you have to grind the beans right before you brew the coffee.  so we don't grind our beans," (even if you ask nicely.)

Thanks for the lecture.  The espresso was impeccable, despite it being served with a side of deuchebaggery...
author: K D.

description: I don't like coffee. I don't like paying for coffee. I don't like waiting ten minutes after paying for my coffee. But I'll drink the cappuccino and the New Orleans iced coffee here... if you pay for them. See, I can compromise.
author: Liz T.

description: Are you serious... Is that line worth the wait?!?  Hell yes it is!!! Get your ass and in line and order yourself a couple of drinks because trust me you'll want seconds and you won't want to wait again... amazing espresso shots and steamed milk!!
author: Matt G M.

description: Creamy and damn good down to the last perfectly roasted drop.  I love their cappuccinos!
author: Michelle H.

description: This is my go-to place for an afternoon cappuccino. The snickerdoodle is also amazing; there's a hint of saffron in it. Beware though, it takes at least 10 minutes to get your drink, typically.
author: Kevin L.

description: I love Blue Bottle Coffee and was very surprised to find it at the Ferry Building last Tuesday. My friend ordered an espresso while I had their Mocha. So yummy. Kept me a lil' wired throughout the day.
author: Mika D.

description: New Orleans Iced Coffee, I love you. Don't ever change. Also the Three African's beans are so good.
author: Angela K.

description: I tried the New Orleans iced coffee.  It was good, but not 3.50 for a small ass cup good.
author: Lawrence C.

description: Well I can only comment on the coffee; not the latte's etc.  So after waiting in line 15 minutes I order a coffee and wait while the guy slowly pores hot water over my grounds. This happens like 4 times over 5 minutes?  The coffee is done and I am handed my cup.  I add some cream and sit down and taste it and it tastes goood.  So what is the problem you ask?  The coffee is lukewarm and I have to chug it so it doesn't become cold.  Chuggin my coffee is not relaxing on a Sunday morning.  Tastes better than Peet's but I don't walk around with a microwave so I was dissapointed.
author: Mark M.

description: 4.5 They make a darn good cup of coffee!  I got the drip coffee and it totally hit the spot.  You know it's great coffee when you can just drink it black.  I rarely get no-cream-no-sugar opportunities so I was stoked to get my hot cup of joe, enjoy some great company, and soak in a nice clear day in San Francisco.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
My favorite: New Orleans iced coffee
2nd Favorite: Tied between giant steps drip and their lattes. 

The employees are much more helpful and nicer than the ones at Philz, too. =)

Yum, yum, yum!
author: Linda I.

description: Meh. It was alright. Not worth $2-something for a cup of regular drip coffee though. Really not worth waiting in a Starbucks-esque line for.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
There are three types of people who visit Blue Bottle at the Ferry Building.  

1.  Tourists who are meandering around the building with an hour or two to kill.  

2.  San Franciscans who happen to be in the neighborhood and want a Blue Bottle coffee and don't really have anything to do for a few hours.

3.  San Franciscans who work downtown and want a good cup of coffee and need to get back to work.

If you fall into category #3, stay away from Blue Bottle!  Yes, the coffee is good .  But for the love of God, is any coffee worth standing in line for 25 just to place your order??

I stopped by a week ago at 9am.  There were 16 people already in line.  I'm thinking it shouldn't take more than 10 minutes to get to the front of the line.  At 9:20 I'm still 3 - 4 people away from placing my order.  Keep in mind that I haven't even ordered my coffee yet!  I'm still standing in line just so I can place my order.

Fed up with the lackadaisical attitude of the two guys behind the counter (and someone who looked like a pastry chef, but simply stared blankly at the crowd as he carefully placed small treats in the display case), I ducked out and headed over to Peet's.  5 minutes later I've got my drink in hand, heading back to work.

I don't care how good the coffee is.  Only one star until Blue Bottle figures out how to stop wasting my time.  Until then, I'm a Peet's or Martha & Bros. customer.
author: Charlie B.

description: Perfect stop after lunch in the Ferry Building. New Orleans Iced Coffee = swag.
author: Karkar L.

description: The most overrated place in SF. I typically like Blue Bottle when served at other places but whenever I go here the wait is insane and the coffee is average, overpriced, the serving is too small, it's never that hot and the service sucks and the cashiers are rude.
author: Brian J.

description:
they said this is the best coffee in SF.

they weren't kidding.

seriously, blue bottle has the best lattes i've ever had. it's rich and smooth, and not bitter. they also don't burn the coffee like some other places (*cough*starbucks*cough*) sometimes do. i usually get a shot of vanilla or hazelnut in my lattes, but this stuff i like to drink plain. 

it's good stuff. and the leaf design in the foam? it's the icing on a very delicious cake!

the downside is the long line that always exists every time i come here, but it's worth it.
author: Caroline I.

description: May be there's something wrong with me, but I just can't get myself to like Blue Bottle. Both their espresso and drip taste sour to me in an unpleasant way. That's not to say it is bad, it is still very good. But I prefer a darker bolder taste... it's always too bright and acidic, I've tried Bella Donna and Three Africans but both my wife and I preferred darker oilier beans. Those waffles look delicious tho.
author: Joon L.

description: Blue Bottle was recommended to me when I first moved to SF. It is so close to my school and this local has a separate to go counter which is great if you're in a hurry. I LOVE IT! My only complaint is that there aren't more locations ie closer to my house!
author: Lucy S.

description: Delicious and beautiful!  They truly treat it like an art.  I've had the affogato, latte, espresso, & mocha and all of it is really good.  When I was in town for a week, staying at a place near the Embarcadero, my bf and I would trek down to the Ferry Building every morning so we could start our day with their espresso.
author: Nina K.

description: By now we should all be acquainted with Blue Bottle coffee, so I wont go into how impeccable I believe it is, but instead comment about this location. While I am glad that they have expanded from their two cart booths at farmers market, I feel that this location just isn't pulling it's weight. While they still bang out an excellent cup of coffee, every time I have stopping in here to by beans they have been sold out of just about every roast. Perhaps it's one of those early bird gets the worm deals?
author: Allyson S.

description: There is a difference!  Life doesn't get much better then being able to enjoy a spectacular cup of coffee in the beautiful Ferry Building during a break from working downtown.  The Baristas know what they are doing, triple filtered water and organic milk, beans roasted within just a few hours.  Anytime i see Blue Bottle I have to stop, even at local farmers markets.
author: Sean H.

description: Fantastic place!!!  Great coffee but you MUST order a made-to-order caramelized Belgian-style waffle...  7 x 7 said it's on of the top 100 things to eat before you die and I just died and went to heaven while devoring it along the bay during the morning hours on a beautiful Saturday at the Farmer's Market...
author: Aaron H.

description: Best place on the Embarcadero for a cappuccino or gibraltar.
author: Lion G.

description: Coffee is great and the latte is really cool looking.
author: Kenneth L.

description: First time I had latte art. So impressed...because my homemade lattes always end up looking like a disaster, what a sucker I am. Foam was smoooooth. Cup is kind of small, but it's probably the best tasting latte I've had.
author: Bill K.

description: I've heard so many great reviews from friends about the infamous Blue Bottle Co. Coffee and I finally got to try it, the lineup was insanely long, but when I had the first taste of my soy latte. OMG. Definitely worth the wait. I was skeptical about how great this coffee could possibly be but it really is amazing. Smooth, not bitter, great flavor, oh so right. I'm in love.
author: Ennie L.

description: the coffee is phenomenal!!! And fun to watch the barista do his magic.
author: Anya P.

description: It's good coffee, so here's two stars. Where did the other three stars go? They got tired of waiting in a 15-minute line to order a $2.50 small cup of coffee from a prenentious, unfriendly counter person. Those stars watched the barista move so slowly and casually (as the line of customers grew) that you would think he was a union MUNI mechanic with all the time in the world to perform each task asked of him. Those stars went over to Peet's, which was about 50 yards away, got great coffees (mediums for $1.80, BTW), and sipped their coffees while watching the Blue Bottle line move ever so slowly, and they wondered, "Why do humans love to queue up so much?" They also thought, "Hey, this Peet's is really good coffee."
author: Jesse C.

description: Who needs starbucks when you've got Blue Bottle Coffee? Yeah, it's a long line (not that looong) but totally worth the wait for their $2 fresh and strong cafe americano - eat it with next door's miette pistachio macaroon and you'll be one happy camper :p.
author: Jenny L.

description: I've only recently started to get into *real* coffee drinking--that is, coffee without syrups and majority milk and sugar. So I figured I was ready to try the Gibraltar (recommended by 7x7's list), which is essentially a shot of espresso with steamed milk in a small glass (think of a very strong latte). My coffee-drinking friend and I luckily came at a time where there was no line, so the wait and service was fine. Although I'd heard a lot about Blue Bottle being pricey, I think I paid $2.75 for it, so it wasn't bad. I'll admit I had to put some sugar in it because of the strength, but man, was that one smooth cup. The barista also put a leaf and heart design on it, so I think that, coupled with the crazy amount of caffeine, added to my giddiness. Definitely worth the trip and money. I'd like to come back and try some other stuff. (:
author: Jen T.

description:
insane lines aside, their mochas are the best thing around.  not to say that their drip coffee or cap is any good, but i that mocha w/ chocolate from recchiuti down the hall is just phenomenal!  it's must have for me for those groggy mornings.  

as an afternoon pick-me-up, their affogato, that has secret breakfast ice cream (bourbon and corn flakes) from humphry slocombe along w/ some well drawn espresso, will kick any low blood sugar levels you have towards the end of the day.  i'm drooling right now...
author: Swarup B.

description:
I was very resistant to trying out this place, considering my staple drinks are always extremely sweet, such as the vanilla lattes and caramel macchiatos from Starbucks, Peets, etc. 

But Blue Bottle Coffee's soy cafe latte - OMG!  LOVE IT! It's not bitter at all, and not necessary to add any additional sugar and syrup. The designs they decorate with the foam is so pretty!

So far, every time I've been to SF the past 3 years this place is a must.
author: Daphne L.

description: Really great coffee -- I've only had their iced coffee, and it is great.  Super strong, freshly roasted beans.  YUM.
author: Oliver S.

description: Excellent coffee.  Longish wait (10 mins?) but worth it for the quality. Highly recommended.
author: Mike S.

description: really good coffee, really nice people.  A bit expensive but worth it if you like your coffee individually dripped.  And their cookies and treats are even better and super unique.  There's an olive oil and lavender cookie.. and some other weird combo that are fun and surprising tasty.  I will come back for the treats for sure... coffee's too strong for me.
author: Janet S.

description:
